Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:When he was a small child he called the giraffe mascot a cow, it was a fond memory of the now defunct what? That means its sides are the same. It's 6 feet on each side, or __4__ feet on a side * 2. The 5 feet in the statement refers to the width. If it has __4__ feet on each side, there's only room for 3 feet of height in each direction, and 15 feet in each direction would be square.<n>```<n>6x6 square<n>2x2x2x2<n>```<n>6x7 is not square.<n>6x5 is square.<n>5x7 is not square<n>5x3x2x2 is square.<n>```<n>\$\begingroup\$ 5x4x3x2 is not square, but I guess it's valid? \$\endgroup\$<n><n>I think the wording here is the most problematic.<n><n>"The room must be square." That's not what was asked. A 3-foot by 4-foot room is perfectly valid, albeit unlikely, and the statement can be interpreted that way.<n><n>### The room must be square<n>The statement can only be interpreted in one way, and even then ambiguously. It was not ambiguous in the original question.<n><n>## Update 11/27/17<n>In an example about a question that asked a student to divide 42

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Lindy was a senior.  He lived with his children because he didn't want to go where? Choices:  A: republican party B: old people's home C: office D: park E: high school or college<n><n>### Response:		<n>```Lindy lived in an old people's home because he didn't go where<n>```<n><n>### <n>Input:During lunch break. What are you more likely to do? Choices:  Answer or text a friend.  Answer or play a game on your phone.  Read a book.  Push your luck by staying in the game longer than usual.  Text or read on your phone while you play.<n><n>### Response<n>```It isn't likely that you will answer a friend during lunch<n>break since you can text or read on your phone<n>```<n><n>## #0: No response.<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Why might a person go to get counseling? Explain your process.<n>### Response:#2. You need to know what the principal is, what the rate is, how many compounds, what the time is, and how many times the rate is compounded.<n><n>#3. If you have 100 gallons of water at a cost of $4 per gallon, how many inches of soil can you plant for $100?<n>### Response:#3. You will need to first convert gallons to inches and then multiply by 5 to get inches of soil.

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What would you do if you have curiosity about something but cannot leave your house? Choices:  A: hear testimony B: go somewhere C: see exhibits D: outdoor concert E: surf net<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### 3.  B<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input has a pattern, which is represented by the first three digits, where the first digit is a unit, the second digit is either a unit or a zero, and the third digit is zero.<n><n>If the pattern repeats to the right 8 times,  what is the total number of digits in the pattern?<n><n>#### 9<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: The first digit of the pattern is a unit.<n>The second digit is zero or a unit.<n>Therefore, the sum of the first three digits is a unit plus a unit plus a unit.<n><n>The digits repeat 2 times.<n><n>The total digits in the pattern is 2(1 + 0 + 0) = <<3=0>>0.<n><n>#### 0<n>Answer: 0<n><n>### Input 2:<n>#### Input 2<n>Input is a three-digit number that represents the temperature in degrees Fahrenheit.<n><n>If an integer 29 less than the input is added to it, what is the result?<n><n>#### 36<n>Answer: 36<n><n>#### 17<n>Answer: 17<n><n>### Solution 1:<n><n>### Input is a three-digit decimal number. An integer 29 less is subtracted from, and then 5 more is added and the results are <n>summed for each unit.<n><n>\### Rationale 1:<n><n>- The three digits represent the sum of the three single-digit values of the input.<n>- A value for each unit is generated, which is the sum of<n>- The original number plus or minus 29,<n>- and another plus or minus 5, respectively.<n><n>\## 29 less subtracted from the original<n>- A new value is generated for each unit. This new value is the original number minus 29.<n>- Since the original number was a three-digit number, the new value 29 less subtract from the original represents a two-digit decimal number.<n>\## 5 more is added to the new value for each unit<n>- Another value is generated for each two-digit value, which is the original number plus 5.<n>- Since the new value is a two-digit decimal 29 less subtracts from the original number represents a two-digit
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:A gentleman is very wealthy and flaunts it, where does he likely live? Choices:  A: europe B: big house C: tuxedo D: palace E: men's room<n><n>### Response:		<n>A gentleman  E: men's rooms<n><n>### Input(s)<n>```<n>2019-05-28T05:47:25-0400 [WARN] [org.springframework.boot.test.context.support.SpanningReporterFactoryBean@452f668c]<n>Unable to create SpannedTestExecutionEvents since the testOutputDirectory does not exist.<n>2019.05.28 5:47:30 [WARN]  [org.springframework.beans.factory.dirtiescontext.ContextScanner]<n>No ContextScanner found with rootClass be org.springframework.core.annotation.OrderMultiple. (Searched in the following locations:  classpath  PRIVATE CLASSPATH)<n>```<n><n>### Outputs<n><n>|  |  |<n>| ------------- | ------------- |<n>| Input(s) | A:europe;B:big house;C:tuxedo;D:palace;E:men's room |<n>| Outputs | A:europe |<n>```<n><n>##<n>### 1. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where would you put a handle if you want to bring it with you? Choices:  A: briefcase B: coffee cup C: carry object D: frying pan E: on a hat<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choices: A, D<n><n>### Rationals:<n>The handle is on A: a briefcase. We know this because it is brought with you.<n>We know that on B: a coffee cup, it's taken away.<n>We know that if it's brought with you, then the handle is on D: a frying pan.<n>So, it has to be on A: a brief case.<n>And a briefcase has a handle, too, so the handle is on A.<n><n><n>

How long did it take him to drive a total of 260 miles?<n><n>Rationales: So, the total time of the trip is 200 x 60 x 2 = <<200*60*2=1200>>1200.<n>The total number is 200*6 = <<200/6=33.33>>33.33,<n>and the total distance is 260 - 200 = <<260-200=60>>60<n>1200 / 33.33 = 35.5. As a decimal, 35.5 or 0r 3 and 5/10.<n>We can write it as 0r3 and 5/ 10 to solve 260 = 200 + << 33.3 + 60>> 3.33 6.33.<n><n><n>##### Recomemnded answers:<n>- 0r 3 5/10<n>- 0r3 5/ 195<n>- 0r5 5/ 185<n>- or 55/ 180<n><n>##### Recommented answe:<n>-3 5/195<n><n><n>### Input<n><n>During the summer, the price of a 15-ounce soda increases by 10 percent. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:He was looking for the holiday decorations and found an old box of clothes up where? How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Grocery stores do not pick potatoes. A farmer would be the person to hire to do that, so choices B, D, E, or F would be correct. Choices:  A: confusion B: complications C: riot D: arrest E: protests<n><n>### Response:		 D: arrest<n><n>### Rationale: B: Complaints (noun)<n><n>### N:N: Noun<n>(A): <n>confusion; n. the state of feeling bewildered or at a loss as to what to do <n><n>[source](https://quizlet.com/509537391/civil-disobedience-flashcards/)<n><n>### B:<n>Complications (verb)<n>compliCATiON : noun 1: the act of accepting or doing what someone has asked 2: a difficult, confusing, or annoying thing<n><n>[source](http://www.dictionary.com/browse/complication?s=t)<n><n>### D:<n>arrest<n><n>### R:<n>Noun<n>[https://study.com/academy/lesson/noun-definition-examples-quiz.html](https://study.<n>com/academy / lesson/noun- definition-examples-quiz. html)<n><n>### E:<n>protest<n><n>### RESULT:<n>\+ D<n>\+ B<n>\+ N: N: Noun<n>\+ R: Noun<n>\- C<n>\- E<n><n>### Rationales: noun: confusion; n. the stateof feeling bewildered orat a loss as to whattodo <n><n>### - C: <n>There are many variations to the spelling of complain, but they all mean the same thing: <n>(1) to express the idea that something is wrong or not quite right, and (2) to express <n>the idea that you have been hurt or annoyed, and something needs to be done about it.<n><n>### <n>the act of accepting or doingwhat someone has asked<n><n>### 2: a difficult confusing, or annoying something<n><n>### C:<n>confusion<n><n>### B : <n>Complaint (noun)<n>compliCATion : noun 1 the act of accepting or <n>doing what someone has asked <n>2: a difficult, or annoying something <n><n>### D : <n>arrest<n> <n>### N:<n>Noun<n><n>### R :<n>Noun    <n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where would I put a rosebush if I did not have any containers to store it in? Choices:  A: flower garden B: garden center C: pot D: pot E: formal garden<n><n>### Response:		In the greenhouse<n><n>

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Bob needs a level to hang a shelf but cant find one in his home. Where would he go to get one? Choices:  A: glass of water B: build evenly C: garage D: carpenter's shop E: video game<n><n>### Response:		A: glass of water<n><n>### Demostration:<n>  * You need a level to hang a box onto. If the box leans over on one side, it will fall off.<n><n>#### 21<n><n>### Response<n>A: glass of water<n>[Link to the right answer](https://github.com/TeacherTurtle/Lessons/tree/master/TurtlesAllTheWayDownV1.0/Chapter6/5)<n><n>```ruby<n>## Code here ##<n>puts: "Bob needs a level to build a shelf and cant find one in his house."<n>puts: "Choices:"<n>puts: "  A: Glass of water"<n>puts: "B: build evenly"<n>puts: "(c) Garage"<n>puts: (d) Carpenter's shop"<n>puts:  "(e) Gaming station"<n>puts:<n>puts: "Answer:"<n><n>## 5<n>answer: (c) Garage<n>```<n><n>## Chapter 5<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>#### 49<n><n><n>### Demstration:<n><n>#### 64<n><n><n>Input: Bob is building a box that has a long side and two short ones. Two of his sides are 5 centimeters shorter than the third. If Bob can make the long side 100 centimeters long, What can the side that's exactly half of the long side measure to be?<n><n>#### 48<n><n><n><n>### Response <n>48<n>answer: 112<n><n>#### 143<n><n>input: 42<n>Output: 42<n><n><n><n>## End
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where in a town would you put your shed? Choices:  A: next to the house B: keeping things in C: backyard D: farm yard E: ranch<n><n>### Response:		Keeping things in<n><n>### Input::What is 7 + 7?<n><n>### Rationales:<n>7 + 7 = 14<n><n>#### 14<n>Answer:<n><n>### Input<n>#### 502<n>#### 130251<n>#### 137455<n>#### 9185<n>#### B<n>#### Incorrect<n>

Choices:  A: united states B: atlas C: developed land D: park E: countryside<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### A<n>A: united states<n><n>Input: What is the rule if you double each number and add 1?<n>Rationales:: The rule is 2n+1 where: n=<<0>>0 to 31 and the output will be between 2n+1 (for example, 4 × 2 = 8) to 2n+1 in the range of 0 to 16.<n>First, you double a number in the sequence 0 - 31 and add 1. Thus, your output will be between 48 to 52.<n>#### 48<n>Answer: 48<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Input: Add the first two terms of the series 2, 2x, 2x2, 2x2x, … where x is the number one more than one-fourth of 10. For example, x = <<10-<<1/4 - 1>>1/4 -1 = 1.4999999… or 1.5.<n><n>#### 25<n>Answer: 25<n><n>### Instuctions:<n><n>Input: A carpenter measured a rectangular wooden board to see if it would fit between two studs in a wall. Each stud was 8 inches (20 centimeters) apart. The carpenter found that the board would exactly fit between the studs. In other words, he saw that the length of the board was 88⁄12 inches (18 3⁄4 c<n><n>Rationales:  Length of carpenters board = «8812″ or 18 1⁄2 inches or <<18.5″>>18½ inches<n>Width of the board = «12x31″ or 2 3⁄4 inches or «3 1⁄4″>>3 ¹⁄₄ inches<n><n>#### 394<n>Answer: 394<n><n># Mathematics (Grade 3)<n>The purpose of this problem is to analyze and solve a mathematical problem. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where in your entrance hall can you keep you head wear? Choices:  A: school B: large home C: house D: hat rack E: closet<n><n>### Response:		A: school<n><n>### Rationale:Entrance hall is a large room where you walk in the building to get into the building like the lobby the front of the building where you walk in or the door of your house that are outside of a home usually a house.<n><n>### <n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>#1:  Entrance hall of your home have space to keep your head warm<n><n>#2:  Your entrance hall is in your home<n><n>#3:  There is a place that place is a hat rack<n><n>```<n>#4:  The entrance hall of your home is where you put your coat on<n>```<n><n>### Ratiocination:<n><n>\[ 3 = 3\]<n><n>### 5+3 = 8 <n><n>### 2 + 2 = 4<n><n>```<n>2 × 2 = 4 <n>```<n><n>## 68 = 139+47-80<n>## 139+80+47=266<n>## 266 = 2+1+6+3+3+9+5+1 = 26<n><n>## 65+40+5 = 100<n>## 64=4<n>## 63 = 8<n>## 62 + 8 = 70<n>## 66 = 72-6<n><n>```<n>56 + 4 = 60<n>55 = 8<n>```<n><n>## D:<n>```<n>52+70+56=178<n>1-0+8 = 9<n>```<n><n>## A:<n>```<n>12 + 3 = 15<n>14 + 12 + 8 + 1 = 33<n>```

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where do most people keep their curling iron stored? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Danny was having fun singing in front of his class.   He has a lot of what? Choices:  A: laughter B: being happy C: glee D: opera E: injuries<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>import random<n>from math import *<n>import pickle<n>from datetime import *<n>input = pickle.load(open("question.pickle", newline=''))<n>answer = input[0]<n>answer<n>```<n>```<n>output:  A: laughs and being happy<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>\_\_\_\_\_\_\_<n><n>### Question:<n><n>* * *<n><n>### Input A:<n><n>1#What does it mean if a number is a prime number?<n><n>### Example:<n><n>* 8<n><n>* 15<n><n>### Input B:<n><n>1#Choose a number.<n><n>* 4<n>* 24<n>* 26<n>* 28<n><n>### Input C:<n><n>1#Answers will depend on the number you choose.<n><n>* 84<n>* 2^29<n>* 196003<n><n>* * * 2)Answers will depend<n>### * * *<n><n>##* * * * * * *<n><n><n>### Answer:<n><n>```python<n>import math<n>x = int(input("answer = "))<n><n>for nbr in range(0, 9, 2): # from 0 to 9 by 2<n>    if nbr%x == 0:<n>	#if you can tell if the division is a divisible by x<n>        print(f"{nbr} modulo {x} = {x} " )<n>        break<n>```<n>#### output:<n>```<n>answer = 4<n>1#What does a number divisible by x mean?<n><n>**4<n>15<n><n>**Answers will depend**<n><n>29*<n>3^<n>2^29<n><n>2^29** #*output of number divisible by x<n>```<n><n>## Acknowledgements:<n><n>### The problem was taken from<n>https://education.com/practice/5th-grade-math/problems/6837a15f-3a78-4c0f-96e7-af83b60acd07/<n><n>### The code was inspired by https

There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Changing society using a violent conflict is know as a what? Choices:  A: action B: demonstration C: understanding D: vote E: revolution<n><n>### Response:		Choice: B<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>### Instructions:If the statement is true, write T. If the statement is false, write F.<n><n>### If a person rides a bicycle, the person may use energy efficiently.<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>### Choose an answer, write it on the line, and then explain your reason.<n><n>### Input 1: An average person may need to walk ten blocks to get to school.<n><n>### Response 1: T<n><n>### Instuction 1:<n><n>### Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Demistration:<n><n>Input: When a baseball leaves the bat, the bat’s initial speed is 6.2 m/s. The acceleration of gravity is -9.8 m/s2. How long does it take for the ball to hit the ground if the ball leaves the bat?<n><n>### Rationale: Time = speed × 1/ acceleration.<n>1. Since speed = 6.2 m sec-1.<n>2. Then T =6.2 ×1/ 9.8 = <<=1/9.8=9 m>> sec.<n>#### 10<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: What are the solutions to 5 + 0.5 = x + 30?<n><n>Answer: Choice: A<n>Choices:<n>A: 5 + 0 5 = x + 20 B: 5 + 10/2 = x+5/2 C: 5+10 = x+30<n><n>### Input answer:<n><n>### Input response:<n>5 + x + 30<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>## Input:<n><n>## Response:<n><n>## Rationales:<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What do humans take in while breathing? Choices:  A: lungs and diaphram B: oxygen C: abdominal muscles D: air E: open throat<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input<n>What is 2 times 2? Choices: A: 2 B: 4 C: 3 D: 8<n><n>### Response<n>Choice A<n><n>### Input <n>What is 4 to the 3rd power? A. 6:00 AM B. 8:00 PM C. 4:24 PM D. 5:00 PM E. 5:26 PM<n><n>### Response : Choice E<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. If the first number is multiplied by 4 and the second number is subtracted by 1, the result is 43. If the third number is decreased by 1, the new number is 35. The third number is subtracted by the first number, The product of these numbers equals 5. Which number would replace the third number?<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The first number = <<<114>>114.<n>The second number = <<114-4>>114-4.<n>The third number = <<115>>115.<n><n>The first number x 4 = <<<115*4>>115x4 = 460.<n>114-4 = <<114+4>>114+4 = 112.<n>115 - 1 = <<115-1>>115-1 = 114<n>114 - 115 = 0.<n>5 = <<115*(115-114)>>115*114 = 5<n><n>#### 1356 <n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input 3/5<n>4/8<n>7/11<n>8/
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where does someone lay with their leg elevated when it's broken? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:He had an index card he had to return, so where did he put it after finding the book he needed? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where do I put my coffee mug after it's dry? How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:John is a human who is in a wheelchair due to an accident.  Where would he go to get to the third floor of his apartment building? Choices:  A: space shuttle B: detroit C: stairs D: downtown E: elevator<n><n>### Response:		<n>If John could stand and was not in a wheelchair, he could take the stairs to the the third floor of his building.<n><n>### Explain your answer:<n><n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>1. Answer the following multiple choice question by picking the correct answer.<n>2. Demonstrate for John that he cannot use the elevator if he is in a wheelch.<n><n>### 1. Demonstration:John cannot ride the elevator if  he is in a wheel chair because the wheel chair does not go to the third floor. If John  was not in a wheel chair he could go in the elevator  to the third floor.<n><n>### Answer the following multiple choice questions about the demonstration.<n><n>### #1 Question:How many blocks travelled to the post office to Houston?<n>### #2 Question:How many blocks traveled home from the Houston stop?<n><n>### # 3 Question:How many blocks were in total?<n><n>### 4. Answer the following multiple-choice questions if you  want to make your answer 100.<n><n>Input: The train ride to Denver takes 3 days while the road trip takes half as long. The trip by road requires one tenth of the trip to Denver but only travels half as  far. The bus trip  takes one quarter of the time of the train trip but goes to a different destination. Which trip would be faster if the rush hour traffic on the road was cleared? A: Train B: Bus C: Road Trip  D: Don’t change<n><n>Demonstration: A, B, and C are examples of different trains. A and B is a route to Denver that are very close to each other.  C is a different route to Denver that is distant from the B  and A train. All of the trips have different rates of speed and time needed (and are only slightly different).<n><n>Answer: In this example, it is clear that the bus would be the fastest.<n><n>### A: The trip that travels half what it takes to Denver.<n><n>### B: A different route on the train.<n><n>### C: The route that gets to Denver in the same amount of time as A.<n><n>### D: No change to the trip<n><n>###
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:One might find theirs open, with the letters that had been delivered stolen. Choices:  A: front door B: newspaper C: post office D: package E: mail box<n><n>### Response:		Choices:  A B C D E<n><n>A B C D E<n>####  A B<n>Answer: A-B<n><n><n>Input: Choose any of the following and determine which of the choices will be the odd one out.<n>Answer and Rationales: Choices are <<<b.t._d.c.r.>>><n>b.t. is <<<<b.t.>>>>, and it stands for <<<<bt>>>>.<n>d.c.r, then, is <<<d.c.r>>>.<n>b and r are the odd ones because the others all have periods after them.<n>####  b.t.<n>Answer: b.t.<n><n>Input: Each time one subtracts from 908, one obtains either a positive or negative number that is 50 smaller. How old is one?<n><n>Answer: The answer to the challenge will be the sum of 14 or an odd number (depends on how you solve the question)<n><n>A) The number 908 is subtracted by another number and the answer will be 908-x=908=50.<n>We do not want to add 14 or any odd number because this might go more difficult later on. So x=50 will be the right answer to the given solution<n><n>B) 908-50=858<n>858 is subtracted again the answer 858-14=844<n><n>Now in 14 we want to use an odd number of 13 or 15, however 15-13 = 19  but 844-19= 825, which is an even number. So 19 is the answer.<n><n>C) the answer to 844 is 825 we add 19 and 825 +19= 844=<n>This process repeats again, the answer to 825 is 806, but 844 - 19= 806 +19= 0825<n>This can now be called a series because the first few integers in this series are 14 we could not use 19, so the number after 14 is 23 which is even, so no possible
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where are a lot of offices in New York? Choices:  A: school building B: skyscraper C: business D: grocery store. E: work<n><n>### Response:		<n>> A  <n>### Rationale:<n>### A: school building <n><n>### B: skyscraber <n><n>### C: business <n><n>### D: grocery <n><n>### E: work<n><n>#### 0<n>Answer: E

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where can you store a small notepad on your person? Choices:  A: back pocket B: meeting C: drug store D: home E: school<n><n>### Response:		Answer Choice A, B or C.<n><n>#### Choice A <n>Rationale: Janette has a small notepad. She can put her notepad on her person in her back pocket.<n><n>#### Choices B and C  <n>Rationale: Tiffany also has a small notepads. This notepad has two different colours. She can put that notepad on her dress and also has a large backpack that she can put it in.<n><n>#### Chocies D and E  <n>Rationales: Mariah has one large notepads that can fit up to 100 pages. She can put it in its own box, and she does have a drawer that she can put in her home, but it is not convenient to take it out every day to take notes.<n><n>#### Chooses B and D<n>Rationale: Tina has a 1 small notepad and she can store it in her meeting. As she goes to a meeting, and wants to take notes, it would be quite convenient as she could just take it out from her desk.<n><n><n><n>### Input<n><n>Demonstration with Rationales:<n><n>- Anastasia weighs 114 pounds. She takes 50 pounds off for baking.<n>- In this example, the number 114 represents the number of pounds that <n>- Anastasia initially weighs. If she takes 50 pounds (the subtraction) off,<n>- it means that the resulting weight must be 114 – 50 = <<114-50=64>>64.<n>- The final result is the subtraction expression with the right variable and <n>- variable values, in this case, <<50=50>>5=50 (in this case, 5=5 pounds).<n><n><n><n><n>## Input 2<n><n>Demonstrations and Rationales: <n>- In this example:<n>- The 5 represents the variable.<n>- Its value, in this case 2, is called the subtrahend.<n>- Its value is the second subtraction expression.<n>- As such, if the subtraction expression's left variable equals  x, the term 5/x is divided by it. <n><n>> x/x = 1/1
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Reading a newspaper gives you a what about local current events? I reckon I'll get bored'm.<n><n><n>### Input:\<n>The square in the picture has a side of 2 units. The length of its diagonal is 8 times the width. If the area of the square is 400, what is the perimeter of the square?<n>#### 92<n>Answer: 92<n><n>### Response:\<n>The area is 400. The side of the square is 2. It's also 2^2 = <<2^2=4>>2 cm.<n>The diagonal is 8 x 2 = <<8*2=16>>cm, so it makes the perimeter 4 [4 cm] = <<4*4=16>>cm.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:After attending school for twelve years what do you do? Choices:  A: inspiration B: much work C: boredom D: graduate E: degree<n><n>### Response:		<n>### <n>The answer must be either boredom or graduation in which "graduation" is the last answer.<n><n>###<n>### Input:How many more 2s are in 221 than are in 121?<n><n>### Response<n>### Either 2 more of them or else nothing. The correct answer is 2.<n><n>

The first seat which has a capacity of 50 is full. He moves to the 2nd table which has a capacity of only 40. He sits there only for 4 people. All remaining places contain only 6 people. Only the last remaining place has a capacity of 20 people.<n><n>Explain : “The person sits at the last place with ten less people than the capacity. So what is the remaining capacity of that table”<n><n>Rationale: The empty seat in the table contains 20 – 10 = <<20-10=10>>10.<n><n>The second table’s capacity is 40 – 10 + 10 = “20-10+10=“<<20-10-−10=20>>20.<n>And the person sits at the 3rd empty seat in the table with only few people left.<n><n>### Response<n>So the remaining capacity of the table is <<20-1<<20-110>>10-10.<n><n>#### 20-1<n>Answer:20-1<n><n>### Inputs and Rationale for part 2<n>Suppose there is 500 dollars in a school and many people take loans on there which are 250 dollars, 300 dollars and 50 dollars respectively. Now the remaining money equals to only 0,1 and 0,25.<n>Explain: “The remainder in all the loans are 1 as their difference is 250 dollars”.<n>Rationale<n><n>The remaining money in the 250 dollars is 250-1 = <<250-250=0>>25

What percent of the students are girls?<n><n>### Response (Expected):<n>Answers may only contain numbers. You may omit the "percent (%) sign" from any answer.<n><n>36 ÷ 1 / 1 = %girls<n><n>### Rationales:<n>If there are boys and girls in the camp, and the total number of students is 36:<n><girls>:12, 30 + 12 = 42 <males><n><n>So: 42 / 36 = 1.222222 -> 12% of the campers are males.<n><n>40:  32,  7 + 32 = 39 <boys><n><n>So:   32 / 36 (The number of boys ÷ total number) = 0.944444 -> 94% of the campers is females.<n><n><n><pre id="1c5987"><n><div class="tab">   <n>  <nav class="tabNav"><n>    <select onchange="tabs(this.value);" class="tab" id="navLinks"><n>    <option >Basketball</option><n>  <option id=\"navOp1\" value=\"Basketball\">1. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where do people traditionally get information about the world? There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where does a shadow usually appear? Choices:  A: suface of moon B: building C: bridge D: ground E: bright light<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Rationale:<n>#### <n>The moon casts a shadow on earth. The word surface can be replaced with shadow. Therefore, the shadow usually appears on the surface of the moon.<n><n><n>### Inputs:A baseball game was called in the second inning when it rained. The following day, the result of the game was officially recorded as a tie. The score at the end of the first inning was Hens 7, Tigers 2. If the score at the end of each inning was recorded in the following way, what was the final score at the end of nine full innings?<n><n>####<n>Let a =<n>Hens(1)<n>=4<n>Tigers(1)<n>=0<n>Hens(2)<n>=7<n>Tigers(2)<n>=2<n>Hens(3)<n>=7<n><n>####<n>Tigers(3)<n>=2<n>=Hens(3)+Tigers(3)=9<n>Let b<n>=<n>Hens(9)<n>=7<n>=Hens(1)+Hens(2)+...+Hens(9) <n>=Hens(9)+Tigers(2)+Tigers(9...=8<n>=Hens(4)+Hens(5)+Hens(6)+Hens(7)+Hens(8)+<n>=7<n>Totals<n>=7+7=14<n><n>####<n>Since an extra inning was added to the game because of bad weather, the score of the last inning was recorded as 9 innings.<n><n>If the score at the end(=Hens(9) at the last inning was 7)   and the score at end of the second inning(in game = Tigers(2) and Hens(2) before weather intervention) was 7 + 2 = 9.<n><n><n>Therefore, the final score was 7 + 9  + + 7 = 14<n><n>#### 14<n>Answer: 14<n><n>### Input<n>Write a rule with at least three operations that uses the following variables:<n><n>| Variable Name | Symbol |<n>| ----------- | ----------- |<n>| a | x |<n>| b | y |<n>| c | z |<n><n>### Response<n><n>####

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:George ruined the surprise.  How did he do so? Choices:  A: hiding B: accidentally C: expectation D: knowingly E: planned<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>I believe George was being malicious knowing that they would be upset.<n><n>### Input George's response is "I wasn't trying to ruin your friend's surprise.  I was only doing it to protect her. She was too young to have her secret shared in a large group setting and I felt she needed protection." How did George respond?<n>#### E<n>Answer: E<n><n>### Input Janie was upset with her teacher, Ms. A, for being mean to her.  How did Ms. A respond? Choices:   A: explained why she was mean B: said sorry C: offered an apology D: said she did not know what Janie was talking about<n><n>### Response<n><n>It seemed as though her teacher was having her own internal battle. I believe her actions were born out of confusion.<n><n>### Response Ms. A's response is "That was wrong of me.  I was trying to help you, but I apologize for the things I said in class." How did Ms.  respond?<n>B<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Input A group of five people had different preferences.  Annie and Bob like sushi, while Bob and David like Italian food.  Bill and Carol prefer Indian food, and they also hate sushi. Of the five people, what was the one food that ALL like?<n><n>#### C: Indian food.<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Input Samantha said to Bob, "I thought you would like this movie. It has lots of action. " How did Bob respond?<n>#### F: Indicating he is interested.<n>Answer: F<n><n>### Input Sara asked John, "What did you buy?" His response was "I bought a new game."  How did John respond?<n>#### A. John responded by giving the game's name.<n>Answer: A<n><n>### The class was assigned to write a paper.  After receiving the first draft, the teacher said she would check over the draft for grammatical errors and then give it back to the class. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where do fish spend the majority of their time? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:She a deep love for all her friends, every Friday she had an open invitation for them as she loved to host and what? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:If electrical equipment won't power on, what connection should be checked? Choices:  A: company B: telephone netwok C: airport D: wires E: freeway<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>##### Explanation:<n>If something electrical won't power on the circuit breaker (A) is most likely the issue (unless it's a specific battery-powered device, of course). Aside from the breaker, if someone is traveling and their device isn't working, they're most likely going to check the network connection with their service provider. If someone is traveling and wants to access the network, the network wouldn't be checked for accessibility until they are done with their traveling in their hotel room.<n><n>Additionally, the wires are going to connect to the airport, but the "airport" would be the hub or terminal for the particular airport, which doesn't directly correspond to an entire "airport" as it's being checked. <n><n>**NOTE:** This question was very tricky as it doesn't mention "wires" directly on the "network system" or "network connection."<n><n><n>##### <n>Answer: A

There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:How might compassionate thoughful be described as being? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Choices:  A: make friends B: mingle C: meet people D: small talk E: meet new people<n><n>### Response:		The correct response is (D). small talk<n><n>A: make friends<n>The wrong response to this question is (A). This answer indicates that socializing involves making friends with someone, while socializing can involve small talk and making new friends.<n><n>B: mingle<n>The wrong response to the question is (B). Even though mingling can also involve making friends, meeting new people, and making acquaintances, this answer is incorrect because mingling is usually defined as the behavior of looting and robbing in the evening, after the day's work is done.<n><n>C: meet people<n>Corresponding to (C), this answer is not suitable for the question because socializing is usually thought to be part of human behavior.<n><n>E: meet new people<n>The correct answer to this question is (E). meeting new people is correct because socializing is often regarded as a way to meet new people (or acquaintances), whereas meeting new people is the same as meeting new people.<n><n>### Input If x + y = 7 and z + x = 10, then what is y when x = 2?<n><n>Choice: y = 4<n><n>Correct Answer:y = 3<n><n>#### Rationale:<n>When x = 2, y + x = 7 +2 = 9, then z = 9.<n><n>Z + y - y +x = 9+4-4+2<n>1) z - y = 9- (4-2) = 9 -5=4<n><n>2) y + z + x = y+9- z-4+2<n>5) z = y+9-y-4+2<n><n>3) z=10 - 9+-2+2+2<n><n>4) z = 1 + 2 = 3<n><n>5) y = 9<n>If x=2 then y = (9-4)<n><n>The answer is (B).y = 3.<n><n>### Tests<n><n>### Instructions:<n>This is a test question and response box similar to an actual test question and response form.<n>#### 1)<n>(x + y) × (x – y) = x² – y²<n><n>#### 2)<n>A: y = 6<n>B: y = 8<n><n>#### 3)<n>

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:The shark was migrating between continents, where did biologists find it? Choices:  A: fresh water B: gulf of mexico C: open ocean D: television program E: coral reef<n><n>### Response:		<n>The shark was migrated to Gulf Of Mexico from Coral Reef. There is 15% chances of shark to migrate to gulf of Mexico. I choose B as the answer.<n><n>### Input<n>The turtle was migrating between continets, where did biologis find it? Choices :  C : fresh water D: gulf of meexico E: ocean F: television program G : coral reef<n>#### Input:<n>The shark migrate to Continent of gulf of meexic, the chances is 10%<n>The turtle migrate to continet of coral reef, the chances is also 10%<n>#### Reponse:<n>There are 20% of chances of finding the turtle and 15% chanses of finding shark.The shark has more chance of beinge found. So, I choose option G as the answer.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What does one chop us a grape for?
