airplane.<n>While airplanes are fast, they are expensive.<n>Therefore, shipping companies transport many smaller packages by airplane than the boat.<n><n>#### Answer: A<n><n>### Demands and Supply:<n>#### Demand:<n>Input: What is price elasticity of supply?<n><n>Output: The percent change in the quantity supplied of a product is called price elasticity of demand. <n><n>#### Supply:<n>Input: How does a tax increase affect supply?<n><n>Output A: At a high price, the supply is low because there is less supply at a high price<n>Output B: At a low price, the supply is high because there is more supply at low prices<n>Output C: A tax increase has a negative effect on supply<n><n>#### Answer: C<n><n>![](tax.png)<n><n>A tax increase decreases supply, resulting in less goods bought, sold, and supplied to consumers.<n><n>#### Demand:A higher price decreases demand.<n>```Math<n><n>If a good's demand is inelastic, a large change in price leads to a large change in quantity  <n>    demanded.<n>---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------<n>    If a good's demand increases, quantity demanded increases, and price increases.<n><n>If a good has an elastic demand, a large price change will result in a relatively small response in <n>    quantity demanded.<n>                       Quantity   Price<n>                       Demanded =   1.5<n><n>If a good’s demand is inelastically, a price hike will result in a large drop in demand,<n>           which will result in a reduction in the sale of goods.<n><n><n>Price elasticity of demand has low levels of elasticity, such as during inflation.<n>Price inelasticity of demand means that a large change in prices would indicate a substantial change in buying behavior.<n>                       Quantit   Price<n>                       of    Demanded =   0.5<n><n>-------------------------------------------------------------------------------<n>If the price falls by 8%, the quantity demanded would increase by 80%. <n>		<n>```<n>#### Prices<n>Output A: Price at equilibrium is determined by the two markets.<n>Output

Choices:  A: meet people B: meet friend C: make people laugh D: socialize E: liquor<n><n>### Response:		<n>Rationales: Meeting people will relieve the person from loneliness.<n><n>### Input:"There are at least two ways to get to our school. But if you take the road along the river instead of the road along the creek, the road along the river will always be two miles shorter." The statement is true if and only if<n><n>### A: you can only do one or the other<n><n>### B: your choice of the longer road is your choice<n><n>### C: they say that if you take the long way around, it will always save you at least two miles<n><n>### D: they are two roads going along the river<n><n>### E: you can do both in the same trip<n><n>### Response:"There are at least \textbf{two} ways to get to our \textbf{school}." The statement is true if there \textbf{are at least two} ways to get there. <n><n>We \textbf{take the road along the river} if it is shorter, so it is not necessary that we \textbf{take the long way}.<n><n>### A<n><n>### B<n><n>We still have at least two ways, and therefore, the sentence is correct.<n><n>### C<n><n>The sentence means "if you have the freedom to choose one or the other, you should not take the longer road."<n><n>### D<n><n>The roads are both "along the river" and the longer road is shorter. We can still answer "true" without getting rid of this choice.<n><n>### E<n><n>We \textbf{"can do both in the same \textbf{trip}"}, i.e., we can use both roads to go there as there are at least two: one \textbf{"along the river","along the river".}<n><n>### Input<n>The following sentences can be rephrased as  If only \textbf{choice} A is true, then \textbf{condition} follows; and otherwise \textbf{choice} B follows.<n><n>### The following contains errors.<n>> \textit{John was supposed to help his mother. He was busy writing code to work long hours. After a long day of coding, John is tired to death.}<n><n>### How many errors do you think appear in the passage?<n>#### 3<n><n>### The passage is:<n>> John was
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where might someone find old clothing? Choices:  A: trunk B: drawer C: suitcase D: book shelf E: washing machine<n><n>### Response:		If it’s old clothing it might be found in the drawer of your bedside table.<n><n>### Input<n>Where might someone find old and unwanted clothing? Choices A: trunk  <n>B: drawer  <n>C: suitcase  <n>D: book shelf  <n>E: washing machine<n>#### E<n>Answer: E<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Sarah and Sam were assigned to two different classes and study groups. Therefore, BC+CD=AC-B and AC-B=CD-A, A=BC+CD and B=CD-A.<n><n>### Answer:<n>A=4<br><n>BC+CD=4<br> <br><n>BC=CD-A <br><n>B=CD-A. <br><n><n>### Justifications:<n>To make the answer we can just replace the C with BC, AB in BC and CD in AD as shown in the picture.<n>Then we can apply the basic math formula to do subtraction.<n>The first equation is C=AB+BC and the second equation is C=CD+DC. Finally, you will get AC=CD as your answer<n><n>#### <n>### Instructions:Write a response that appropriately answers an open-ended question based on the diagram below.<n><n>### Subject:<n>In the shape drawn below, line segment AB is one-third as long as AB-CD. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What is KFC who serves chicken? Choices:  A: fast food restaurant B: plate C: bowl D: freezer E: oven<n><n>### Response:		Input:Janet has 9 cards and Brenda has 14. Input: In a classroom there are blue chairs and green chairs. In a classroom there is at least one more green chair than the total of blue and green chai Input: Pete walked 6 blocks to the supermarket, bought 5 items, and walked 3 blocks home A: In a classroom are blue chairs.B: Pete bought 5 items at the supermarket. C: Janet has 4 cards. D: Janet has 17 cards. E: Pete came home 9 blocks.<n><n>#### 6<n>Answer: fast food restaurant<n><n>#### 12<n>Answer: Janet has 5 cards.<n><n>#### 18<n>Answer: Pete went 6 + 3 + 6 = <<6+3+6=15>>15 blocks in all.<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. Will you come with me?"<n><n>Brenda doesn't know if Pete is rich or if he's poor. All she knows is her friend keeps good company. She will definitely be happy if Pete answers "yes," but she doesn't want to risk being turned down.<n><n>Brenda asks Mara, a rather rude and aggressive person, "How do you feel about going to this high-class place at high prices, Mara?" How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:The keys were black and white, what were they attached to? Choices:  A: get tired B: have legs C: skip D: not fat E: look first<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>(A: get tired)<n><n>### Solution:<n>E is the correct choice.<n><n>**A) Get Tired**<n><n>As you run, you exert energy. The more energy you exert, the faster your heart beats and the more tired you'll be.<n><n>**B) Have Legs**<n><n>It does not matter if you are chasing a boring old ball or chasing a really fast and dangerous ball, your legs will always be the same, either two strong legs to carry you or two weak legs that will not work properly.<n><n>**C) Skip**<n>In the first place, skipping is a way on how you can lose some weight or at least control your weight with a healthy way.<n><n>**D) Not Fat**<n>In general, we know that obese children are at a higher health risk from chronic disease in adulthood, such as heart disease, cancer and diabetes, than their normal weight peers.<n><n>**E) Look First**<n><n>There are countless numbers of diseases, ranging from diabetes and heart disease to paranoia and depression. It could be anything – for example, if you spend hours looking at the ceiling of one’s room, you might find out that there are some bugs above the ceiling of your room. You need to get up, open the window, and see what's actually up there - and there are many other diseases that are going to come your way soon, but if you're not ready for it, you will be.<n><n>### Input - If you play baseball - Do you throw a baseball or bat it with a bat? All you have to do is take the pitch and throw it to the catcher. Sometimes you throw the ball down to second base or the first base. You can either use your

Choices:  A: candy store B: butcher shop C: kitchen D: auto repair shop E: post office<n><n>### Response:		<n>If you have bought something from this place more than once, put D. Otherwise, put A. A: B: C:<n>This is where I buy my birthday treats to feed to the dog.<n>D:<n>My husband buys birthday treats for the dog here. A:<n>I can buy lots of dog treats here.<n>This is where I get a small container of treats so the dog won't get too fat.<n>### Choice:<n>Input: On January 1st, there were 13 cats in a family. On January 1st there were 2 cats more each month. When did they have 14 cats?<n>Rationales:{<n>The number of cats in the house changed by 2 since Jan 1st.<n>If there were already 13 cats, then the house had 13 + 2 = <<13+2=15>>15 cats for the last month in the family,<n>and it had 13 + (2-1) = <<13+(2-1) =10>>10 cats for the previous month because it had 2 cats more.<n>Therefore, it had 15 - 10 = <<15-10=5>>5cats more since Jan 1st.<n>When did it have 14 crows. Since Feb 1st, it had 5 more<n>crows. Therefore, it had 14 crows on Feb 1st.<n>}<n><n>### Input:-74:54<n><n>### Response:-20<n><n>### Rationale:<n>#### <n>Answer: 20<n><n>####<n><n>```js<n>// input:<n>// -1.034:34<n>// -1.251:25<n>// 13.75:34<n>// output:<n>// -20<n>```<n><n>```js<n>const add = (a, b) => ((a += b), a);<n><n>const minus = (a, b = -1) => ((a -= b), a);<n>```<n><n>### Input/-1.251e-34:34-10.79:34<n><n>### Rational:<n>#### 6.500000
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where could you find a laundry room that is only used by staff? Choices:  A: house B: hotel C: green house D: college E: dorm<n><n>### Response:		<n>  You would find a laundry in a dorm so you will not use a laundry in college or dorm. You can wash clean clothes and launder them when you have a place and wash. You can use a laundry when you have a job or a job in college. I chose a college rather than choosing a green house because I got a green laundry here in college. The people in a green house can be laundry or not because they are using green color. When there are no people in a green house a person can go to the green house to watch a green house. In a dorm, you can't take green clean laundry.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>To begin with, a college has a green house but a college is not a green house because of its green dorms.<n>The house in college is not a greenhouse. There may not be green clothes in a green house because it is a house and not a green one. The house is a green one because it belongs to a green one. Therefore, the house is green and the people who are in it are not green because the house is green.<n><n>The people who are in college do not live in a house. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:The artist didn't use many colors to capture the view, he was famous for his very plain what? Choices:  A: landscape B: east side C: countryside D: middle america E: georgia<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>| Answer      | Points |<n>|-------------|--------|<n>| A B or C B E    | 5     |<n>| D            | 10    |<n>| E            | 5     |

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where would you hear a viola along side many other string and brass instruments? Choices:  A: symphony B: band C: create music D: orchestra E: string quartet<n><n>### Response:		A
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What has highly criticized security? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:A person is putting on makeup, what is their likely goal? Enter answer as a number."<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>We are given that<n>```<n>2 <= 5 <= 7 < 11 < 13 <= 17 <= 19 <= 2<n>```<n>So for the first set<n>```<n>2 <=3 <=4 < 5 < 7 < 13 < 17 < 19 <= 11 <=2<n><n>Therefore, the sum of a, b, and c is given by<n>```<n>a +b = 1+2 = 3<n><n>a -b = 3 - 2 = 1<n><n>And c = 4 - 3 = 1<n><n>a - b = 3 - 3=0<n><n>b - c = 3 - 4 =-1<n><n>c - d = 4 - 4 = 0<n>d - b = 7 - 4 = 3<n>```<n>The minimum for the values of a, b, c, d must be zero, where `m` is defined by<n>```<n>min{a, b, c,d} = m<n><n>Solving for<n>```<n>b = d = 4 -m -m=6<n>```<n>And<n>```<n>b = c = m+m= 4m = 5<n>```<n>We can set 2 equal to c, and set c equal to d, leading to 2=d and c = 6-m<n>```<n>3 = c+b+c<n>6 = 3m<n>m = 4<n>```<n>The minimum possible numbers for `m, b and c would be 4, 5 and 6<n>```<n>a= -1<n>b = m+m = 4m  = 4*4 =16<n>c= m= 4<n>d= d-m = 6 - 4<n>```<n>Therefore, the set `{2, 5,7, 11

There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where is a horse likely to live? Choices:  A: michigan B: stable C: race track D: farm yard E: arizona<n><n>### Response:		<n>D: farm yard<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Your best friend calls you to invite you to a party. You would like to go, but you can t figure out how to get there. Describe how to get to the party using at least two different methods.<n><n>### Example:<n>Get to party #1: Go to a mall. Walk to J. C. Penny store. Enter store. Take left into Ladies World department. Go up escalator. Exit onto second floor. Go to 10th door and knock.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Get to party method #1: Go to mall.<n>Get to party method#2: Walk to J. C Penny. Enter the store. Take left into the Ladies World department.<n>Get to party Method #3: Go up escalator<n>Get to party Method#4: Exit the store onto the second floor.<n>Get to partyMethod #5: Go to the 10th door. Knock.<n><n>**NOTE: If your instructor asks you to create a set of methods, you can use<n>the methods described here to help you. They are in order from easiest<n>to most difficult. You can use one of the previous methods as a template<n>for your own method.**<n><n>#### Party Location<n><n>#### Rationales<n><n>#### Instructions:<n>In the table above, the directions for getting to a party are described.<n>Using table logic, develop an equation that represents the method for<n>getting to the party.<n><n>### Solution<n><n>`<n><n>![solution](images/solution.png)<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### Expected Answer:<n>[23 -17 + 8 x 25 + 7 ] - 1 = 7<n><n>#### Expected Answer:<n>Because there are 23 - 17 + 8 steps in the directions - 1 step from the beginning for leaving your house.<n><n><n>### Solution:<n>To find the number of steps, follow the steps below:<n><n>+ -1 step from the beginning (from leave the house)<n>+ 23 - 7 steps (getting to the mall)<n>+ 4 steps in method#1 for the mall<n>+ 3 times the 4 steps in method #1 at the mall<n>+
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:James kept a clipboard where he could easily find  it.  Where might he keep it? Choices:  A: shelf B: place of work C: desk D: office supply store E: school<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### A) Place of work<n><n>#### B) Place of work<n>

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Why shouldn't you walk barefooted after the rain? Choices:  A: shoes B: wet ground C: wet clothes D: start to fall E: water garden<n><n>### Response:		<n>A. You can't see what's on the ground as you're walking and you could get a sharp rock stuck in your foot.<n><n>### Input (Same):Which of the next should you not leave outdoors. Choices:  E: a bicycle. B: a water garden, C: D:<n><n>### Response(Same):<n>C. Water garden should not be left outdoors.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:The doctor recommended washing hands, what was being promoted? He writes a short paragraph, with a sentence of analysis: __A__: He has a strong point (“This type of analysis and its subsequent conclusion is the basis for logic, and is necessary in all sciences and in the study and analysis of literature.”). However, the student does not support his claim with adequate evidence (“This is because literature allows one to analyze a work from many perspectives, such as psychological, social, and philosophical. Literature is a study of human existence, and one cannot understand human existence without studying human literature.”). What should the student do next in his response? __A__: Show how he has developed his strong point by giving examples __B__: Explain how literature allows one to understand human existence __C__: Show how literature teaches one to use logic to analyze a work __D__: Use a different type of reasoning (conceptual diagram, Venn diagram, etc.) to support his conclusion __E__: Conclude that his argument is irrefutable<n><n>### **Response:**<n>D) Conceptual diagrams are a perfect way to explain one's argument and how it logically proceeds.<n>

In this example, the condition is that the variable is a number.<n><n>### If the name is a number do this...<n>#### The body of the condition should be in a code block.<n>If name = <<name=.int>>int(name) <n>	print("The value of 'name' is a number")<n><n><n>#### Else, don't do this...<n>else: <n>	print("It isn't a number")<n><n>### Demination<n>##### Write a response:<n>**It is a variable name.**<n><n>###### The code does not print what the variable name is.<n><n>###### Here is a code block.<n>```<n>if name = name<n>```<n><n>###### This is incorrect code.<n><n>##### Write code in a code block. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where was the apple tree said to contain something forbidden? Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Dan said that getting in line was the best choice because it would lead to what? Choices:  A: being ordered B: less confusion C: boredom D: standing in line E: have to wait for<n><n>### Response:		C<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:When having food at a formal place, what do you usually do? How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Who designs a building? Choices:  A: builders B: driver C: architect D: fall down E: tradesmen<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Question:<n><n>#### 67

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Before getting a divorce, what did the wife feel who was doing all the work? Choices:  A: harder B: anguish C: bitterness D: tears E: sadness<n><n>### Response:		B<n>### Rationale: After getting a divorce what is the feeling of the wife?<n>#### A: harder<n>#### B: anguish<n>#### C: bitterness<n>#### D: tears<n>#### E: sadness<n>####  B<n>Answer: B<n>### Input: The 6 students in Ms. Cuthbert's math class have just taken a test. Five of the students passed the test, but one did not. How many of the students passed the math class test?<n><n>### Response B:<n><n>### Rationale::The sum of what the students passed were 5+1=6.<n><n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Choose the answer that best completes the sentence using the words in parentheses.<n>How many points does the team need to win the _______ (football game)? The team has 47 points so far, plus 9 points more than the competitor's.<n>A  _______ (team)<n>B  _______ (points)<n>C  _______ (scored)<n>D  _______ (wins)<n>E  _______ (game)<n><n>### Rationales::The points scored by a team are 47+9=56.The team has 56 points so far, therefore, the required point to overcome the opponent is (9+66=75) and it is shown below:<n><n>#### 75<n>Answer: 75<n><n>You worked on two projects in the _______ (classroom).You need to bring 4 boxes of _______ (paper) and another _______ (tool) from the _______ (shed) to finish them.<n><n>### Rationales::The given words are: 4 boxes of paper, 2 pairs of scissors and 2 glue sticks.<n><n>#### 4 boxes of paper<n>#### 2 pairs of scisors.<n>#### 2 glue stixs.<n>#### Classroom<n>#### shed<n>#### 7<n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Note to Teacher<n><n>*You can give an instruction or explanation of the above task to the learner.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Bill is stuck in marsh when a man comes up to him peaking Cajun, where is he? Choices:  A: low lands B: new york C: forest D: louisiana E: everglades<n><n>### Response:		E: Everglades<n><n><n>A: Low lands<n>B: New York<n>C: Forest<n>D: Louisiana<n>E: Everglades<n><br><n>Demonstration: The man asks Bill how far inland he had waded before finding him. If Bill had waded 4 miles inland, he would have to travel 4 more miles in the same direction. So his return trip would be 4 +4 = <<4+4=8>>8 miles. (4 + 4 = 8.)<n>Bill would have to travel 8 miles in a 45 degree change in direction to get back to where  he started. So he would have a total of 48 miles (45° + 35° = 80°, 80° = 48°).<n>If Bill was in marshes of the Everglades, he might reasonably be in Florida.<n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question by matching the proper letter to each numbered answer choice.<n><n>##### 1. When using each number I need to use the week's index number to separate the week from the day.<n><n>| day | week 01 | week 02 | week 03 |<n>- |:-:|:-:|:-:<n> 1 | 21  | 22  | 23<n> 2 | 24  | 25  |<n> 3 | 26  | 27  | 28<n> 4 | 29  | 30  |<n> 5 | 31  | 32  | 33<n> 6 | 34  | 35  |<n> 7 | 36  | 37  | 38<n> 8 | 39  | 40  |<n> 9 | 41  | 42  | 43<n> 10 | 44  | 45  |<n> 11 | 46  | 47  | 48<n> 12 | 49  | 50  |<n><n>Then, I can put each day into the correct time for that week. For example, since day 8 is in week 2, then day 8's index number will be 2.<n><n>Now, I need to do this for each individual day which I want to use. After which I need to make sense of the data.<n><n>So, I'll put each day in order by days, weeks and then index numbers.<n><n>I'll start with week 01 so it will be 1-7.<n><n>Index 1: day 1 (21) - Day 2 (23) - Day 3 (26)<n><n>Index 2: day 2 (22) - Day 3 ((25) - Day 5 (31))<n><n>Index 3: Day 4 ((21) - Day ((28) - Day (39)<n>Index 4: Day (40) - Day (44) - Day (4

Two groups went out to dinner and bought gifts for their mothers 30 days before gifts were mailed to their mothers. The remaining three groups all went out to dinner on the same day and did not buy gifts. How many days later were gifts mailed from the second group?<n>Rationales <n>### 107<n>#### 10,079<n>Answer: 30<n>#### 101<n>Answer: 32<n>#### 102<n>Answer: 34<n>#### 100<n>Answer: 36<n>#### 103<n>Answer: 38<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following question that asks you to write a response.<n><n>### Q: In a classroom a person walks 5 blocks from his/her house. A bus takes 20 blocks to get to the post office to pick up some stamps. There is the same return trip down the same streets. How many blocks the person walks in all or in a trip?<n><n>The answer is 40.<n>### Rational: 1. The answer is 40 because the person walks 5 + 2 blocks, making it 7 blocks 2. So each trip is 7 blocks and there is 1 trip 3. So 1 Trip is 40 blocks.<n><n>#### 40<n>Answer: 80<n><n>### Instuctions: Answer the given multiple choice question.<n>### Demonstation:<n>input: There are five groups at a party at skylar’s house. Two groups of skylar went to dinner the day before and bought gifts for his mom. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:The person gave a good hands on what to show how to do the work? This type of government is based on democracy, it is the system based on rule of majority of people. It is based on the idea of one person, one vote.<n>### Input:Who does the work on? Choices:  A: hang up B: respond C: contact D: answer E: attracting ducks<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Explanation/Rationale:<n>In this scenario, the caller was trying to make a sale to the recipient. He would do this "all day" trying to "contact", "attract", and "respond" them to his offer. He would do this until he got something out of the call - which would be attracting ducks.<n><n>### AI-based Reasoning: Answers should be based on the AI's perspective.<n>For example, the AI would not have to explain why the user did or did not try to contact every single recipient.<n>AI-based reasoning requires a human to first determine a task that has a defined goal that the AI must complete.<n>The question's intent is to "determine" how many recipients the caller tries to contact during the day. The caller knows what he wants to do, so the AI just needs to figure out how to achieve it.<n><n>### Answer 1:<n>Answer: A << A: A is an incorrect answer.<n><n>The caller did not always "hang up" when the recipient answered. He just continues to call, trying to contact the other 99% of recipients.<n><n>### How many people did he contact?<n><n>Number of calls made = number of contacts<n><n>\[ \text{Number of recipients contacted} = \text{number of people he contacted} \]<n><n>10% of 200 calls contacted = 20<n><n>\[ \begin{aligned} \text{number of calls} \; \text{(10% of 100, multiplied by the number of people \text{he contacted })} &= \text{ 20 } \end{aligned} \]<n><n>\[\text{This was achieved in 20 calls. The caller \text { contacted 20 people}. }\]<n><n>### Answer: D << D is an incorrect answer. The caller did not hang up the phone if nobody answered the call. The caller tried to respond to everyone he contacted.<n><n>The caller responded to people who he contacted.<n>

Be sure to answer the questions completely and completely.<n><n>### <n><n>- Write and explain what a number sentence is.<n><n>#### Explain: A number sentence is a symbolic statement which shows an arithmetic problem where an unknown quantity is replaced by a given numerical quantity.<n><n>- Give an example of a number sentence where an entire number replaces an unknown whole number.<n><n>#### Explained: The given number sentence 3 - 2 = 1 or in words form 3 less 2 equals 1. The given number sentence contains an unknown quantity which is replaced by a known unknown quantity in the form of subtraction.<n><n>- Give a number sentence where the sum of whole numbers is written as a sub-traction.<n><n>#### Explication: The given number sentence where the sum fo whole numbers is written as subtraction as (55 + 63- 19= 1) or (55 + 4 + 1 + 15 + 3 = 8).<n><n>### Instrutioion:Answer the 4 questions below. Each question must be answered with more than 50 words. Write the best answer and explain it.<n>### Write and explain at least five different ways to add two whole numbers.<n>#### Explained : Addition is a basic and important arithmetic operation that allows you to combine numbers. There are six ways you can add whole numbers.<n><n>The first way to add two whole numbers is by counting starting at a given number. The second way is by counting backward starting from an unknown number. Another method is to count by starting from an actual base 10 value. In the third method, you count by a starting a point and writing the first number. You can also count forward starting from the end and keeping track of the second number on a piece of paper or a calculator. These four ways can help you add two whole numbers more easily. In the end, the math operation is the same no matter which one you use, but the method you use is different.<n><n>#### Addition Formula:<n>The second way to add two whole number is by the addition formula called the long addition formula<n><n>Addition Formula : The sum of n(n+1) + n(n+2) +..

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:The fat man refused to accept what was possible, he complained that he what the simplest activities? Choices:  A: no go B: unlikely C: unable D: cant do E: impossibility<n><n>### Response:		B: impossible, he complained that what he was capable of no go, unable, and cant do<n><n>### Explanation: The fat man refused to accept that no go, unable, cant do, and impossible things to do.<n>#### impossible<n><n>### Answer: B<n><n>### Input 2: The fat man refused the impossible, he complained he could do what?<n><n>### Response2 A: impossible C: what he was capable of doing impossible<n>### Explanion: impossible, the fat man complained that he could do impossible things. <n>#### impossible<n><n>#### possible<n><n>### Answer2: C<n><n># Questions to Add<n><n>**P1.** We have four options as input, choose which one is impossible<n><n>### Input3 : A: Going by plane to the moon is impossible<n>B: The air is very cold and very high<n>C: Its a dream<n>D: We will do it, we're people<n><n>### Instructions: In the sentence above 1 and 4 are false, explain the statements that are wrong<n><n>### Demostration1: Answer A<n><n>A: Going by plane is impossible because the first option says "its a dream".<n><n>### Answer3: C<n><n>### Demonsration:<n><n>Answer3: is Choice C is possible because Choice A said that its a dream<n><n>### Demotstration 2:<n>A: Its a dream, because Choice A said so<n>B: The air to cold, and it's too high above the Earth's atmosphere<n>C: We will do it and people can do it<n><n>### Instuctions: answer the following questions.<n><n>### 2. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What is someone who gets angry after getting drunk likely to participate in? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Though it stayed strictly indoors, the small dog felt like it had all the space in the world in the what? Follow the instructions exactly as written.<n><n>### Demo:<n>Write the following multiplication expressions in expanded form.<n><n>### 2 × 3 × 4 <n>* 2 + 2 + 2,<n>* 2 + (2 - 4) + 4,<n>* (2 + 2) + (2 - 2 - 4)<n>* (2 + (2 -4)) + 4<n><n>### 3 ×2 <n>*3 + (2 + 2),<n>* 3 + (2 - 3),<n>* (2(2 - 2)) + 2 + 3<n><n>### Response<n>The second expression expands to be (5 + 3) + (3-5) + 6.<n>We can rearrange the subtraction terms into a series of additions, one to each of the terms in the expression.<n>The next expression expands to be  (3) + (1 + 1) + (5) + (7).<n>We can rearrange all the additions into one addition, then add the multiplication terms.<n>The last expression expands to be ((3 + 2)) + (3 -3) + (1).<n>The addition terms can be rearranged into (3 + 5) + (3 + 4) + (1). He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where would there be many people sitting in chair and listening to religious speech? Choices:  A: auditorium B: office C: synagogue D: confession E: church<n><n>### Response:		Select a choice that contains the information below.<n>Auditorium<n><n>### Input<n>The people in a classroom have 5 pairs of socks each. The total number of students in the classroom is 20 less than the number of boys in the classroom. There are 11 girls in the classroom. How many girls are there in the classroom?<n>#### Answer:109<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. What is the value of s, if one centimeter equals 50 feet, and angle QPR equals 65 degrees?<n>#### 54<n><n>#### 54/25 = 2<n><n>### This is an image of a triangle with angles measured in degrees. The figure below is drawn to scale. What is the measure of angle PRQ in the triangle below?<n><n>### Response<n><n>### **85**<n><n>### 85 degrees<n><n>### *Hint: <n>The measures in the picture all have to be the same, or they would not be in an isosceles triangle. So we can draw two lines to connect the same angle. One goes from R to 110°, and one goes from Q to 110. Because they are 110, those two angles are congruent. So the congruence (or the side between those angles) is the hypotenuse of our right triangle. And since angles in a right triangle are congruent and the hypotenuse is always double that of the other two sides, that hypotenuse would be double the length of the adjacent side.<n><n>### <n>Answer:<n>3x/4=3<n><n>### Question : A pump moves water through a pipe from a river into a lake. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Sky diving scared him, once they jumped out of the plane he began losing consciousness while what? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where is a fox likely to be caught? How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Bob's feet hurt from running barefoot on the hot pavement.  I lost his shoes, didn't know where they landed, and had to run from the corner store to his home.  About where did he run? Choices:  A: a bed of nails B: town C: attractive consistent look D: city block E: ground<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Rationales:If he was running on the ground, then he could only run 25 meters.<n>Since he had to run from a corner store to his home, he didn't run on the ground.<n>So, he was running on hot pavement.<n><n>### Input：Bob's feet hurt. I lost his shoes. It takes 5 minutes to run at a steady pace. About how far did he run in a little over 4 hours? Choices: 1. less than a mile 2. between 1 to 5 miles 3. more than 5 miles 4. not sure<n><n>### Response： 4<n><n>### Rationale:5 miles is between 1to5.<n>Therefore, the response is 4.<n><n>### Repeat:<n>- The number of blocks traved on the way to the poat office is 5+20= ___.<n>- There are ___ many white chairs in a classrom.<n><n>### Check:<n>- If it takes 5 minute to run a steady pace, then about how far did he run?<n>- There are____ blue and green chairs in a classroot.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What could a massive building be if it is not constructed well? Choices:  A: insubstantial B: massless C: dwarf D: inconsequential E: good<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A is the correct answer choice.<n><n>#### A<n><n>Answer: "A"<n><n>#### 2)<n><n>2. Write and solve an equation for a system of linear equations.<n>Write and solve an equation for the set of linear equations below.<n>-3x + 2y - 6z = 8<n>7x - 4y - 11z = 17<n>The second equation should be subtracted from the first by subtracting 2y from both sides and then subtracting -3x from both sides of the second equation.<n>7x - 3x + 4y - 3x - 4x = 17 - 8<n>The 3x terms are combined to give: 3(x-x) = -8<n>x - x = -8<n>Therefore, x = -9.<n>The variables are the constants and are set to zero since the equations do not have variables on the left side and do not contain x + 2y.<n>The equations should be multiplied by -9 in order to obtain a solution.<n>-3(x - x) - 9(7x - 4z) = -8(17 - 8)<n>Therefore, 2x + 14y - 54z = 98, so the system of linear equations has the solution:<n>(x,y,z)=(9,14,54).<n><n>### Input : Write out and solve the following system of linear equations. 3(-6x + 2y) + (-10x + 6y) + (-3x + 7y) = -15 4(2x - 3y) + (17x - 8y) + (12x - 9y) = 19<n><n>### Response :<n><n>1. Write out and solve the given system of equations<n>2. The first equation should be multiplied by 2 and then subtracted from the second equation, -47.<n>3. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What would happen to a person if his or her money is stolen? How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:They checked the weather one more time during the flight, they were on their way to paradise and wanted it to what? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:He was a very sharp engineer, but when it came to the details his calculations could were often what? How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:The electric motor powered many important things, including one if almost every house.
