Choices:  A: electric locomotive B: electric typewriter C: multi-coloured walrus D: electric refrigerator E: electric drill<n><n>### Response:		The answer choice was "E" electric refrigerator<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the following task.<n><n>### Use 5 fractions: 1/4 1/2 1/5 1/10 1/20<n><n>A) Subtract the fractions:<n><n>+ - 4 = (5 - 4) = <<5-4=1>>1/1<n><n>+ - 2 = (7 - 2) = <<7-2=5>>1/2<n><n>+ - 5 = (7 - 5) = <<7-5=2>>1/5<n><n>+ - 10 = (8 - 10) = <<8-10=2>>1/10<n><n>+ - 3 = (9 - 3) = <<9-3=6>>1/20<n>A1) There are 5/4 = <<5/4=1.25>>1.25 fractions.<n><n>A2) 4/5 - 1/4 = <<4/5-1/4=(4/5)-1/(4/5)=4---->>1/2 of 1/1 fraction.<n><n>A3) 5/5 - 1 = <<5/5-1=1>>1/5 of 1/5 fraction.<n><n>A4) 1/2 - 1/10 = <<1/2-(1/10)=(3/10)-1/(3/10)=2---->>2/20 of 1/20 fraction.<n><n>A5) 1/5 - 10 = <<1-10=9>>9/10 of 1/10 fraction.<n><n>#### (3/10)  / (9/10) = 3/27<n><n>A5) The answer for 1/5 -10 = is 10/15 = 5/7 = 2/3 = 3/21<n><n>A6) The answer for 4/1 = 4/4 = 1/1 or 3/21.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:If I am a person, I have a unique ability to do what? How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:How is someone who loves their TV likely to feel about their remote? Choices:  A: attached B: nostalgic C: companionable D: likely E: close<n><n>### Response:		<n>The most likely feeling is going to be companionable.<n>### <n>Rationales: A is obviously incorrect since companionable could be derived from love for the TV<n>as opposed to attachment which is usually a negative word.  B is also incorrect since if you love your TV you could feel connected to it, but likely not nostalgic about it.  The feeling of being nostalgic comes with time, and it would be unlikely for someone to have a nostalgic feeling about their TV.  C is also incorrect since companionable also comes with time.  It also is the feeling that someone can get when someone that they love or cherish goes away, not when someone gets a new remote.

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:The camper looked up at the vast night sky, it left him feeling mighty what? Choices:  A: unimportant B: insignificant C: stellar D: somewhat E: helpless<n><n>### Response:		B<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How many cats are left now?<n>Rationales:-The first cat gave birth once and had 1 kittens which is 10.<n>The second cat gave birth once and has 9 kittens.<n>The third cat gave birth once and no new kittens which is only one now.<n>The fourth cat gave birth once and have 8 kittens.<n><n>The fifth cat has given birth once and 7 kittens.<n>While the sixth one has only one kitten.<n>Now, the seventh cat and the eight cat each have 6 kittens.<n>Now the ninth cat gave birth again giving 5 kittens.<n>In total, the number of kittens that there are now is 55(9 plus 10).<n><n>#### 55<n>Answers：55<n><n><n>### Demons:<n>Input:  How many blocks are in a 50 foot, 23-inch long train?<n>Output：50*230=124
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:what happens to a company when it is bankrupt? Sticking to the fingers sounds like it would be sticky.<n><n>### Input 2<n>I am looking to buy a caffeine beverage right from the roaster, where should I go for the freshest taste? Choices: A: Starbucks B: Dunkin Doanuts C: Cafe Bustelo D: McDonalds<n><n>### Response 2<n><n>#### Explanations:<n>A and B are incorrect because they buy coffee rather than roast coffee and sell it at the same place.<n>D is incorrect because it looks like McDonald's roasts coffee and the beverages are sold in the same place.<n>C is incorrect because it sounds like they roast coffee themselves.<n><n>#### Response<n><n><n><n>The correct response is D.<n><n>#### Explanatioon<n><n>D is correct because it sounds like they do their own roasting.<n><n>### Question<n><n><n><n>### Response<n><n>A is the wrong answer choice because it is in the list.<n>F is the wrong answer choice. Although there are 2 or more possibilities in a set, there are only 0 or 1 possibilities in a function.<n>A or B is not possible if only one choice is in a choice.<n>C is a true value because only it and E are true.<n>D is a true value because B, C, and D are true.<n><n>#### Examplifications<n><n>A and B are not true.<n>F is false. Although there are 0 or 1 possible elements in a function, all or some could be true.<n>C and E are true. All or some could be true if only two are.<n>D is false because A is true, but D is false. D is false because A is not true.<n>F and G should have similar responses and answers.<n><n>#### Explangration<n><n>D can have multiple values on the function. If the only ones that are true are A, B, C, then they can be true.<n><n><n>### Instuction<n><n>Input: The number 2 was __________ the number 4.<n>Rationales: 2 added 4 = <<2+4=6>>6<n>The answer was 6 - 2 = <<6-2=4>>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Jimmy wanted a beer but his wife was an alcoholic on probation.  Where might he go? Choices:  A: neighbor's house B: bridge C: home D: homeless shelter E: prison<n><n>### Response:		A<n>

It refers to the use of mental steps to figure out numbers and answer questions. For example, I know I spent $20 this week, and I don’t want to buy anything new, so I should save some extra cash for the weekend.<n><n>### Answer:<n>Computation is when a person uses a process in many ways to figure out similar problems.<n><n>### Problem-solving is a process the person works through each time he encounters a single problem.<n><n>### How do you turn a square box into a circle box? How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What might a person receive from their boss if they do a poor job? Choices:  A: misfortune B: fearful C: criticism D: make mistakes E: promotion appraisal<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Input: What might a person receive from there boss if they do an poor job?<n><n>### Question:Boss: What is promotion appraisal?<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>Input:What might a person received from there boss if the do a poor job?<n><n>Output: The answer will be in the form: <Letter+Question+Answer><n><n><n>##  D<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## B<n><n>Input: A pizza parlor was looking for a few extra helpers at the busiest time of year. All applicants for the job would be asked the same question, “Who would you rather work with - a cow who can type 100 words each minute or 4 hedgehogs who can type at 100 words per minute?” Applicants must choose one of the 5 options below.<n><n><n>###  A1<n><n>####  A2<n><n>## C<n><n>### Instruct: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>Demonstration:<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Question<n><n>### Rationales <n><n>Output:  <Letter+Question>  <Rationales+Question><n><n>### Output:<n>A: D<n><n><n>### Input :  Choose one of the 5 possibilities.<n>Question: What type of employee you would want to work with?<n><n>A: The 4 hedgehog<n><n>#### Rationales : The 4 hedgeho<n><n><n><n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Bob and Boris were standing in a queue at the grocery store.  They were standing in place.  The line was fast, but the children in front of them were loud.   They were what? Choices:  A: frustration B: being annoyed C: delays D: irritation E: out of order<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>\(A) frustration<n>Since they were “fast”, they had a chance of being ahead of the children who are “loud”. However, they were not moving. And then since the children behind them were “loud”, they were irritated as well. Hence, they are frustrated.\(B) being annoyed<n>Since they were “frustrated” and not moving, they were annoyed.\(C) delays<n>Since there were children “loud” in front of them, they were “delays” as well.<n>However, they “fast” and also moved.<n>Therefore, this choice is wrong.<n>\(D) irritation<n>Since they are not moving, they are “irritation”.<n>\(E) out of order<n>Since there are children “loud” and “fast” ahead of them, this is not the correct choice.<n><n>### Input Bob has a 4-digit number in mind, where each digit is less than 6. The number increases in value from left to right on a 10s-1s basis. All the digits are unique. The number is divisible by 3. In how many different ways can Bob represent his number?<n><n>### Instructions:<n>The following are the options:<n>\(A) 1293<n>\(B) 3621<n>\(C) 2194<n>\(D) 1932<n>\(E) 3921<n>\(F) 3612<n><n>### Response<n>\(A) is incorrect.  The third digit is greater than 1 and less than 6. \(B) is wrong.  The third digit exceeds six and is less than ten.   The answer should be a four-digit number.   However, the fourth digit has to be zero.\(C) is correct because the number is divisible by three. The third digit is less than six and less than three.  <n>\(D\) should not be used. The fourth digit should be less than six.   The number's fourth digit should be a 1 or 2.\(E\) is incorrect.   There is no way to divide it into three parts.\(F) is incorrect because the number's last digit is three.  <n><n>### Input Janet says to

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How far did they all walk?<n><n><n>## Rationale:<n>The number of blocks walked by the Changs going along the street was 5 + 3 = <<5+3=8>>8 blocks.<n><n>The number of blocks the Changs and the dog together walked by walking the dog 2 back was 3 + 2 = <<3+2=5>>5 blocks.<n><n>The dog walked 5 + 3 - 2 = <<5+3-2=3>>3 blocks back.<n><n>Therefore, the group walked together 8 +

There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:The person knew the police were after him, so what did he do? Choices:  A: the sun B: catch cold C: prepare to go D: feel humiliated E: hunt for food<n><n>### Response:		<n>The person knew the police, so he did something that would make him hungry. So the answer is choice E.<n><n>#### Explanation:<n><n>#### Input:Which expression simplifies to 1/2? 1/2 × 1/2 1/4 × 4 1/8 × 3 1/16 × 8 - 1/16<n><n>### Demand:<n><n>A.The expression 5/3 × 5/3 simplifies to 5/3.<n><n>B.The expression 2/4 × 4/4 simplifies to 1.<n><n>### Response 1:<n>The expression 8/16 × 4/4 which equals to 7/8.<n><n>## <n>The sum of all the numbers between two integers is which number<n>### Response: The sum of all the numbers that are less than the greatest integer equals to that greatest integer. That means the sum of all the numbers b/w 0-9 is 9.<n><n>## Summary:<n><n>### Input<n>You add 16, 18, 19, 20, and 21 to get 90. The question is asking for the sum of the first five even numbers less than 20.<n><n>### Output<n>- 16 + 20 = 36<n>- 18 + 22 = 40<n>- 20 + 24 = 44<n>- 22 + 26 = 48<n>- 24 + 30 = 54<n>- 26 + 32 = 58<n>- 28 + 36 = 64 <n>That sums to 64, which is not correct. <n>### Rationales: <n><n>### Summary 2:<n>The second question asks for the sum of all the odd numbers. You would need to add all the odd numbers less than 21, and that would equal to 51. <n><n>### Explanation:<n>The question asks for the sum, so I will combine all of the even integers that are less than 20 to give me an even result.<n><n>### Exam:<n>- 16, 20, 24. 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where would you get a bass clarinet to take home? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:A person with brown skin may share that skin with whom? How many friends does Julie have?<n><n>Answer: 8<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Instruction:Write a response that appropriately addresses the request.<n><n>#### 46<n>Answer:<n><n># Exercises<n><n>### Instructio:Write a response that demonstrates appropriate computation.<n><n>### Procedure:Add 123.98 × 6.69<n><n>### Answer:"123.96"<n><n>### Instrumention:<n><n>### Insttructions: Write a response that demonstrates the appropriate computation.<n><n><n>```py<n>a = 123.78<n>b = 98<n>answer = a + b<n>print(answer)<n>```<n><n><n><n>### Answer:<n><n>## Input:<n><n>### Response to Instruction:<n><n>## Instructions:Write a response that has a command word (e.g., add) and the operands (e.g., 3 and 4) that represents the computation that you plan to perform.<n><n>### Answer to Input:<n><n>## Instruction:"What's your name?" the bus driver asked Julie. -Julie<n>-Julie's name is Julie.<n><n>### Response<n>Julie is Julie.<n>## Instruction:<n><n>"What do humans do when they in a race?" Choices: A: lie eggs B: eat fruit and vegetables C: wrestle D draw pictures and paintings<n><n>Response:<n><n>Lay eggs, lie eggs<n><n>## Instruction<n><n>"Which one is greater, 7 or 6?" asked the teacher. -Julie<n>The answer is 7.<n><n>Response<n><n>The answer is 6.<n><n>## Exercise:<n><n>## Ex
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What happens to people playing games? Choices:  A: winning B: entertainment C: happiness D: cheating E: relaxation<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>  **C. happiness**<n><n>### Explanation: Games are for entertainment. They make people happy.<n><n>### Additional resources:<n><n>#### [Introduction to programming](https://www.khanacademy.org/computing/computer-science/cs-principles/prog-cs-intro-topic/a/introduction-to-programming)<n>#### [Factorials](https://www.mathsisfun.com/factorials.html)<n>#### [Fractions and decimals](https://www.bbc.com/bitesize/articles/zht94qt)<n><n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. Choices:  A: town B: carpeting C: city D: phone book E: magazines<n><n>### Response:		Choice A<n>####<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Input: In which of the following places would you find a bookstore – town, city, carpeting, phone book, or magazines?<n>Answer: The choice is A – town.<n><n>### The answer choices are A – town, B – city, C – carpeting, D – phone book, and E – magazines.<n><n>## Rationale: A bookstore would be found in the town if you are looking for it there. A bookstore would not be found in a city, carpeting (carpet), phone book, or magazine. <n><n>### The question is answered accurately.<n><n>### Choice A: town<n><n>####<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Instrument: Answer the following multiple-choice statement.<n><n>## Input : In which of the following items would you find the phone book? Choices: A: books B: carpeting  C:  City  D: magazines E: town<n><n>### Choices are A: books, B: carpeting, C: City, D: magazines, and E: town.<n><n>## Rationales: If you were trying to find something mentioned in a carpet, phone book, or magazine, you would probably not use the phone book.<n><n>### Phone books include information such as phone numbers, addresses, and maps. You can expect to find it somewhere in a town.<n><n>## Incorrect Answers: Choice C:<n>The answer is C in the town since it is mentioned in the question. B, D, and E are incorrect answers.<n><n>## E: town<n><n>#### <n>Answer: A-books<n><n>### Input : Where could you find a book store?<n><n>### Choixes : A: town B: city C: carpeting D: phone book E : magazines<n><n>####<n>Answers: Choice D- Phone Book<n><n>### Rationales: <n><n>### If you were looking for a bookstore, you could go to the carpeting, city, phone book, or the magazine. You are likely to find them in a town. Phone books are used to store phone numbers, addresses, or maps.<n><n>### Therefore,

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:The sample needed to be pure, but the lab assistant got it what? Choices:  A: corrupt B: applied C: dirty D: contaminated E: fresh<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: The sample needed to be pure but the lab assistant got is dirty.<n>Rationales: Dirty implies contaminated, which means that the sample is the wrong choice or not pure.<n><n>The answer is E. It should be pure. <<P>  = <<pure>>P|<n><n>### Direction :<n>For each of questions, draw a correct answer that follows the directions given.<n><n>### Input :<n><n>You have 131 more marbles than Danny does. She has 103 fewer marbles than you do. How many marbles do you and Danny have all in all?<n><n>### Input 2 :<n><n>While playing baseball, the score was 12 to 10 in the home team’s favor. Then the away team scored six runs in the last inning to win 16 to 12. By how many runs did the home team lose in the last inning? Write the answer as an integer. (Do not include the negative sign in your answer.)<n><n>### Response 2 :<n><n>Inputs: You have 131 marbles more than Danny does. Danny has 260 marbles. The sum of 131 + 260 = <<131+260=391>>391.<n>Inputs 2: You both have 391 marbles altogether.<n>Answer: Both players have 391.<n><n>---<n><n><n>### Instructions 2 :<n><n>Draw a correct answer that follows these directions.<n><n>### Danger:You are in your room with 403 marbles. The marbles in the bag are 14 more than the total number of marbles in the bag and in your hand. How many marbles are in your hand?<n><n>### Dare:The marbles in the bag were once in your hand. Now the marbles in your hand are 30 less than the total number of all the marbles. How many marbles were in the bag? Write your answer as an integer.<n><n>### Response :<n><n>Inputs to the first question: You have 403 marble, plus 14 more than that is <<403+14>>417.<n><n>Inputs to dare: <<The marbles
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What do you need to have before buying products? Choices:  A: desire B: spending money C: money D: needs E: time<n><n>### Response:		<n>  D is the correct answer.<n>      <n>### Rationale:<n><n>  Answer: A is incorrect because you need "spending money" to buy products.<n>  Answer: B is incorrect because you need to have money before buying products.<n>  Answer C: E is incorrect because it does not mention that you need time to buy products.<n><n>#### E<n><n>Answer: E<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>In our opinion we should choose the correct answer which should be "E".<n><n>      We believe it's "time" that you should have, to have the ability to buy products you are looking for.<n><n>### Output<n><n>  D<n><n>### Exercise:<n><n>Solve the problems above.<n><n>### Notes:<n><n>#### Notes:<n><n>Think about the task and the solution.<n><n>```<n>  Input #1:<n><n>  $5 is on the left so we subtract 5 from both sides.<n>  $30 - $5 = 25.<n><n>  Input #2:<n><n>  $200 and $100 were the top amounts so we take away $200 - $100 - $20 = $50 from the last amount.<n><n>  Input 3:<n><n>  $375 - $250 = 125.<n>```<n><n>#### Exercise Solution:<n><n>Solve all four of the problems above, including all the steps.<n><n>#### Notes:How to work out ExerciseSolution:<n><n>1. Write Exercise Solution as a multiple step problem.<n><n>Example:<n>`$5 is on the left.`<n><n>`$(5 - 6) on the right`<n><n>Or<n>`$(5 - $6) on the right.`<n><n>`$5 is 6 units away from the left so we must take 6 away from both sides.`<n><n>`(2) on the left.`<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. They hear sounds. Noises are sounds.<n>C: pets make babbies. They hear sounds and have sex.<n>D: humans make (and reproduce) babies. They see and hear.<n>E: humans make babies. Humans see and hear.

B: Subtract the numerator from both sides. C: Multiply the numerator by both sides D: Divide the numerator by both side of the equation.<n><n>### Response :<n>E<n>### Instructor explanation:<n>Divide divides the numerator by the denominator, leaving the numerator.<n>Take away takes away both sides of the equation, leaving nothing.<n><n>#### Correct Response<n>Answer: E<n><n>### Input A: If a number is multiplied by 6, the number increases by 3. When the number is divided by 4 the number decreases by 8 What is the number?<n><n>### Response<n>- B : 43<n>- D : 44<n>- E : 2<n>- F : 35<n>### Instructed Explanation:<n>If a number is multiplied it increases by 3 because an x means to add another to it. Therefore 3x= 3 + 3= 6. When a number is divided it decreases by 8 because a divided by a number is greater than a number so in this case: 4/4 the number (4) is  divided by 4 4 =1/4 decreases by 4 (1), thus 1/4 - 4=3/4<n><n>#### Correct<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input B: A car traveling 90 miles per hour takes _ minutes _ to cover a certain distance. There is no need for a variable. By using a variable there is extra steps taken. 160 miles / 60 minutes = 2.6

Choices:  A: theater B: computer C: opera D: television E: concert<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A. Theatrical performances are typically accompanied by printed programs that provide a synopsis of the performance to be staged and other important information about the show. Therefore, an obvious place to find a paper program is at a theater.<n><n>B. Computer programs are sets of instructions (or programming) that tell a computer what to do.<n><n>C. The term opera comes from the Italian word opera, which means “work.” It first applied to the musical compositions of the Renaissance.<n><n>D. Television programs are broadcast through the airwaves as electromagnetic signals and are received at home by a television set.<n><n>E. Concert programs are promotional publications (usually on paper, but also electronic) for musicians and ensembles presenting their concerts. They detail all the important information related to the event, such as the time, date, and venue, and in many cases include a description of the event, a biography of the performers, a playlist for each performance and the musical program in case of an opera, and photographs relating to the event.<n><n>### Output:<n>The answer is A<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:If they were celebrating the occasion, how could the occasion be described? Choices:  A: drinking B: intimacy C: dancing D: happiness E: enjoyment<n><n>### Response:		D<n>#### D<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Input:(4 + 8) ÷ 2 A: 3 B: 3 C: 3.5 D: 4 E: 5<n><n>### Response:(4+8)÷2=12<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Instructions:If the temperature is -1, which letter is the closest to zero on the number line?<n><n>### Rationales:As on the number line,<n><n>#### -3 and -2 are closer to zero, so -2 is closer.<n><n>#### -2 and -1 are closer to zero, as -1 is closer to it.<n>#### -2, -1, and -1 are closer, so<n>#### #-1 is closest.<n>#### -1 is closest.<n>A: -1<n>A: -1.<n>#### -1<n>Answer: -1<n><n>### Input:"We will walk 3 miles east, then north, then west to the restaurant. When we are finished, we will have walked 2 miles east and south." How many blocks does the walk consist of?<n><n>### Input:[1 + 3] ÷ x = 5<n><n>## Input:If they were playing chess, what would be the chessboard in use? Choices: A: Standard B: Reversible C: Checker D: Difficult E: None<n><n>### Response:"E"<n>Rationales:The only letter that is not a choice is E, which would be a None, since they are not playing chess.<n>A: Standard<n>B: Reversible<n>C: Checker<n>D: Difficult<n>E: None<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where could you find some large pieces of paper that are not for sale? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What is not a safe way to transport jewelry on vacation? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:They launch a surprise attack, this ended the what? Choices:  A: surrender B: defence C: retreat D: cease fire E: defend<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>If they launch a surprise attack, it means that they attacked in a sneaky way that is hard to be prepared. Defence means defending one's position. And so, C is the answer.<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: She wanted to be a writer, but she couldnt find work. There was a job opening that she applied for, and it appeared she would be hired. The job she interviewed for offered a nice pay and good benefits. Was she hopeful she would get hired for that job in her field? A. No, she had to be hopeful because she was interviewed for another job. B. The job she interviewe for had good benifits such as high pay and good benifits. C. She wanted to become a writer for her the rest of her life<n>D. The job that she interviewed for offered her a nice pay and good benifit<n>E. She applied for job but she did not know if she would be hired for the job<n>F. She was interwieved<n>Rationales: She could not get the work in the first place, but the job has good benifits and her interest is to be a writer.<n>Answer: E<n><n># Partial Inputs<n>Input: They launch a surprise attack, you can choose from choices A: surrender   B: defence C: Retreat D: ceasefire E: Defend<n>Rationales: Choice B is the answer.<n><n># Partial Outputs<n>Output: <<E>><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:The shore was now a tourist attraction with nearby little shops, but at one time this what was home to a bustling fishing industry? Choices:  A: seaside town B: resort C: ocean D: california E: beach<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Demostrate:<n><n><n>### Instructions:Follow the prompts to answer the question.<n><n>#### 2145<n>Answer: 222<n><n>Input: There are 15 people, each in a different country, who are all planning to cross the lake to the other side. They are able to each cross in one of two ways. They can go by boat and stay on the boat the whole time, or they can cross the lake by land, walking. The first person crosses by boat and the remaining 14 cross by land. How many people cross the lake (both ways)?<n>Rationales: 5 people go by land and one goes by boat.<n>The total number is 5 + 1 = <<5+1=6>>6.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:When someone falls from a mountain it will lead them to? Choices:  A: too much B: act dead C: die D: rush E: explode<n><n>### Response:		Choice: D<n><n><n>### Input,Instruction and Answer:<n><n><n>## How to solve this: <n>## The answer we came up with is 67 <n><n><n>### Your Solution:<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>We can solve this problem by calculating the sum of the number of blue chairs (10), the number of green chairs (30),and the number of white chairs (13).<n><n><n>### Demostration (Instructions):<n><n>The sum of the number of Blue Chairs, Green chairs and White chairs is<n><n><n>Blue Chairs : 10<n><n>Green Chairs : 30<n><n>Whites Chairs : 13<n><n>There are (10 + 3/2 +13) in total<n><n><n><n>### Answer:<n>This is 67.<n><n>The number of Chairs in the Classroom is $ 67 $<n><n><n>## How we do this:<n>We started with what we know, that<n>Blue chairs - 10 x 1<n><n>Then we took half of 10 that is 5<n>Next we solved 13 white chairs which is 13 x 1<n>Then we solved 30/2 which is 15<n><n>#### Green chairs<n>Next we solved 30 x 2 that is 60<n>Next we took 25 from the 60 which is 35<n>We then took 17 from the 30 which is 13<n>Finally we added all of these together to get 10, 11, 13 and 17.<n>We then took the total amount of these to get to the total.<n><n><n>### What made us believe that this solution is correct?<n><n>I believe that  it is correct because what we were given in the instructions the answer was 67<n><n>Which made us solve for how to get to that number.<n><n>We did it and we had the result as the answer.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:There was a saucepan used only for marinara, where was it kept? Choices:  A: georgia B: the south pole C: kitchen cupboard D: italian restaurant E: boil eggs<n><n>### Response:		 C  kitchen cupboard<n><n>### Rationale B:The south pole - Not a good choice<n><n>### Rational E: Boil eggs - This is not a correct answer<n><n>### Rating: **Correct** (C)<n><n>### Input The number of minutes before sunset of an afternoon on Monday, September 11th was 3 less than the number of minutes before sunrise of the morning on Monday. On Tuesday, September 12th, that number is 5 times the number before sunrise that Monday. At sunset on Tuesday, how many minutes before sunrise was it? (Express the answer as an integer. Round to the nearest minute. If the answer is not an integer, type "Not an integer.")<n><n>### Response The number of minutes before the sunset was 3 less than number of minutes of sunrise of the day that was 5 times the number of minutes between the sunrise that of the day before. The sunset was on Tuesday, September, the 12th. The number of minutes before Sunday, The sunrise was 2:05 AM. Since the number of minutes before the first sunrise was 3 more. Then after 2:05am then 5 times 3 = 15 minutes. Therefore, the answer is 15.<n><n>### The correct answer is 222. Since we subtract 3 from the number of minutes that sun is up then 5 times that is 15 and when you subtract that number from what we found which is 222, then we are left with negative 58, therefore, negative 58 is NOT an integer.<n><n>### Ration:<n>The number of minutes before the Sun was up on the second day is 5 less than the number of times before the Sun was set on the day before. In response to Monday, September 12: Sunrise was 3:05 a.m. Less the amount is before the sun rose up.<n><n>The amount of time that was before and after the sunrise was 5 minutes.<n>### Rating : 3<n><n>Input: <n>If a dog sleeps 1 hour, a cat sleeps 0.01 hours, and a coyote sleeps 30 hours, then how
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where is a system of electronic devices likely to be used in school? Choices:  A: nature B: toilet C: computer science D: computer store E: human body<n><n>### Response:		What is the number of questions that were answered correctly?<n><n>### Answer: C<n><n>### Rationale:<n>The question states that the response is likely to be used in a school so therefore it will most likely be in a computer science class.<n><n>### Input<n>How are electronic devices used in school? Choose A through E.<n>A: nature<n>B: toilet<n>C: computer science<n>D: computer store<n>E: human body<n><n>Rationales: "Toilet" was not the correct answer.<n><n>### Answer<n>C<n><n>### Input : What does an aerospace engineer study? Choices: A: airplanes B: space C: dinosaurs D: stars E: none of the above<n><n>### Response<n>What is the number of years?<n><n>### Rationales: Aerospace engineering studies airplanes, space, and dinosaurs.<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input <n>What does an aerospace engineers do? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. Choices:  A: theatre B: fairgrounds C: friend's house D: show E: casino<n><n>### Response:		A or E<n><n>### Rationale:<n>There are many different types of entertainment that can offer a great experience. The fairgrounds are a great place to see many rides, like roller coasters and high-speed thrill rides. I like rides that spin, spin and turn. When I do things with my friends, we always have a good time.<n>The theatre is a great place to see a play or a musical. I'm interested in seeing a show. The casino is a great place to play a game of chance.<n>Finally, if you want to relax and enjoy nature, the show is an excellent option.<n><n>### I've decided! I'm going to the fairground.<n>#### Thank you for your assistance.<n><n>### Let me know if you have any more questions.<n><n>### 1: You<n>```<n>Let me know if you have another question.<n>```<n><n>### 2: My sister<n>```<n>I had 188 more toothpaste than you.<n>```<n><n>Rationale: You have less than my sister.<n>###### - 1: I<n>```<n>I would prefer to be asked out for a nice dinner.<n>```<n><n>###### - 2: My sister  <n>```<n>I would rather be ate a box of chocolates.<n>```<n><n>This is her choice.<n><n>### My friend<n>```<n>That is fascinating.<n>```<n><n>In general, you should use this statement.<n>If the speaker said something that sounds impressive, you can say "that's fascinating."<n>You can say it to acknowledge that he or she got a good grade after a disappointment.<n>For example, if someone said: "I think we're going to fail this course. I'm not getting any answers. I really don't get it," if you say, "that's fascinate" it implies sympathy and encouragement.<n>If someone said, "I think we'll have better weather next week," it's an indication of encouragement.<n>Instead of saying "yeah, right" this sounds more polite.<n><n>When people say, "I don't think so" or "I bet you that "is this a bad response to a new idea you have no idea how it works?<n><n>##

Therefore, "too holy" in the context of James's thought process means not free from human imperfection, and not human error.<n><n>### Input:"Grow some peppers if you'd like a hot meal.  Tomatoes are spicy this time of year."<n><n>### Response:"Thanks.  I'll try to get some peppers."<n><n>### Expl:<n>"Thanks." means "Thank you." in this context.  "I'll try to get" means "I'll do my best to get."  "Some peppers" is used instead of the phrase "the peppers".  The subject of the sentence is "I'll try" which means "I'll try my best," and not "I'll try the peppers."<n><n><n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:The shelf was showing signs of instability, what should the carpenter fix to avoid any issues? Choices:  A: roof B: corner C: school building D: wall E: cupboard<n><n>### Response:		The shelf was showing signs it was going to fall. The carpenter needs to make sure the roof is sturdy, and doesn't have any cracks.<n>#### E

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:At a state fair judging pigs requires careful what? Choices:  A: verdict B: judging C: responsibility D: evaluating E: prejudice<n><n>### Response:		Verdict, judging, responsibility, evaluating, prejudice<n>#### <n>C: responsibility<n><n>Input: Choose the best answer for: A: The most important problem facing our country is ______. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. Sam ran 1,025 more miles<n>than Sally. Sally ran 3 fewer miles<n>than Mark. Mark ran 350 more miles<n>than Mary. How many miles did Mark<n>run?<n><n>### Answer: Mark ran 2,573 miles.<n><n>### Justification:<n>- The difference of 3 + 3 = 6 miles<n>- The difference of Mary and Mark = 350 + 3 = 353 miles.<n>- Then, the difference of Mark and Mary = (353 + 200) + 3 = 2,572 miles.<n>- Sally also ran 3 miles less than Mark = (1,025 + 3) miles = 1,028 miles.<n>- Then the difference of Mary, Mark, and Sally = 353 + (3 - 2) = 353 - 2 = 355 miles.<n>- Therefore, Mark ran 355 - 353 = 2 miles.<n><n><n>

How many students in the class do not have lunch?"}]<n><n>### Response"55% of the children in the class bring lunch. So, 55% - 10% = <<55% - 8 = 47%%>47% of the students bring lunch, and 47% / 2 = <<47%/2=23%>>23% of the students go to the cafeteria. So, 23% + 47% = <<23%+47%=70%>70% or 175/2. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:James was cooking s stew in his apartment kitchen.  Where might he look for a potato. Choices:  A: restaurants B: casserole C: root cellar D: pockets E: pantry<n><n>### Response:		<n>He would look for potato in E: Pantry.

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where did his wife ask him to look first when he complained of missing deodorant? Choices:  A: say thank B: smile C: looking for D: get more E: show appreciation<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer: A(say thank)<n><n>Demonstration:<n>Thank is a process of appreciating something. Therefore A is a grammatically correct answer.<n><n><n>### Input : If I put a number between 10 and 100, what is the median?Choices :  A : 50 B : 85 C : 90 D : 63 E : 75<n><n>### Response :<n><n>Answer: A (50)<n><n>Demonstation :<n>Median is the middle value of a group. There are 4 values: 10, 100, 50 and 63. Therefore, the median is 50.<n><n>### Input - Choose the correct answer from the ones given below : I am a friend because of all the times I was there for you no matter what. - Choices :A : I am a friend for all the times I was not there for you<n><n>### Response -<n><n>Answer: A and C is both correct answer<n><n>Demonstations :<n>A(I am a friend because of...) is grammatically correct.<n><n>B(I am a friend... was not there) is grammatically incorrect because it's missing a 'for'.<n><n>C(was there for you no matter... not there for you) is grammatically correct. Therefore, both A and C are grammatically correct answers.

If he can use 29 less cookies in the cakes, how many cookies in all will he bake?<n><n>### Demosntration:<n><n>### A baker named Paul has a total of 99 cookies (99/4 = <<99/4=24.75>>24.75). How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What is a parents primary duty? Choices:  A: speak freely B: happiness of a child C: care for children D: school child E: control children<n><n>### Response:		<n>There are six sentences and this is the only correct answer - "A" - parents should speak freely to their children.<n><n>### Input<n>>   The student population at Lake Middle School is 58% female and 42% male.<n>>   The student council is comprised of 67% female students and 33% male students.<n>>   If 13 female students are randomly selected from the school, how many of them will be on student council?<n>> Use a ratio to answer the question if necessary.<n>#### Response<n>You need to use the information to create a ratio. Let Female = x ; Male = y ; Population = P ; Student Council = SC.<n><n>Ratio: P: x: SC: y<n>Therefore, the ratio is 13:x:SC:y<n>SC:1 : 5480/23136 = <<5480/64202=279>>279<n>x :1 : 23136/5480 = <<23136,64202>>64202279<n><n>Thus, the answer is 6420:2:2<n><n>### Input 1<n>>  The population in each state ranges from a mean of 1.128 to a maximum of 8.57 million.<n> > In the same state, the ratio of males to females ranges from a low of 88:100 to a high of 47.8:52.2.<n><n><n>#### Response 1<n><n>Ratio: 88:666 = <<666/88>>386:88 :47.8:666<n>Females: 666/8346 = <<665/(8346)= 79.3>>79.3:666 :52.2:666<n><n>#### Response 2<n><n>Ratio : Females:88 = <<88/88== 1>>1 : [1]<n><n>### Input (2)<n>Four children were chosen to participate in a community clean-up. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:If children get confused walking home where may they go?
