Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:The teams were evenly matched when competing against one another, what did spectators want to find out? Choices:  A: envy B: resentment C: winning or losing D: one winner E: two winners<n><n>### Response:		A: envy  <n>Rationales: In addition to the fact that the teams were evenly matched, teams that consistently lose would be envious of teams that consistently win.<n>While teams that don't always win are at least satisfied knowing they were competitive, they wouldn't like being behind.<n>#### envy<n>Answer: envy<n><n>### Input : The coaches had to make sure that each of their players were practicing well so that they would all win the first game for the season. What would winning the first game mean to the team? Choices: 19: A: one winner 20: B: two winners 21: C: winning or losing 22: D: envy E: resentment  <n><n>### Response : 20: B : two winners <n>Rationales: Winning the first game will mean the team has a good chance of having a winning season. This means they would be excited.<n>If they lost the first game it would mean the team would have to work hard in order to win the rest of the season. This won't be as exciting. It would bring frustration, as they wanted to win the whole season.<n>#### two winners<n>Answer: two winners<n>

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What is a place where you usually store dishes but not books? Choices:  A: apartment B: pantry C: table D: living room E: shelf<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### A: apartment<n>You have provided correct answer.<n><n>#### B: pantry<n>You have provided correct but alternative answer.<n><n>#### C: table<n>Not matching with input.<n><n>#### D: living room<n>Not matching with input<n><n>#### E: shelf<n>Unacceptable answer<n><n>### Reference: [The Complete Book of Math Trivia][1]<n><n><n>[1]: http://www.dummies.com/shop/dummies-lifestyle/the-complete-book-of-math-trivia/<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Parents often yell in times of chaos, what are they trying to do? Choices:  A: guide children B: understand children C: control children D: care for children E: vent anger<n><n>### Response:		B<n>

Choices:  A: city B: strip mall C: clerk D: neighborhood E: rooster<n><n>### Response:		 A <n><n>### Rationales: <n>Input: The salon is a place where people go to be beautified which makes them feel good about themselves.<n>#### B: strip mall<n><n>Input: A strip mall is a type of retail property (for sale or lease) consisting of small businesses (typically restaurants, clothing stores, florists, etc) that are connected.<n><n>#### C: clerk<n><n>Input: A clerk may work in a store, hotel, or restaurant.<n><n>#### D: neighborhood<n><n>Input: A neighborhood in a city or town where people work, live, and go to school.<n><n>#### E: rooster<n>A rooster is the male of a chicken.<n>##### <n>Answer: B<n><n>### Input : Choose one number. A: 5 B: 41  C: 53 D: 58 E: 62<n><n>### Rationale:  A: 5<n>The city is 5 times the size of the strip mall. <n>B: 41<n>The strip mall is 41 times the size of the beauty salon.<n>C: 53<n>The beauty salon is 41 times larger than the clerk.<n>D: 58<n>There are 41 people more working in the city than the clerk. <n>E: 62<n>Hence, the rooster is about 6 times the size of the city.<n>#### 53<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input Choices:  A. City _____  the  strip mall  ___1___ ___2___ B. strip mall  ____1___ city C. clerk  ____2___ beauty mall D. Beauty  ____1___ salon  strip mall E. Rooster  ____3___ city  __4__<n><n>### Ratios: Choice A Choice B<n>A city: City is 10 times the size of the Strip mall.<n>B: Strip mall is 40 times the size of clerk<n>C: Clerk is 60 times the size of beauty shop <n>D: Beauty  shop is 10 times bigger than strip mall<n>E: Rooster is 40 times bigger

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. To get to a rest stop 30 miles away, she has to drive 25 miles on a winding road, then 40 miles on an even road.<n><n>### Input : a.The total number of miles traveled<n><n>### Output: c.What was the woman's percentage error in her estimate of the distance to the reststop?<n><n>### Rational: 1. The woman drove 25 miles to the reststop<n>2. Then driving from the reststop to where she started the winding road was 45 miles<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What do only some types of police do? Choices:  A: direct traffic B: board vessels C: arm themselves D: help people E: find drugs<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Explain why your answer is correct.<n><n>### Input<n>Police work together for the safety of people in their city. All types of police, except for the one that boards vessels, help people. It is not part of their jobs to find drugs or find themselves being boarded by a police officer.<n><n>### Answer<n>Answer: A. Direct Traffic<n><n>--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:She'd sooner just spray herself with water than the what she didn't like the smell of? Choices:  A: perfume B: air C: fountain D: swamp E: puddle<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Another version of a darned word that indicates that not to do something that is likely to be unpleasant, disagreeable, or uncomfortable. We can use this word to indicate, in a humorous way, that we like another option, such as to something we don’t like.<n><n>### Input She'd rather stay at home than go to the party?<n><n>### Examination She'd prefer rather to go to the party than to stay at home. She'd rather go to the party than stay at home.<n><n>### Note:<n><n>### Choice A:<n>If we use she’d, we are saying that she doesn’t want to do something. To spray herself with perfume is disagreeable to her. So use she’d prefer to spray herself with water.<n><n>### Choices B:<n>The use of the word swamp is too overbearing for this question. It is too negative and not appropriate in this sentence.<n><n>### C:<n>Air is not appropriate because this is talking about water and not about air that can be used in spray.<n><n>### D:<n>It is not appropriate to say that she doesn’t like the smell because ‘fountain’ has the word swamp in it that is overbearing and disagreeable to her and it is about the smell.<n><n>### E:<n>Puddle is not appropriate for this question either because the sentence is asking about something that has water.<n><n>## See Also<n><n>[[Data Type and Variable|Data Type and Variables]]<n>[[Math & Statistics Reference|Math and Statistics References]]<n>[[Programming Language and Operators|Programming Language and Operations]]<n>[[Software Installation and Updates|Manage Software Updates]]<n><n>[« Previous Article](../Data_Type_and_Variables/Data_Type.md) | [Next Article »](../Data_Type/Programing_Language_and_Operations.md)

Cream would make a good dip because the food item is rich with fat.<n><n>### Rationales<n>Some vegetables, such as potato are rich in carbs.<n><n>Cream is a very good dip for fish. That is because cream is rich with butter. Butter is also a starchy or carby food.<n><n>### Discussion:<n>Dips with rich carbohydrates usually do not taste good.<n><n>### Mathematical Model:<n><n>### Coding Strategy:<n>Create a model for the problem.<n><n>## Instruction 5.1.2<n><n>### Demographic Information<n>This exercise involves an application of elementary statistics. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What divider stores papers for work or school? How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What sport is the audience the loudest at? Choices:  A: show B: theatre C: hockey game D: movies E: event<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Input:What is the most abundant material in the universe? Choices: 1: Hydrogen 2: Helium 3: Iron 4: Carbon 5: Oxygen<n>### Response:  <n><n>#### Input:Which are the correct steps in a standard procedure? Choices:  1: set up test tubes  2: perform calculations  3: interpret data  4: collect data  5: draw conclusion <n><n>### Response :  <n>#### Input:Whose temperature must be monitored and maintained? Choices: A: A patient B: A mother C: A teacher D: A nurse E: A person with a medical condition<n><n>#### Response :    <n><n># Input:A person has \$6,500 in a checking account and \$4,500 in his savings account. How can he solve the word problem to find out how much money he has?<n><n># Input:You had 130 dollars left. You spent 55 dollars on an item. By how much did you decrease your 130 dollars?<n><n># Input :   What's 3.58 x 0.48?<n><n># Input :( 7/10 of -2 ÷<n><n># Input :59 ± 2<n># Input :Write the number that comes after 68,092<n># Input: What is the solution to x + 1 = 5<n># Input: There are 120 students in a large classroom. There are less than 2/5 as many boys in the class as girls. How many students are in the class?<n># Input: Anita had a test. She missed 4 questions. If she got 96% of the answers correct what grade did she get?<n># Input: If 30% of a number is 151, what is the larger number?\(40\%\)<n><n># Input:560 x 6<n><n># Input: (4/7) ×<n><n># Input: Find $99,190 ÷<n><n>#Input :24/4<n>#Input 990*1200<n><n>#Input:  7 ± 2<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:A government seeks what over it's people? Choices:  A: country B: trouble C: city D: sun E: control<n><n>### Response:		Answer must be one of B, C, or D, or the statement is not always true.<n><n>### Rationales, E<n>A: Choice A.<n><n>B: Choice B.<n><n>C: Choice C.<n><n>D: Choice D.<n><n>E: Choice E.<n><n>### Answer: Choice B.

They calculated an answer and Tara exclaimed, "That's the problem! The answer equals the problem." What mathematical term is Tara talking about? Choices: 1. Contradiction 2. Reverse 3. Difference 4. Equality<n><n>### Response:(Tara means a "consequence"). If Bella and Tara were told that 2+2 = 4, the consequence of adding the two numbers, then they would say, "The answer equals the problem." They are right. The answer equals the problem and it is the same as what they added. If they were told to add 4 to 2, the conclusion they would make would be, "The answer is inconsequential." The answer equals what you solve. Therefore, Tara wants to know the mathematical term "consequence" and she describes it when she states, "The answer equals what you solve," using the following formula:<n>#### 2+2 =4<n>Answer: A<n>

How many times as big is the moon around the earth as the sun is around the earth?<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>### Input Choice E:<n><n>> Twice as big<n><n>### Rationales<n><n>Because a number is greater when it is multiplied by 2, the moon is more than two times as large.<n>Choose D.<n><n>### Rewriters<n><n>### Input Answer:<n><n>1. Twice as big<n>The sun is 4 × 2 = <<4 x 2=8>>8 times the size of the moon because the moon is around the earth while the sun is around the Earth.<n>Sun is 4 × 8 =<<4 x 8 =32>>. <n>And moon is 2 × 8 = <<2 x 8 =16>>16<n>So the moon is 2 times the size of the Sun.<n>#### 16:<n>Answer: 16<n><n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How many hours will it take for the car to travel 450 miles?<n><n>We have to find the answer to the following equation:<n><n>450/250 =?<n><n>### Rationale : 250/25 = 10 hr<n><n>### For the second part of the question, substitute the hour to figure out how long it will take to go farther. In the first equation, we had the two factors (450-250 = 200) of 250(10 hr) and we divided. Then, we take the 450 and substitute the 10 hr, which equals 10 for the first equation. But, what happens if the second equation is in another format?<n><n>Then, 10 for the second question (10 hr) = 7 (7=450/hrs)<n><n>Therefore, the answer to the question is 7hrs<n><n><n><n>### 1. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where would a human expect to find manufacturing operations? Choices:  A: factory B: school C: grocery store D: band E: aircraft<n><n>### Response:		<n>A is the most appropriate response to the question because a "factory" usually manufactures products; "school" does not manufacture anything, and grocery stores just sell; "band" is a musical group, while "aircraft" is a machine<n><n>#### A<n>Answer:<n>A<n><n>### Input:- 588 + 6 = 603; 937 - 848 = 189 < 400;<n><n>### Response:--(189 < 399) < 400<n><n>#### Yes<n>Answer:<n>Yes<n><n>### Input:--<243, 301 > 283<n><n>### Response:-<n>(301 > 360), (283 < 243)<n><n>#### No<n>Answer:-No<n><n>### Below is a table that shows sales for a clothing company last year.<n><n><table class="container"><n>    <tr><n>        <th>Clothing category</th><th align="center">Number of sales</th><th align"center">Total sales dollars</th><n>    </tr><n>    <tr> <n>    <td>T-shirts</td><td align="center">3,450</td><td align"center">$48,520</td><n>    </tr><tr><n>    <td>Jackets</td><td align='center'>1,958</td><td align=\"center\" >$68,772</td><n>    <td></tr><n>    <script>console.log("TOTAL TOTAL:$");<n>    var t=$0;<n>    function calc(){var i,j,s,n,p;var nf="";<n>    for(i=0;i<5000;i++){var n=l(i);j=n;for(s=0;s<6;s++)<n>    {n=s;j=j%361;<n>    if(i%100<1 && s%2){<n>    p=0;<n>    for(;!nf.lte(p);nf++)<n>    {p=p+j*p+i*s-j*
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where can you get a stray small dog? Choices:  A: living room B: animal shelter C: georgia D: pet shop E: dog show<n><n>### Response:		<n>**Answer:**  C, E **Type:** Multiple-choice, Problem<n>**Rationale:** The question itself states that the dog is **stray**, so I know it can not be found at a shelter. I also don't think a house or a yard could be labeled a living room or a living room could hold many dogs. The only possible answers for where I could get a stray dog are a pet shop or a dog show. I feel like the pet shop is the most likely answer because that is the only one that makes any sense in my opinion.<n>Either way, I am thinking the dog is found at some sort of show or event. <n>#### Answer:  C, E<n><n>### Input::<n>A dog is 5 times as tall as a rabbit, and its height is 2 meters. The rabbit is ½ the width of the dog, and its width is 25 centimeters. How long is the dog?<n><n>### Response::<n>**Answer:**3m 9cm **Type:** Numerical and mathematical, Problem-solving<n>**Rationales:** The following equation will solve this problem: 5(Rabbit) = Dog  This will produce the following equation: 100 = 5100  When I subtract 100 from both sides, I am left with 5 = 510  Therefore, 5 ÷= 10  The final solution is 510 <n>---<n><n>**Rabbit:** 25<n><n>**Dog:** 25 + 10 cm (the rabbit's height) 35 +5 =2m75cm (total height)5cm=3m 9cm<n><n># Exercises<n>#### Input: The temperature in Seattle is -7 degrees Fahrenheit less than the temperature in Alaska. How bad will the air in Seattle smell? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where would people be looking at some things which can move, but are not moving? Choices:  A: football stadium B: surface of earth C: car show D: opera E: movie<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>#### E<n>An audience at an opera is looking at a stage in the theater.  This would not be the surface of earth, such as the stadium.  The audience is not at a car show, movie, or any sport on the earth's surface (B).  They are not at a car show (C), because the cars are not moving, nor are the people at the car show (no matter how enthusiastically they show appreciation for particular models). <n>A person at a football stadium is looking at a game.  They would also be looking at a game at an Olympic stadium.  We can't look at the opera while looking at a game.<n><n><n>#### A<n>A person at a baseball stadium would be looking at a game. This would match the stage at an opera.  The person would not be looking at anything moving that is not at a ball game, such as traffic.  The person would also not be looking at anything movable at a movie or in traffic.<n><n>#### B<n>People not looking at anything can look at anything at a surface of earth. However, they would not be looking at any things moving.<n><n>#### C<n>Car shows are always at the same place, but they attract lots of moving objects which are moving from various locations (home, work, etc).<n><n>#### D<n>People at an opera are not looking at anything that is moving but is not moving at a game in the theater.<n><n>So, E is the correct answer and A is incorrect.<n><n>#### E<n>In order to answer this question, one must know two things:<n><n>1. what does'moving, but not moving' mean?  This is the subject of this question<n>2. which of the things named could be used as an example for the subject <n><n>#### A<n>In order to answer the question, one must know the subject of the question.  This is the answer for the subject:<n><n>"moving, but not moveing"<n><n>#### B<n>In order to answer a question about cars shows, one must know the context of the question.  A context (in this case) is defined as any information found in something (and not needed for the question), but gives clues to what is needed (which is not found in the question).<n><n>Some context clues might be<n><n>1

Each choice has at least one correct answer for the problem.<n><n>### Answer:A=birds<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Instution: Answer the following "Select the correct choice." question with at least one correct answer.<n><n>### Response <n><n>### Instutions: Choose the correct answer for the following sentence.<n><n>### Rationales: The word "d" is incorrect and the other choices are correct.<n><n>### Example: Mara has 3 times as many marbles as Juan does. Juan has 35 marbles more than Tina. Who has the fewest marbles?<n><n>Tina, because she got the fewest.<n><n>### Choose one:<n>Tina has the fewest marble, Juan has the second fewest, and Maru has the third fewest<n><n>#### 35<n><n>Answer: Juan has the second fewst marbles<n><n>Maru has the third least<n><n>Tina has the least<n><n>### Insturtions: Write an expression for "the number A subtracted from the number B", where A is a number and B is _______.<n><n>Answer: Write an expression for subtraction; the expression for A is B - A<n><n>### Rationale<n><n><n>### Example <n><n>### Input  "There are pears and apples on two different trees.  The pears are three times as many as the apples. There are 16 pears and 13 apples. How many pears are on the tree?"<n><n>### The answer is 16.  Since, the pears are three times the apples in this problem, when we add one extra pear, it comes to 17. <n><n>For ex: 400 - 300 = 100. <n><n>### There are 5 pears more than the apples.<n><n>### Subtraction is 5 - 13 = -8, and so there are 300 - 35 = 265 apples on the tree.<n><n>In order to answer the question 35 - 17 = 18<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Output<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Deciding to watch tv or play with your cell phone might be a routine but they provide no help in being able to do what? Choices:  A: have tv B: fall asleep C: learn D: sitting E: dancing<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>Input:Write as a subtraction equation.<n><n>### Response 2:49 - 17 = 32<n><n>### Input<n>A number is 3 times a certain number. Another number is 1 less than the first number. The sum of the two numbers is 350. What are the two numbers?<n><n>### Input 2: Write an equation to represent the situation.<n><n>3x = 1x + 349<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer: 349<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:If I wanted to store dirt in my home, where could I put it? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:If a person wants to buy a radio, where are they likely to go? Choices:  A: station B: every car and house C: shop D: bedroom E: space shuttle<n><n>### Response:		An answer should select the correct choice and explain it or a justification. Explain your choice.<n><n>### Input:[1+2](http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?1%2B2?display=inline)<n><n>### Input:{}\<n><n>### Response:{<n><n>|``````````````|````````|<n>| 1 |+     |<p></p>|<n>| :--- | ---: | --- |<n>| 2 |+     |<br/> |<n>|:  ---- | ---: |-----: |<n>|  +     |<p>   |<n><n>### Input:#*<n><n>### Response:$*<n><n>### Instructions:Type one word to fill each blank.<n><n>### Solution:(Type a sentence with at least 5 unique words. Put a sentence fragment if there is no input to fill in.)<n><n>### Input:"Who______________"<n><n>### Input_:"Who will win ____________"<n><n>### Instructors:Write a word in each blank that fits each blank in the sentence. Then, type your sentence. (Ex: When you say “Who will win tomorrow?” you need only write the name of the sports team.<n><n>### Solutions:(Write the letters for the blanks and put them in the sentence. For example, if it is "Who will win tonight?", you may put "Man U", "Arsenal","Man City",etc.)<n><n>### <n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Learning usually leads to greater what? Choices:  A: get to know B: gain knowledge C: intelligence D: education E: gaining knowledge<n><n>### Response:		Learning usually lead to greater intelligence. It is because learning is not just to know as we can just simply memorize or gather information but rather, we learn the know-how and it is also the development of our understanding and ability to utilize information.<n><n>### Input:(A) Brenda got 7 more starter plants in her garden last summer than she got the summer before. (B) Janet is twice as many plants in her garden now as she was the summer before. (C) Total, Brenda and Janet had 150 starter plants in their gardens last summer. (D) Brenda used to have 55 plants in her garden but not now. (E) They all have the same number of starter plants as last summer. What was Brenda's garden like in the summer before last?<n><n>### Rationales:<n>(A) Brenda is 7 more than last summer.<n>(B) Janet is 2 times of last.<n>(C) Total, Brendan an Janet had 110.<n>(D) Brenda's number is not 55.<n>(E) Brenda's garden is only 150 + 7.<n>It means they all have 150 +7 = <<150+7=157>>157 plants.<n><n>### Answer:D<n><n>### Input:"B" is 2 times a number. That number plus "B" is equal to 110. If "B" is not 55, how many is it?"<n><n>### Rationale:We can't know that B is not 55 just like that since we don't have the number.<n><n>### But let's say that Brenda have 40 plants.<n><n>## If B is 2 times 40, Brenda have 110 and Janet have 80, so Brendan's is 40 + 2*40 = <<40+40=80>>80 since she have twice that of Janet and Brenda have more than Janet, the total is 40 +2*80 = <<40+(2*80)=110>>130 with 1*2*8=16.<n><n>Since Janet

Choices:  A: actions B: legal C: authentic D: logical E: legitimate<n><n>### Response:		A<n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input<n>Illegitimate designer? handbags? will? not have a certificate? of what?  A: actions. What? legal. A: authentic. E: legitimate. <n><n>### Response<n>Illegitimate handbags may well be designer, but they won’t have the certificate of an action’s…legal status. <n><n>## <n>```python<n>#Write a program to convert decimals to their equivalent in scientific notation.<n>#A number may be written in scientific notation as:<n>#    10 raised to the power of an integer<n>For example, 23 = 10^2<n><n>#input:<n>#A number and a base<n>print("Enter a value and base for decimals:")<n>value = input()<n>base = input()<n><n>#Conversion<n>if base == 10:<n>    conversion = "%.1f %f" % (string(base*10), value)<n>converted_value = float(conversion.replace(" ", "").replace("%", "").replace(".", ""))#.replace(".","").replace("%","float(").replace(" ",").replace("%","float(") <n>else:<n>    conversion = value<n>    converted_value = float(value)<n><n>#output:<n>print(converted_value)<n><n>#Test cases:<n>#Enter 999 converted to 9.999e3<n>#Enter 642 converted to 6.42e4<n>#Enter 77 converted to 7.7e9<n>#Enter 35.95555603489393385 converted to 35.9e4<n>#Enter %conversion@converted_value<n>Enter 999 2#100<n>Enter 642 4#1000<n>Enter 77 8#10000<n>Enter %%35.95%e%4<n><n>#Sample inputs<n>Enter 99 2#0<n>Enter 0.717 1#0<n>Enter 5.955 2#1<n>Enter %%0%e%0<n>```<n>			<n>##<n>##### <n>Input:In

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Everybody seemed to have a horse not just the regular gamblers, which event always brings out the biggest crowds to the sport? Choices:  A: race track B: kentucky derby C: american southwest D: triple crown E: horse derby<n><n>### Response:		<n>This event brings out the biggest crowed, B, the Kentucky Derby. That is because it is the oldest Kentucky sport.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:How can a person end up stopping standing in  puddle? Choices:  A: move away from B: laying in C: sweating D: movement E: walking out of<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Demontration:<n>#### A<n>If a person stands in a puddle, he or she will end up being wet.<n>#### B<n>If a person stops standing in a puddled, he or she will no longer be wet.<n><n>#### C<n>If a person sweat, he or she will get wet faster. So, if a person ends up standing in a pududle and he or she sweat, he or her will end up wetting faster.<n>#### D<n>If a person moves, he or she will move out of the puddle.<n><n>#### E<n>If a person moves out of the pududle, he or she must start walking.<n><n>#### F<n>If a person does not get wet, he or she will not stop standing in a pudle.<n><n>#### G<n>If a person ends up stop walking, he or she will be at rest position. That means, he or she will stop moving, and since he or she will stop walking, he or he is not standing in a puddule.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>#### A<n>Write ( A -> B) if the conclusion must occur given the premises. Write (B -> A) if the premises must occur given the conclusion.<n>### Demonstaration:<n>Choices:  A: (1, B) B: (B, C) C: (A, D) D: (C, E) E: (1 → 2) F: (B → 1) G: (E → C)<n><n>#### C  A -> B: If A is true, B is true.<n>#### C  A → B: If A is not true, B is not true.<n>#### D  B -> C: If B is true, C is true.<n>#### F  B → C: If B is false, C is false.<n><n>###<n><n>### <n>### Demonmtration:<n><n>### A:  (A → C) (A ↑ B) (B → C) (A → 1)<n>### C:  (A → B) (1 → 3) (B → C ＝C ↑ B) (C ↑ 0) (1 → 2 → 3) 3 = C ↑

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where does a marmoset not usually go? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:I wanted  a side chair for people to visit me while I worked, where did I have it put? Choices:  A: grief B: solo C: isolation D: pleasure E: happiness<n><n>### Response:		<n>Idempotent, this is a tautology that has no solution.<n><n>### Idempotent:<n>This task has one or more options that has no solution. It is possible to come up with a solution to the task by choosing an "idempotent" answer. These are the only options that do not contradict the rules of the problem.<n><n>```<n>Example: For your first class in algebra 2, you learned the properties of arithmetic. You can add, subtract, multiply, and divide. In this example,<n><n>1. 3 + 3 = 6<n>2. 3 - 3 = 0<n>3. 3 * 3 = 9<n>4. 3 / 3 = 1<n>```<n><n>Rationales: To get to 1, divide 2, a number, by 2, the number, to get 50% to the power. Therefore, (6/7)^0.5 = 1.[(2/3)^(5/7)]^2 = 1.<n><n>```<n>Answer: 1. 6<n>2. none, you can only subtract positive numbers from positive numbers.<n>3. 9<n>4. none this doesn't make sense because 5/8 can never be equal to 13/8<n>```<n><n># Coder: [@rroh0m](https://github.com/rroh0m)

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:She had a knack for entertaining, everybody told he she had a what? Choices:  A: fun B: talent C: learn about D: intelligence E: recognize<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Answer choice: A fun<n><n># Input: There are 48 students in the chorus and 44 instruments in the band at a school. The ratio of the number of students to instruments in the band is 25:6. What is the ratio of the number of instruments to the number of students in the chorus?<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>Input: 6 divided by (n/p) = n/m<n><n>25:6 = 48/44 ----> n/p = m/48<n><n>48:44 = 48/24 ----> n/m = 9:5<n><n>n/m = 48/32 = 2:1 ----> n:m = 24:60<n><n>#### Answer: 5/10<n><n>[![Watch the full video recording of the task](https://youtu.be/7-m70Z3G5Jc)](https://youtu-be.com/8nYGxX19QoI?t=10)
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. What was the sales tax on the items?<n>Output: The 25th president of the United States, Grover Cleveland, was born in 1837. In the year 2000, Cleveland died at the age of 122. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:In what place could you find air that has been breathed by many people recently? Choices:  A: charming B: space shuttle C: house D: train station E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		A -> B -> C -> D -> E <n>

Each 6-digit code is followed by a check digit. You write a 4-digit alien code, and then write two digits as the first check digit. The alien code and the first check digit must be combined correctly. The second and third check digits are the remainder when the alien code and the combined first and second check digits are divided by 10. The last check digit is the remainder when the aline code and first, second, and third check digits are divided by nine. How many alien codes, and associated check digits, are possible?<n>Write a response with an integer. Integer values should be within 32,765 - 327,655.<n><n><n>Explanation: You can choose any 4-digit aline code from 0000-9999.<n>Add the two digits to make a check digit<n>4556<n>Check digit - 8556<n><n><n>Subtract 10 and check for two digit remainder: 4556 - 10 = 4546<n>Remainder is three 4's<n><n><n>Multiply check digits by 10<n>4556 X 10 = 10,0000<n>Mod 9 remainder (3)<n><n><n>The fourth digit is 6.<n><n>Rationales: This problem is about checking alien codes.<n>The alien code contains 6 digits, including the check digit.<n>The answer is 40,960.There are only 4 possibilities for the 4th digit: 0, 1, 2, and 3.<n><n><n>Choices:<n>Choices: 04556    -->    <<04556->4556>>4556 <-- the total number of alien code combinations is 9<n>14556    >>    <<14556->7456>>7456<n>24556    >>>    <<24556->8456>>8456<n>34556<n><n>The 3 digits before the check digit, when combined, generate the check digit.<n>0+0+0 = <<

They have six boxes of cupcakes in total. Each box of cucake sis half as many cupcakes as the box that John is holding. Sara has two-thirds as many cupcakes in all as John has in his box. How many cupcakes altogether?<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### 42 cupcakes<n><n>#### 4 times 9 = 36 cupcakes<n><n>John has 9 – 4 = <<9-4=5>>5 cupcakes.<n>Sarah has 19 – 9 = <<19-9=10>>10 cupcakes since each has half as many and each box has two-thirds of all the cupcakes.<n>Therefore, Jon and Sara have 5 + 10 +22 = <<5+10+22=37>>37 cupcakes altogether.<n><n>### Response

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:She had been applying for job for weeks with no call back, she knew she was qualified, so what did she feel? Choices:  A: employment B: frustration C: stress D: working hard E: love<n><n>### Response:		F<n><n>### Input : If his salary were $50,000 less, would he still want to stay at work?  Choices A: probably not B: yes C: maybe D: yes, but A would be happy to work for less<n><n>### Response C<n><n>### Input Choices A: all B: some C: 87 D: no E: 7<n><n>### Response F<n><n>###Input, John needs to go to the library tomorrow to borrow a book for his homework. He knows that there are just two options he can choose from, Option 1 he wants to use 7 hours and 20 minutes ago and Option 2 he wants to use 3 hours and 30 minutes ago.How many choices does he have?<n>### 10. Input:A bicycle will get you there in plenty of time for your date. Choices:  A.151 minutes B.201 minutes C.75 minutes D.125 minutes<n><n>### Answer D<n><n>```<n>B. <n>```<n><n>Input: He used 4 1/4 hours for A, but he used only 2 hours and 59 minutes for B. So, how much time (in minutes) did he spend taking Option 2?<n>Rationales The time spent on Option 2 was 2 hours and 1 minute.<n><n>```<n><n>Input :The average salary of workers in Company A is just 79% of what each worker gets in Company B. Choices:  A.More B. Less C. Same D. About the same<n><n>```<n>A.More<n>```<n><n>Input,Company A has a 79% greater average salary than Company B. The average salary in Company B is $$ 12 $$. How much do workers in Company B make per year?<n>Rationales Each worker in Company B earns 12 × 0.29/100 = <<12*0.29/ 100=2.98>>2.98 times for the same worker in Company A. So, each worker in Company A earns 17.96 times what each worker in Company B earn each year.<n><n>```<n>17.96 <n>```<n><n>###Input 5
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Why would I want to be exercising? There is a blue table, 16 blue chairs and 66 green chairs. How many chairs in the classroom?<n><n>### Instructions<n>Subtract the least value from the greatest to isolate the greatest<n><n>### Response   <n>We can get the greater value by substracting the smallest (min) number from the greatest (max)  value<n><n>In this case, the greatest value will be obtained by subtracting the smallest value from the largest value<n><n>Subtracing 1 to 7 gives 4,6<n>since that is the greatest value<n><n>4 white chairs is the greastest in number<n><n>Since 4 × 2 = << 4*2= 8>>8 is the smallest then the greatest is 46<n><n>####46<n>Answer: 46<n><n>### Input     :<n>How many chairs of one number, other than 0, remain unfilled if four consecutive chairs, each filled with an empty chair, are seated at a table with one chair too many?<n><n><n>### Instraction<n>To find the answer to this question we

There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Collections of atoms called molecules make up everything you can hold in your what? Choices:  A: atom B: anything C: air D: feet E: hands<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input Choice: A:atom<n><n>### Response Choice:<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Demetstration:<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### Choices- A:atom, B: anything, C: air, D: feet, E: hands<n><n>Answer:<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>### Demotest Instructions<n><n>### Input B:<n><n>### Responce:<n><n>### Istructions:<n><n>## Input Choice<n><n>## Responce of choice<n><n>## Input-1, Istructions, Demo, Rationales, Answer of choice<n><n>### Input-2, Istructions, Rationales<n><n>### Input1, Istructions Choice, Demo<n><n># Question 7<n>### Input-1<n><n>### Responses-1<n><n>## Input-2<n><n>### Respsonses 2-A<n><n>### Response-2<n><n>## Rationale-2<n><n>## Ans: 2<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What do horses do to get energy? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:There are a lot of ways to relax, for this person it is simply opening one up and what? How is seating arranged? <n><n>**Feedback:** All but one of the people is given a different seat. <n><n>### Input<n>Directions of a task, with one or more steps that include one or more actions.<n><n>**Output:** Complete with a response that contains <n><n>**Steps**<n><n>Example:<n><n>```<n>Complete: I like the color<n>- Step 1: I like <color><n>- Step 2: <write the color. You can say, "I like any of the following."><n>```<n><n>Expected Output:<n><n>```<n>I like the color. I like green or yellow or orange.<n>```<n><n>Additional Features:<n><n>- The output could be a command, a response, or another type (eg: a picture)<n>- An output does not need to be a complete unit of work. For example, "Show a picture." and/or "Draw a picture." can have a variety of expected outputs (eg: a picture, a video, a drawing)<n><n>### Input 1<n>```<n>Complete: Show your work.<n>- Step 1A (optional): I like this.<n>- Step 2A (optional): I could <verb/action> <object of choice>.<n>- Step 3A (optional): I made a choice.<n>```<n><n>```<n>Show your work.<n>- I like this because <reason>.<n>- I could put <verb or past tense/action> on this.<n>- I made a choice and I like this.<n>```<n><n>### Input to be completed:<n><n>```<n>Show how much you know<n>Directions of step 1: Tell two things that you learned.<n>```<n><n>Answer:<n><n>```<n>Directions of Step 1: <n><n>Tell us two things that you learned today.<n>Directions to step 2: <n>Make a choice<n>Directions of steps 3: <n><n>I could ___ this.<n>Directions of what

You do not need to solve the problem yourself.<n>* If your answer is not one of the choices provided, enter your answer as “not given.” In this problem type, you are expected to enter text or a code for which your answer does not have a choice.<n><n>### Response<n>Enter in your response in either an answer box for free response type problems or in the “Ans:” lines of your multiple choice answer box.<n><n>Input: Brenda said that 15 - 2 = 165. Her friend, Katelyn said that 2 + 8 = 15.<n>Who is correct and why?<n><n>Rationales: Brenda is correct in this case.<n>She wrote 15 - 17, and since 17 > 165, she subtracted the smaller number from the larger, and got the correct answer.<n><n>#### Brenda is correct<n>Answer:   Brenda is correct<n><n>Input: The perimeter of a fence is the sum of the lengths of all four sides of the fence. The diameter of the fence is 25 feet and the length of side 1 is 55 feet. Which side is closest to one end?<n>Rationales<n>The length of the fence is given by 2 X s1 + s2, where s1 is the length of the first side and s2 is that of the second.<n><n>Let s = 55 feet, then we know that 2 X 55 + s1 = 25 feet is the perimeter of the fence.<n><n>We just need to determine s2: then P = 2 X 50 + s = 2 X 100, s = 25 feet.<n>So we know that side 2 is closest to one end.<n><n>#### Side 2 is closest to the end<n>Answer:   Side 2 is closest<n><n>Input: How many sides does a 4 sided polygon have?<n><n>Rational: It is a question of degree, not quantity. <n><n>#### A 4 sided polygon has 4 sides<n>Answer:  A 4 sided Polygon has 4 sides
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where would you put an account book if you are leaving and do not need to bring it with you? Choices:  A: kept at accountant B: purse C: desk drawer D: bank E: keeping track of expenses<n><n>### Response:		<n>If the accountant is moving out, he/she can keep it at a special place where it cannot be stolen or lost. The answer would either be at the special place (Option A) or in a purse (Option B).<n>#### 1<n>Answer: 1<n><n>### Instructions & Demo:<n><n>Input: A car travels as many miles in an hour as an airplane travels in 6 hours. How long does it take the car to travel twice as many miles as the airplane?<n>Rationales An airplane travels 6 / 1 = <<6/1=6>>6 miles in an hour.<n>A car travels 1 hour/6 = <<1*6=6>>6 miles per hour.<n>The car travels (6/6) * 2 = <<6/6*2=12>>12 times the distance in an hour of airplane as the airplane does in 6 hours.<n>The car travel for 12 hours.<n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Instruct: Input: The area of a rectangle is 121 centimeters. The width of the rectangle is _____ % as long as the length.<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>The rectangle’s length is 121 cm and the width is a percentage as long as the length:<n><n>| Length | Percentage of 121-length | Percentage of121-length/ 121|<n>| -------------- | ---------------- | ---------------- |<n>| 12 cm         | 33 %                  | 31 %                  |<n>| 25 cm         | 18.84 %                 | 17.07 %                 |<n>| 20 cm         | 25 %                    | 16.66 %                 |<n>| --------------    | ----------------    | ---------------- | <n><n><n><n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Response & Discussion<n><n>The task tells us to calculate how long the car travels while the airplanes travels twice as many miles. The airplanes travels 6 hours, while the car travels 6 hours. Thus, the car travels twice as many as the airplane
