Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What is a place that someone can go buy a teddy bear? Choices:  A: thrift store B: bed C: shelf D: home E: toy store<n><n>### Response:		If the option that the student selects is A or B, write "no." If the option that the student<n>selects is C or D, write "yes." If the option that a student selects is not listed, write "invalid."<n><n>#### Response:<n>A<n><n>B<n><n>C<n><n>D<n><n>E<n><n>### Input<n>-What is the next number in the sequence? Choices A: 30,17,27,8,13,23<n><n>B: 3<n><n>C: 28<n><n>#### Response<n><n>A<n><n>B:<n><n>C: <n><n>#### Answer<n>29<n><n>### A set of 3 consecutive integers has a sum of 97. Which expression is equivalent to 24,5,20,15,7?<n><n>- 8x + 2y - 3z<n><n>-x+3<n>-x-3<n><n>-y+7<n>-y+2<n><n>A:<n><n>B:<n>C:<n><n>D:<n><n>I will be more detailed, and provide screenshots of the answers at the end.<n><n>## Answer A<n><n>**What is the next number from this series:**   <n>Answer<n><n>3, 32, 31, 73, 92, 83, 73,,.....<n><n>Answer<n><n>**What math operation would add or subtract 30 from a number?**<n><n>A) Add 11 to the number<n><n>B) Subtract 11 from the number<n><n>Answer<n><n>A)

There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What do you do to hold loose papers together? Choices:  A: tighten B: packaged C: bound D: faithful E: compact<n><n>### Response:		The correct choice is D, Faithful, which means firm and loyal.<n><n>### Explanation:If a paper is tightly bound to another piece of paper, then it's held together firmly.<n><n>### Input : Choose True or False. <n><n>### Which word begins the sentence about a dog that follows two people with a leash and is followed by another dog on a leash? <n>- [ ] dog <n>- [ ] man <n>- [ ] leash <n>- [ ] another<n>- [ ] dog<n>- [ ] begins<n>- [ ] sentence <n>- [ ] two <n>- [ ] follows<n><n>### Explation:<n>- [x] The word Dogs appears in the subject position.<n>- [x] There's a verb to be (is), which is a sentence modifier.<n>- [x ] A prepositional phrase appears, which is used to locate the dog.<n>- [x   ] There are two nouns (man and another dog) in the predicate position.<n>- [ ] False. <n>- [ ] The word leash occurs in the subject position and is the first word in the sentence.<n>- [ ] Two verbs (follows and is) is used in the predicate position.

There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:If I have a reception with many people attending, where should I be sure to hold it? Choices:  A: grand casino B: large room C: restaurant D: country club E: lobby<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Choices: A, B, or C<n><n>### Explanation:<n>This is a multiple choice question as well as a free response question. Here, the user can pick one or more of the provided choices only or from the options provided.<n><n>### Input :You must remember that there is more then one book in a library. One day you visited a library and found one book from one of the shelves. The book was in a position that was different from the other books. So you knew that book was the only one of its kind. How did you know that the book in a bookshelf was also in the library? Choices:  I knew it was in a bookshelf  I knew that the book was different from the other<n><n>### Response<n><n>Choices: I knew it was on a bookshelf  or I knew that the book in the bookshelf was alsoin the library because it was also in the bookshelf.<n><n>### Exlanation:<n>Similar to free response questions, multiple choice questions can use negation of correct answers so as to provide the student with the right answer.<n><n>###  Input:  One day I called up Sam to tell him I was coming to see him that way he<n>    wouldn't be surprised when I got there. I just called him to tell him I was<n>    coming to see him without actually saying I am coming to see him. What must<n>    I have done to accomplish this? Choices:  said one day he will make my birthday party<n>    invite myself over without saying I was coming to see Sam<n><n>    Answer:<n>    I called up Sam to say just came to see him.<n><n>### Answer: In this question the student asked to choose a response from the options provided or from the options provided, but in the same line. This can only happen if the question is given in correct format.<n><n>### Note:<n>When constructing free response and multiple choice questions, you should make sure that the given question makes the student choose or write the correct answer from the choices provided.<n><n>## See also<n><n>* SAT<n>* ACT<n>* TOEFL<n>* IELTS<n>* CELPIP<n>* AST

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What past time are people engaged in when they are traveling along liquid? How many seconds later do you find him?<n>- A rectangular garden has sides that are in proportion to the side lengths of a square with a diagonal of 8 ft. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Bill was awaking, what was happening to him physiologically? Choices:  A: tiredness B: grogginess C: discomfort D: getting out of bed E: eyes opening<n><n>### Response:		<n>* A: Tiredness<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the questions that follow.<n><n>### A: Which of the following best describes how Bill is feeling?<n><n>### B: Getting tired<n><n>### C: Being up in spirit<n><n>### D: Eyes getting awake<n><n>### E: Being restless<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### A : Tiredness<n><n><n>### Input : A person is using the ratio to show how much 6 malt liquor beverages are more than 7 malt liquor beverage. Which of the following best demonstrates the correct ratio?<n>Choices : A: 6:7 B: 3:2  C 1 : <<2>>2 D : <<6/7>>½  E : <<3/2>>½<n><n>### Answer<n><n>### A <n><n>### Instructtion :What is 1 less than the quotient 7 ÷ 2?<n><n>### Answer : 5<n><n><img src="./images/Quiz.png" alt="quiz" height="300"/><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. Then add those totals and subtract that total from 7.<n><n>### Response:(10, 11) 7<n>Choose a starting value of 1.<n>```<n>[1,2,3,4,5]<n>```<n>Pick 2 numbers = 1 and 2<n>Adding 1 and 2 = 3.<n>Subtracting 1 and 1 = 0.<n>Adding 3 and 3 = 6.<n>Subtract 6 from 7 = -1<n><n><n>#### A<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many hours should the train travel to go the same distance as the plane?<n><n>### Choice A: 6 hours<n><n>### Choices: Three students walked seven blocks in a straight line. Each student walked one-half the distance that the student behind him walked. In how many pairs of shoes did they share their route?<n><n>### Rational:<n>Two students walk one-half of the distance from the same point.  The third student follows the two students.  So, three students share the same route because they start from the same point.<n><n>### Answer choice: 4<n><n>### Input The value of one shoe is 4/5 of the value of two pairs of shoes.  What is the value of two pairs?<n><n>### Solution:<n>The value of one shoe = 4/5 of 2 shoes.  Therefore, the value of 2 shoes = (4/5) × 2 = 2<n><n>The value of 2 pairs is the sum of the values of the shoes:  2 shoes + 2 shoes   =  4 + 4 =  8.<n><n>### Choose the correct answer.<n>4 + 4 <n><n>### Input Five pairs of shoes cost $27 more than a pair of shoes.  How much does a pair of shoes cost?<n><n>### Option B<n><n>### Input Six pairs of jeans cost thirty eight dollars.  A pair of long

There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What type of person typically contracts illness? C: Sick person is infected.<n><n>### Input : How many times more is 42 than than 14?<n><n>### Response : This is correct. 42 =4 x 9<n>14 =1 x 14 42>14. 42 is times more than 14.<n><n>###<n># Below is an instruction that explains a task. Write a complete program for the given scenario.<n><n>### **Instruction:** Find the difference between the age in years, months, and days. <n>### **Demonstration:** The number of months is < 2 + 2 = << 2+2=4>>4. There are no two days.< 4 > < 1 + 2 = <<1+2=3>>3. There are two days. So there is months and days. In the final answer there will be only age years with a number. < 5 + 2 = <<5+2=7>>7. 7 > < 5 + 1 = <<5+1=6>>6. There are six days. The number of months and days will not be displayed.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Which entrance would you use if you do not want to use the back entrance? Choices:  A: side B: main C: anterior D: current E: front<n><n>### Response:		<n>A or b<n><n>### Rationale:<n>b or A<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: The sum of 1/4 + 1/7 is<n>Rationales: 1/4 +1/7=<n>#### 14/49<n>Answer: 14/4<n><n>### Input : Find the missing number : 3 1 8 5 13<n><n>### Response :<n>5<n><n>### Rationales :<n>4x4 + 4x3 + 4x2 + 4x1 + (3-4) = 5 => 5<n><n>### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Inputs:How many bunnies are in the clowns' petting zoo? Choices: A: fewer than 8 B: 8 or more C: Fewer than 4 D: 12 or more<n><n>### Response Option A<n>#### fewer than 8 bunnies<n><n>### Options:Fewer than 8 bunnys in the petting zoo<n><n>### Racionales:<n><n>8÷2 = 4<n>12÷2 = 6<n><n>####4<n>Answer:4<n><n>### Demstration:<n>Input : A bus stop is at the top of the hill, at the bottom of the hill is the station. How high is the hill?Choices :a: 1/10 b: 1/5 c: 1/3 d: 1 2/5<n><n>### Response option: b<n><n>3/5<n><n>## 344<n>### Instruction : Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>## 324<n>### Instrucion : Answer the following multiple-choice question

Is that statement a question? Explain your answer.<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer: No that's not a question.<n><n>The first part of the statement tells us about Rosa's friends telling her how they are not as famous as her. It just informs about her and it is not a question.<n>Then there is the second part of statement which is a question as it seeks for a information or answer.<n>Because of that the second part of the statement is the only part of sentence where the question mark stands.<n><n>### Input The two girls stood under the balloon. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What is the only was to recover from exhaustion? Choices:  A: mediate B: have rest C: stay in bed D: run out of steam E: go to sleep<n><n>### Response:		E: go to sleep <n><n>### Rationales: B: Have rest cannot be true because we must rest after something.<n>C: Stay in bed will not help;we need to take a rest and relax our mind.<n>D: Run out of steam is a very bad choice (bad).<n>E: Go to sleep is the best answer to recover from exhaustion.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What state south of Kentucky and north of Alabama will you find people playing the fiddle? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What group of musicians will include someone playing the cello? Choices:  A: ocean B: symphony C: band D: music store E: music shop<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer is option C; a symphony is a musical group which includes at least one cello.<n><n>### Rationale: <n>Option A does not include the cello. Option B contains a group of musicians, but it is not defined to include the cello.<n>Option C is the only one that refers to the cello.<n><n>#### 16<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Input A: The number of pages in a chapter in the book "What We Learn in Math" is 40 plus the number of pages in a similar chapter in a different book. Find the 21st term of the geometric sequence that describes how many pages there are in the book.<n>Note: The sum of all the terms in the sequence is 920 pages.<n><n>### Response A:<n>The question asks for the number of pages in the 21st chapter (t = 21), so tn = 920 – (920 - n).<n><n>Therefore, tn = 180<n><n>The first 20 chapters in "What We Learn In Math" have n = 18, so<n><n>then 920 – n = 920 - (180)<n><n>920 + (180) = 180.<n><n>The correct answer is 180. 64 pages for each chapter, plus t = chapter 21.<n><n>#### 6<n>Answer: 180<n>#### 7<n>Answer: 57

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:A person lived in my what? Choices:  A: demonstration B: conference C: building D: garage E: mouth<n><n>### Response:		<n>Ans:E<n><n>### Choices:<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>Answer: B<n><n>Answer: C<n><n>Answer: D<n><n>Answer: E<n><n>Answer: F
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:At the end of your meal what will a waiter do? Choices:  A: serve food B: eat C: set table D: serve meal E: present bill<n><n>### Response:		B, present bill.<n>#### E<n>Answer: E<n><n>### Input<n>If your grade needs to be 5% below 80 for you to pass a math class, how many grades do you need to receive on the final exam to pass?<n>Rationales<n>#### A: You pass if your grade is at least 80 if you have received a grade below 69.<n>#### B: If the grade is above 50, you pass.<n>#### C: Your grade must be above 69.<n>Give me what A&B say: If grade is below, get below 80 grade(pass?). If grade is above, get above 50.<n>This is what A says: Get below 69 or pass. This is what B says: Get above 69 or pass.<n>Conclusion: Either A says and B says, or A says and B doesn't say.<n>####<n>A: 50-80->69(pass)<n>B:55-80->65+5(pass)<n>This is what I think A is saying:<n>59-80->1<n>D:69-80->60->59+1(pass)<n><n>#### 59<n>Answer(I think this should be A): 59<n><n>### Input Input What is the greatest factor of 24, 36, 48, and 60? Choices:  C: 24 is the greatest factor of the list of numbers. D: 24 is not the greatest factor. If we remove a 24, the greatest factor will be something else. E: None of the numbers listed is the greatest factor.<n><n>\[24,36,48,60\]<n>Rationales<n>Give me what D says: If 24 is not it then it is not the greatest factor<n><n>#### E<n>Answer(D):E<n><n>### Input If a person has 4 times as much money than another person, how many dollars are the two people’s combined in all after they each put $100 away for savings? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Which region has the most famous temple? Choices:  A: jerusalem B: jewish community C: middle east D: city E: mosque<n><n>### Response:		Answer B, because the jewish community is the only one that has a temple. Basic operations are operations on primitive data types such as int, str, and bool. These operations are compared, ordered, and processed using mathematical constructs, logical functions, built-in functions, and other operations.<n><n>### Object
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What could listening to music cause you to be? Choices:  A: happy B: smile C: calm D: entertainment E: relaxation<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>Input: Choose all solutions that are possible.<n><n>Input: 33 × 11<n>__ Input: 12 ÷ 3__<n>__ Input: ½ × ½__<n>__ Input: a = 9, x = 3<n>__ Input: a < 5 and b > 4<n>a = 9b = 6<n><n>___a <5 and a >=2_____<n><n>___a <3___<n>___b <5___<n>___b >2___<n>___ a >=2___<n>1 <= x<n><n>___a < x___<n>___b <3___<n>___x >=2___<n>1.1 < 3.1 <n><n>___a = 2 and a < 91___<n>___b = 6____<n><n>___a < 9___<n>___b < 21___<n><n><n><n>### Rationales for choosing "D" as an answer:<n>The input is the equation 33 × 5, which is also called 165.<n>If you look up the answer, 165, on your calculator or a computer,<n>you will get _D___as the answer.<n><n>When you look at the word and phrase problems, you notice that the answers are listed in<n>both _a_ and _d__.<n>The answers in the latter are also the only ones that do not contain letters.<n><n>One way to identify the answer is to look at the operations being performed on numbers.<n>The answer is ______ since multiplication of whole numbers (e.g., a and b) is performed.<n><n>Another way to identify the answer as a whole number is to check for the operations that produce<n>half, third, and fourth of a number. The answer, _____, produces a half (i.e., 165/2), third (i.e.,165/3),<n>and fourth (i.e., ____4).<n><n>One more way to determine the answer as a whole and not a fraction is to check for the relationship<n>between the operation and its inverse. The operation times/divides by will give the same answer, so<n>the answer will be the number (e.g., ____165) not a fraction.<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:"There are 10 apples on an apple tree.  Three fall off.  Now there are X apples."  What is this an example of? Choices:  A: park B: coloring book C: garden center D: math problem E: gravity<n><n>### Response:		B<n>I think the given problem is an example of a coloring book. It is a coloring book since it is referring to coloring, and the number of apples are 10, it is most likely a coloring book.<n><n>I believe it is not a park because there is no way that we could see apples fall off the tree. Also, the problem states that there are 10 appels, and there are 3 appels fall off while there are 1 appel which is left out of the 10.<n><n>I think it is not a garden center because the problem is only referring to 10 apples falling off of the apple tree, and it does not talk about any type of plants or animals.<n><n>It is not a mathematics problem since the problem does not talk about any numbers, it doesn't explain any addition or a differentiation. There is no way this is a math problem.<n><n>It is also not gravity since the problem does not explain any type of gravity or laws so it does not fit the description.<n><n>### Input: Write a sentence explaining how to divide 90 by a tenth.<n><n>### Response:"Divide the number 90 by 10"<n><n>### Input"120 and 393 are prime numbers.  Write them as a product of consecutive integers."<n><n>### Response"We can not write 120 and 121 as a product of consecutive numbers since they are greater than 120."<n><n>### Input "Rose is an example of a living thing.  What is an example of a non-living thing?"<n><n>### Response "Table is an example of a desk is an example of a chair is an example of a table is an example of 2 objects put together. The second and third example is what the problem asks for.<n>

Which of the following is true?<n><n>*   Choice A ______<n>  *   Choice A ___<n>  *   Choices B and C ___<n>  * Choices C and D ____<n><n>#### A:  correct <n><n>### B:  Incorrect; naps are not known to help learning.<n><n>### C:  Incorrect; Choice C does not have any information about whether or not learning can happen after a nap. <n><n>### D:  Incorrect; learning can take place without napping.<n><n>### Naps are not known to directly help learning. However, learning can still take place without proper or even any amount of sleep. This suggests that one is not required to nap if they want to learn. Therefore, B is incorrect since a nap is not known to directly help with learning.<n><n>#### Naps are not know to directly help learning so it is not necessary to naps, hence, Kenny is incorrect. However, the information provided does clarify that the miles between the two locations is 100 miles. Since 100 miles is greater than 70 miles. Therefore, the correct answer is that the distance is more than 70 miles,

Joe will be 100 times as old as Jenny, in as many years as Joe is 1/3 of Jenny's age. Will Joe be about 85 years old, 63 years old, 42 years old, 27 years old, or 14 years old when Jenny is 15 years old?<n>Rationales::Jenny is 15y/3 = <<15y/3=5>>5years old<n>Joe will be 10y*(15y/3)<n>So 153 = <<15*3=45>>45 years old<n>So Joe will be 45+85 = <<45+85=130>>130 years old<n><n>#### 130<n>Answer: 130<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What could prevent someone from buying chistmas presents? Choices:  A: happiness B: lack of money C: stress D: relief E: exhiliration<n><n>### Response:		<n>While writing the code for a task and when using the right data type, you will be able to reduce the amount of code you write compared to the amount of code you would need if writing the code by hand.<n><n>#### A = happiness:<n>Rationales: <n>The amount of money the person has will be the amount of presents they can buy.<n>```<n>var amount_of_money = 1000;<n>var presents = amount_of_moneythrough the loop.<n><n>var result = [<n>    ["jane",3998],<n>    ["mary", 4100],<n>    ["bob",3500],<n>    ];<n>```<n><n>#### B = lack money: A person cannot buy anything if they don’t have money to buy things.<n>```<n>var lack_money = 0;<n><n>var result =<n>```<n><n>1. if (lack_money<=3100), run loop, else end loop<n>2. else if (present<=2000), run loop<n>2. else no more shopping<n><n>#### C = stress:<n>```<n>var stress = 330;<n><n>var whileloop = true;<n>do<n>```<n><n>1) Get amount of presents that person would get<n>````<n>var presents = 3000;<n>2) Get amount of money the person would spend<n>```<n>var amountMoney = 10200;<n><n>print (sum(amountMoney, presents));<n>```<n><n>3) if (sum<present), then no stress, else show<n>```<n>print ("not enough money");<n>```<n><n>4) if (sum>present), then too much pressure, else show<n>```print ("too much money");``<n><n>Do some math<n>```<n>var difference;<n>if(sum)<n>```<n>5) if sum > present, give 20 stress to the person.<n>```<n>Difference = present - sum;<n><n>For (x = 0; x <n>```<n>6) If difference>0, show how much stress they got<n>```<n>If (Difference<=20<n>```<n>7) If difference>20, give 60 stress to the person<n>```<n>Difference + 20;<n><n>Difference+=20<n>```<n><n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What enables most people to transport themselves? How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:He was in a cabin in the woods, through the window he saw a fox where? Choices:  A: indiana B: england C: outside D: on the wall E: picture<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### (a)<n>Demonstration:<n>  (b, a) + (c, c) + (d, c) = <<(b+a)+(c+c)+(d+c)>><n> = <<b+a+b+c+a+c+c+d+c+a+b+a+c>><n> = <<9+2+9+6+2+2+5+2+3+12+2+7>><n> = <<93>><n><n>#### Answer: (a)<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Input::How did the baby get from the window to the chair? Choices: <n>A: The window broke and the baby fell B: The window broke and a ladder fell C: The boy was walking by and picked him up D: The baby was in a toy box<n><n>### Response::<n>#### (a) <n>Demonstration:(a-b) + (a-c) + (a-d) - (a-e) - (a-f)<n>= <<(b-a)+(c-a)+(d-a)+(e-a)+(f-a)>><<2+2+2+0+0>><n>= <<5>><n><n>#### Answer:(a)<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Inputs:On a clear night, it takes an airplane 4 hours to travel 44 miles. The airplane leaves at 11:00. It is the 8th hour after the plane left. What time did the airplane leave the airport?<n><n>### Response<n>#### (a,d,k)<n>Demonstratio:<n>  (a, d) + (a, k) = <<(4+4)+(8+8)>><n> = <<12>><n><n>#### Answer(a)<n>Answer: 12 AM<n><n>### Input:(puzzle)<n>**You're on vacation with A, B, and C. The 5 of you are going to do something together.**<n>**A: Let's go to the mountains.**<n>**B: What if it rains?**<n>**C: What if we go to the mountains?**<n>**A: What if we go somewhere else.**<n>**B & C: Let'
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:John enjoyed his time visiting the museum. There are various types of high schools, and perhaps the basketball court is indoors if the school is a boarding, military, elite or otherwise distinguished, or wealthy school with money.<n><n>If A is outside, and B is an outdoor court in the city, the basketball courts must be mostly found in parks and cities.<n><n>If B means it is an outdoor court, the basketball courts are in parks.<n><n>If C means it is an outdoors court, the basketball court will be in parks. Because radio stations generally specialize in one type of content, they may not necessarily need the microphone boom. However, recording studios, concert venues, and television studios require the microphone boom to amplify sound and convey the full range of emotions to viewers or listeners.<n><n>#### <n>Answer: A<n><n>### Response 2:<n>  Answer: E<n><n>### Rationales:<n> New York likely hosts a vast range of musical bands due to its status as one of the most significant cities globally. They decided to share the money evenly among themselves. They decided to use the pound to represent the different kinds of money. Hank had the same amount of pounds that Dina did. Hank had 5 times as many dollars as Evan had pounds, who had 4 times as many dollars as Hank. That meant that Evan had 4 pounds of dollars. Dina had twice as many pounds as Hank. How many pounds of money do the four of them have?<n>Rationales :<n>Hank has 5 more dollars than Evan<n><n>Dinas value = 1/E<n><n>So Evan has 4 pounds of money<n>hanks is 2 dollars  less than evans<n><n>dinas value = 2/1<n><n>Dinas value is 1/1<n><n>Dina has two times dollars more than hanks<n><n>Then answer is 20 pounds total<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What would an adult man do to get ready for work? Choices:  A: dress herself B: shower C: dress himself D: drink beer E: drive train<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>**If we choose A and C:** The man would shower and dress himself.<n><n>**If we chose B and D:** The man would drink beer.<n><n>**If A and E:** He would drive car or truck around building.<n><n>**If B and E:** The man would drive car or trruck around building and drink beer.<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Simon bought a cow because he wanted to put it to work.   He didn't want any meat for it.  Where might Simon be taking the cow? Choices:  A: countryside B: city C: dairy farm D: butcher shop E: canada<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: countryside<n><n>### Instructions:Use the equation provided to solve for the variable.<n><n>### Equation: x + 4 = [](2x + 4)<n><n>### Method: Add (x + 4) to both sides.<n><n>### Rationales: The number on either side of the = sign stays the same: x + (4 + 4) = [x + 8].<n>This equation is now: x + 4 + 4 = [x +8 + 4]. Add (4 + 4 to both sides. x + 8 + 8 = x + 12.  Remove the 8. x + 12 = x. Solution: x = 0.<n><n>#### 0<n>Answer: 0<n><n>### Instructor:You want to buy a small turtle and a large turtle for your garden. You have \$12 of your own money, and your aunt Lina wants you to have her \$5. How much will you need to borrow?<n><n>### Method<n>Subtract the two budgets together to find the remaining amount you will need to borrow. \$12 - \$5 = \$7.<n><n>#### 7<n>Answer: 7<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What could happen after driving car that does not involve pain? Choices:  A: automobile accidents B: backache C: eye strain D: getting tired E: car crash<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```text<n>D<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice questions.<n><n>### Input 1<n>In a survey of 50 people on the topic, 27 people did not have any pain. Of the 23 people who had pain:<n><n>- 12 had backache<n>- 7 had car crash<n>- 2 were tired<n><n>In total, how many people had pain?<n><n>Rationales: If 27 people did NOT have pain, then everyone is left with 50-27=23.<n>Therefore 50-23=27.<n><n>23 people had pain:<n>- 12/27 had backache (since the number of people who had pain is 23, 27 must be divided by it)<n>- 11 + 7<n><n>- 7/23 had car crash (since the number of pain people is 23, the number of car crash people must be divided by number of pain people)<n>- 2 + 2<n><n>- 2/23 had eye strain (since the number of car crash is 7 and number of pain people is less than it, add 23 and find the number of both together)<n>- 2 is the remaining number<n><n>Now add the numbers,<n><n>- 1 + 1 + 2 +2<n><n><n>That gives us 6<n><n>####6<n>Answer: 6<n><n><n>### Input2<n>In a survey, 55 people did not have any backache:<n><n>- Of the 55 people, if 23 people had backache, how many people had either car crash or eye strain?<n><n>\[32 \div 23 = 13\] So, the answer is 13 people<n><n>Based on what you know,<n><n>- if (total of 55) - eye strain = 23,<n>- then 55 - eye strain = total of 32 - eye strain<n><n>\[55-eyestrain=23+32-eyestrain\]<n><n>(since there were eye strains among the 23 people)<n><n>So number of backache was \[=32-55+23\]<n><n>Now
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:The dog ran to the front window and barked, this is because of a presence at the what? Choices:  A: building B: friend's house C: classroom D: window E: front door<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### E<n>Answer: E<n><n>Rationales: B is incorrect because there is no building.<n>C is incorrect because there is a building but no classroom present.<n><n>A is incorrect because there is only a present at the window.<n><n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>Rationales:'Window' is the correct choice. 'Building' indicates that this is the dog's home.<n><n><n>### Choice A:<n><n>### Choices: A: Yes, he made the right choice B: He wanted the dog to run up and down the hall C: He wanted the dog's attention D: He didn't want the dog to run E: He did want the dog to run<n><n>#### B<n>Answer: B<n><n>Rationales. C is incorrect because of the word "make" in the sentence. If there were no option D, D would be the answer, but he did want the dog to be in his room and not run up and down the halls.<n><n>#### D<n>Answer: D<n><n>Rationales' D is incorrect because he did not want the dog to run.<n><n>#### A, C, and E<n>Answer: None of the above<n><n>Rationales B is incorrect because it implies that he did want the dog in the room.<n>C is incorrect for the same reason.<n>E is incorrect because there are only 3 choices given.<n><n>#### D and E<n>Answer: D and E<n><n>Rationalesis incorrect because A and B are incorrect.<n><n>#### A and C<n>Answer: A and C<n><n>Rationales E is incorrect.<n><n>#### C<n>Answer: C<n><n>Rationalesis correct because "Did" and "did not" are contractions.<n>There is nothing wrong with the "make" statement.<n><n>#### D, E, and F<n>Answer: D, E, and B<n><n>Rationalesis is the correct answer.<n>E is incorrect, because there are only three choices.<n>F is incorrect because there are not 4 total options.<n><n>#### A B and C<n>Answer: B, A, C F, E<n><n>Rationalis that the correct answer is F.<n><n>### Input:\<n>How many more are there in a group of 5 than a group of 4?<n>A: 4 B: 5 C: 6 D: 3

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where can someone keep a digital file? How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Jimmy didn't like going to the party.  It seemed like the guys there did nothing but what? Choices:  A: dance B: getting drunk C: meet new people D: having fun E: have fun<n><n>### Response:		Answer: having fun<n><n>### Explain your response:<n>Because he had fun <n><n># Input:If it's 7 p.m. in Chicago, what time is it in Los Angeles?<n><n># Response: Answer: Los Angeles is 1 hour behind Chicago, so it's 6 pm<n># Explain your response<n># It's the same because one is 7 and the other is 6 so they are both in the opposite time zone because they are one hour away<n><n># Input:In Los Angeles, if it's 8:35 p.m., is it the same time in Chicago?<n># Input:Is the answer 144 minutes apart or 145 minutes apart?<n><n># Response:(2) 144 minutes because 8:35 is 835/24 = <<144>>144 minutes<n># Response:(3) 145 minutes because 835/60 = <<835/6=145>>145 minutes<n># Explain your second response<n># Because a minute is 60 seconds and 835/860 is bigger than eight because 606/60 = 860<n><n># Input:A boy from Detroit was moving to Los Angeles. He wanted to find out how far Los Angeles was from Detroit. Using your fingers, how many fingers do you have to hold up so <n># that the 45th and 46th fingers are in Los Angeles and the 31st and 32nd fingers are in Detroit?<n># In Los Angeles, there are 1,088 people for every 500 people in Detroit. How many total people are in Detroit?<n><n># Response (1): 104 fingers<n># Response (2): 5,000 people<n># Explain 1 (Response:1)<n># It takes 44 fingers since 44/7 = 61<n># For the 50th finger, we subtract 5 f<n># Explain 2 (Response:2)<n># 1,000 fingers for every 100 fingers<n># Therefore, 100/1,000 = 8/10<n># Therefore, 500/1,50
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What is a sign that you might not be living soon? The statement "Exercise is good for one's overall health" certainly describes one particular benefit of exercise, among others that could be listed. <n><n>### Input:"Washing" a car is really a type of painting, as well as cleaning it.<n>What is an antonym for "washing" here? Choices:  a: painting b: cleaning c: caring for d: drying e: polishing<n><n>### Response:"Washing" implies removal of moisture, which the polishing activity prevents if applied to a dry surface. Therefore, the polishing activity does not correspond to "washing." The "painting" activity corresponds to "washing". <n><n>### Question 1.<n>A 72% ≤ x ≤ 78%, is an example of how to find the solution set for which x is a number.<n><n>### A 72% ≥ x ≥ 78%, is an example of how NOT to find the solution set.<n><n>### Question2.<n>A < x ≥ B, is an example of how not to find the solution set; B is the lower bound.<n><n>### An example where C < x ≥ D, is an example of a solution set.<n><n>##### Question 3<n><n>I am 24 years old. 5 years ago, I was twice as old as I am now.<n><n>A) How old will I be in 3 years?<n><n>B) What is my present age?<n><n>My present age is 29 and my present age was 23. This is a problem that can be solved with algebraic equations. <n>

Choices:  A: farm B: business district C: car D: amusement park E: urban area<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: The parking lot is near a roller coater, and not near a farm.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Parking lots are generally found in close proximity to transportation (such as airports or large cities where they often need to serve many commuters).<n>Business districts provide opportunities for the sale of consumer goods and services to nearby customers.<n>Urban areas are densely populated.<n>Amusement parks have large areas set aside for parking and often have separate facilities.<n>Farms do not usually have huge parking lots that are near roller coasters.<n>

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where is known to always have snow? Choices:  A: africa B: north pole C: roof D: canada E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		North pole<n><n>### Explanation:Africa doesn't have snow, but Canada does. The surface of the earth has nothing but water, not snow. The roof is not necessarily cold and there may not be any snow there, either.<n><n>### Input How do you make 938 from 110 - 1?<n><n>### Response 1 + 8<n><n>### Exploration:<n><n>### Input An equation is 12 + 20. How do you make 85 - 5 from it?<n><n>### Examine:<n>12 + 2 + 20 = 85 <n><n>### Output:400<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What is a place that could have hundreds of sporting goods store? The student has to connect the bottles such that the air pressure is balanced. What is the pressure on the first bottle when the second bottle is empty, and the first bottle is full? 3. There are three red flags, two green flags, and one yellow flag. The yellow flag is in the middle of the trio
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What happens to the conscience of someone who has been caught committing a murder? Choices:  A: jail time B: fear C: going to prison D: nothing E: feeling of guilt<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### [A] jail time<n>Rationales: Someone who has committed murder will be given _jail time.<n><n>#### [B] fear<n>Rationales: _fear_ is a sense of feeling that may be provoked by something scary that has happened or is about to happen.<n><n>#### [C] going to prison<n>Rationales: A murderer goes to prison.<n><n>#### [D] nothing<n>Rationales: Nothing happens to the conscience of a murderer.<n><n>#### [E] feeling of guilt<n>Rationales: Since a murder has been committed. The murderer feels guilty.<n><n><n>####[A] jail time, [B] fear, [C] going to Prison, [D] Nothing, [E] feeling of Guilt]<n>####[A] 1 and [B] 4<n><n><n>Input: One cup holds 8 ounces of water. Another cup holds 12 ounces of water, and a third cup holds 15 ounces of water more than half as much as the 2 cups together. How much water does the 3 cups hold total?<n><n>Rationales: For "Cup #1, 8 fl oz": 1 cup x 8 fl oz = "<<1 cup*8 fl oz=8">>8 oz.<n><n>"Cup #2, 12 fl oz" =2 cups x 12 fl ox = "2 cups*8 fl oz="2">"2" fl oz.<n><n>For "Cup #3, 6 fl oz" x 15: "1" cup x 8 fl-oz = "1 cup*12 fl-oz" = "1 cup*8 fl-oz" <"1 cup*8 fl ox" is the same as "<<1 cup*12fl ox=8">>"8" fl oz. A total of "3 cups*8 fl ox="3">"3" cups 24 fl oz.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:How might people perceive someone they are scared of? Choices:  A: human B: happy C: dangerous D: strange E: weird<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: D: strange

Choices:  A: do enjoy B: get laid C: enjoyable D: work less E: enjoy living<n><n>### Response:		<n>*A: do enjoy<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Input: Write the statement that is the correct word order.<n><n>Input: Anita says she wants to go. She wants that tomorrow's party. She wants to the party.<n>Rationales: Anita says she -> the -> that -> wants to go. So, "wants to go" is the correct word order since it occurs later in the sentence compared to "go."<n>Anita says she wants to -> the -> tomorrow's party -> wants. Wants happens later in the sentence compared tomorrow's party and the. So, "want tomorrow's party" is not the correct word order. <n>Anita says -> she wants -> she wants to -> she wants to go. Wants to happens later than she wants in the sentence. So, "she wants go" is not the correct order.<n>Anita says she does -> the -> wants -> she to the party go. Go is later in the sentence compared the and does. So, "go the party" is not the order.<n><n>#### Correct:<n>*Anita says she wants -> to go -> to the party -> wants to.<n><n>#### Incorrect:<n>*Anita's tomorrow -> wants -> party -> the wants -> to go.<n><n>#### In incorrect:<n>*Anita does she wants to -> go to the -> party wants to.<n><n><n>### Input(Optional;):<n>In math, a function must satisfy the following conditions.<n><n>Input:  If g and f are functions such that f(g(x)) = a, what must a = f(b)?<n><n><n>### Rationale:<n>f and g f(g(x) = a is a function.<n>In this context,  f(g(x)=a) means given g, f is applied to g. So, g(x) = the result of the application of f to input x.<n>g(x) is the output for input x.<n><n>f(g(x)) is the result of f being applied to g.<n><n>f(b) is a new b.<n><n>#### <n>Answer: <n>Input: The wording in these statements has something in common?<n><n>Rationales: They are two statements.<n><n>#### 2<n>Answer: <n>Incorrect:<n>- If the
