Choices:  A: nuclear power plant B: center C: basement D: main office E: bowel of the ship<n><n>### Response:		 If P is a prime, then LCM(2,4) = 4.<n><n>Input: P + N = Q. If N > 0. In how many different ways can the number P + N = Q  be equal to each of the first 30 natural numbers?<n><n>The number P + N = 2.<n><n>### Response1:<n><n>In how many different ways can you order 2 + 2?<n>The answer is: A,B,C,2<n><n>Input: The number of balls in an urn is twice as large as the number in an urn that has half as many white balls. In each urn, the number of white balls is a multiple of 6. If there are at least 15 white balls, what is the greatest possible number of balls in each urn?<n>The number of balls in an  urn is 25 - 26 = <<25-26=1>>1.<n><n>###Response2:<n><n>The first number is 6 + 1 which is 7.<n>The second number is 13 + 6 which is 19.<n>The third number is 22 + 5 which is 27.<n>The fourth number is 29 + 3 which is 32.<n>The fifth number is 36 + 2 which is 38.<n>The sixth number is 43 + 1 which is < 44.<n>The last number is 50.<n><n>###Input: How many 3-digit numbers have the form 125, where 1 + 2 + 5 = 8, and none of the values of 1, 2, or 5 are 0?<n>The number is 18.<n>There are 10 numbers with 1 < 10<n>So there are 10 x < 10 = 100<n>There are 9 numbers with 2 < 10<n>There are 8  numbers with 5 < 10<n>Subtract the 100 + 90 + 80 = 270<n>So: 100-270 = -270<n>The -270 is the last digit in the number.<n>The first digit is 1 so: 125
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:There was a show on television about a ranger who loved flowers, but the next day it was about a gardener who also loved flowers.  It was a what? Choices:  A: countryside B: anthology C: dull read D: state park E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		 Answer to Question: The answer here is a, "countryside".

There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:If I have a vintage, decorative light source in my possession, what is it likely to be? Choices:  A: sun B: sky C: candle D: house E: lamp<n><n>### Response:		<n>My response is D) house.<n><n>### Explanation:Light sources include the sun, the sky, candles, and lamps. However, all of these sources are not vintage or decorative.<n><n>### Input/Explanation:An animal exhibit that's a mix of wild and tame animals is a ________. Choices: A: zoo B: sanctuary C: exhibit D: reserve E: enclosure<n><n>### Response/Explanation:C) exhibit (an exhibit is a presentation)<n><n>### I:<n>While working with a coworker on a project, Sam is told by his coworker at a specific day, to meet with a group of people at a specific time. Which of the following is true about these plans?<n><n>### A:<n>Sam was told to meet with the group at the same time as the meeting.<n><n>### B:<n>Sam was told he must meet with the group before he meets the people who are at the meeting.<n><n>\[\begin{array}{l}{ \text { A: }}\\\\{\text { True: }}\\\\{} \\\\{\text { False: }}\\\\\{\left(\text { \text { A:True } }\right)}\\\\ \{ \text { A: False } }\end{array} \]<n><n>### C:<n>Sam will need at least 7 days to complete any project involving a group.<n><n>\[\text{C.}\]Sam is likely to be able to complete a project quickly, especially given that he is not going to be working on any group projects.<n><n>\[\{\left(\text { \left(\text { C: True }\right)}\right)}\]<n><n>\[\{\text { \text { \begin{align} \left(\text { \begin{aligned} \text { \end{aligned} \right) } \end{align} }\end{split} } \}} \left( \begin{aligned}\{\text { True \}& &\Rightarrow & & \end{aligned} & \right. \right. =\text { \left(\left(\text { \color{red}{\underline{True}}\right)}\right)}\right)\]<n><n>### D:<n>Sam will need to meet with the group to meet the manager, who will be at the
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:He was good at traditional science but excelled at social science, his favorite subject was what? Choices:  A: geography B: history studies C: math D: religion E: dancing<n><n>### Response:		Dancing<n>

How many stairs do you have?<n>Rationales:"You can reach the top of TWO flights of stairs faster (than one flight)."<n>"You can reach the top faster, no matter which stairs of staircase you choose...because the speed of each flight's ascent or descent is the same."<n>Therefore, the equation is "2 x SST = (2 SSF)"

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What often happens after a long day of traveling? Choices:  A: sickness B: motion sickness C: relocation D: jet lag E: fatigue<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### How Many Questions Are There?<n>

There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:You can read a magazine where while waiting for your transportation on rails to arrive? Choices:  A: train station B: bookstore C: newsstand D: waiting room E: airport<n><n>### Response:		<n>Ideas:  B B, C<n>Reason: Waiting room, C, is where you can wait to catch a flight.  While waiting for a train at a train station, you can read for pleasure at the bookstore or take a magazine from the newsstand.  In an airport, you can go into the bookstore/newsstand to pick up a magazine.  I'm not sure whether a plane would arrive at the newsstand or the bookstore, however.  You wouldn't be in a waiting room.  You might need to wait at the bookstore. <n><n>### Input:"Sarah is 5 years younger than 20 3 years younger than Tom is. How old is Tom?<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple, choice question.<n>### Demonstraiton:<n>Input: Let us consider the following expressions:  +, +, , +, -, -,  +, +, +, -,... Then write a statement such that for ____, 3 + = < 5.<n>Rationales: 3 + 2 = 5 since 3 + 2 > < 5.<n>5 - 4 = 1 < 5, so<n>1 + 1 = < 5. So + < 5.<n>+ < 5 as well.<n>+ < 2, so + = < 5 since + = 2 + 3.<n>+ = < 5. Since + = +<n>Subtraction < 5.<n>Subtraction < < 5 since subtraction does not change numbers<n>Division < < 5 as well since division does not change numbers.<n>Multiplication < < 5 as multiplication does not change numbers.So, 1 + = < 5 for 1 + 3 + = <1+3+ = 5.<n><n>### Input : A pond has 1/6 of its water drained off by a pipe. Afterward, it has 1/7 of its water left. What fraction of its original volume does the pond lose?<n><n>### Demostration :<n>Input: How many ounces are in 4.80 quarts?<n>Output: 0.25 gallons<n><n>2 quarts is 2/1 = 2/1 =.5

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:The policemen wanted to clear the scene of the accident, so what did they do to traffic? Choices:  A: hurry along B: direct traffic C: help D: force open door E: corner thief<n><n>### Response:		Answer the question with the appropriate choice<n><n>Input:If the cost of a package of groceries is $9.50, plus $2.40 tax, how much is the total?<n>Rationales:(a)Subtraction: $9.50 -$2.40 = <<8.10-2.40=6.00>>6.00.<n>(b)Adding: $9.5 + $6 + $2.4 = <<9.5+6+2.4=20+>22.8>>22.8<n><n>#### 22.8<n>Answer: 22.80<n><n>Input: The length of this problem is 79 inches. In this problem 40% of the length is the width. If the length is 124 inches, would the width be twice the length?<n><n>Rationales: For the length and width to be twice the length, the length must equal 99 and the width equals 28<n><n><n>#### 99
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where would you find performers on a platform in public? Choices:  A: arena B: building C: dock D: concert hall E: museum<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>C is the correct choice.<n>```<n><n>### Input<n>Ann buys a house that has three bedrooms, nine hallways, and five bathrooms. She pays $2 for each bedroom, $3 for each hallway, and $5 for each bathroom.  How much does it cost to buy the house in total? Enter your answer _______<n><n>### Response<n>```<n>165<n>```<n><n>## 3. Find the rule from one set of data that you can use to create the data in another set of data.<n><n>### Input 1<n>Find the rule from the data for Questions 1-4 that you can use to make the data for Questions <5-8>.<n><n>### Response 1<n>```<n>1/2/4/8 is the pattern<n>```<n><n>## Input 2<n><n>Find the rule from <1-4> that you can use to answer the questions in <5-8>. <n><n>## Response 2<n>```<n>5 is 1/2/4 away from 8<n>```<n><n>## #5 - Multiple Step Questions<n><n>### Input5<n>Mary has 40 books. She gives 102 of the books to the school library. The library has 4 times the number of books that Mary took, and the library has 3 less books than Mary. How many books does the library have in all?<n><n>### Response5<n>```<n>Answer: 17<n>```<n><n>##6 - The goal is to answer the questions in the multiple-step format below. Where would you find each pair of students? Choices: A: by the windows B: next to each other C: on opposite sides of the room D: sitting side by side E: all three pairs have the same seating arrangement<n><n>### Response6<n>```<n>Answer: D: all three pairs have he same seating arrangement.<n>```<n><n>Output(input 6):<n>```<n>All three pairs of students have the same seating arrangements.<n>```<n><n>Input (question 8)<n><n>### Response8<n>```<n>Answer: B<n>```
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:A balloon or two is a staple at a what? Choices:  A: birthday party B: child's hand C: grocery store D: sky E: up in the<n><n>### Response:		<n>C:<n><n>### Rationale: It is a birthday party.<n><n>### Input:"The sky is the limit" means? Choices:  The sky is a boundary.  The sky is the beginning.  The sky is an example.  The sky is full of options.  The sky is your limit.  The sky is a sign.<n><n>### Response:"The sky is your limit" means there are no boundaries.<n><n>### Rationales: In a sense, the sky is limitless; it is full to the sky and beyond.<n><n><a href="https://rosettacode.org" target="_blank"><img src="https://github.com/jacques-rosettacode/jacques-web/raw/main/assets/RosettaCode.svg" srcset="https://github.githubassets.com/images/modules/opengraph/actionsherobanner.png?v=502326494" width="100" height="160" alt="Rosetta Code" /></a>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where do people find bills with bread? Choices:  A: restaurant B: congress C: envelope D: mail box E: cheese store<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n><n>#### Input: There are 3 mice and 2 cats.The average weight of the cats is 11 pounds. D = C E 3 = 3.<n><n>### Response : D or E<n><n><n>### Instructions<n>Write a code that performs the following:<n><n>#### Input: P = (9, 7, 23) <n>Q = (25, 19, 36) <n>Output: P + Q = P = Q<n><n>#### Solution<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where can you eat fruit on a red bridge? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What makes people happy when it is surprising and unexpected? Choices:  A: joke B: humor C: frightened D: fight E: laughter<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>A: joke- people laugh when it is a surprising joke.<n>B: humor- laughter is caused by funny movies, shows, events, etc..<n>C: frightened- people smile when they are surprised when they are scared.<n>D: fight- the reason why people fight is because they are not pleased when someone does something.<n>E: laughter- laughter is the result of events, jokes and other forms of amusement.<n><n>### Response 2:<n>I believe that people are happy when they are surprised by laughter.<n><n>### Comments<n>#### A: <n>* Humor is often intended to make people laugh.<n><n>#### B: <n>* Humans laugh when they find something funny, which is why humor makes people laugh.<n><n>[Answers](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1g-8kj3Q0p2sB_XM_y_bjB_ViYC4RBKbz0QrF8EhjFtJU/edit)<n>[Rationales](https://docs.lms.io/h/B3MZ1EO6E/edit#fold=1&_k=x5gwvk69)<n>

Anita is a bookkeeper for a group that publishes an annual statistical review of economic conditions. She creates charts of government and private expenditures for each type of commodity. She uses the following code to prepare the charts.<n><n>    A: The income statement is a statement for all firms<n><n>    A: Revenues are equal to total payments that customers make<n><n>    B: The income statement equals the balance sheet<n><n>    C: The income statement shows the movement of the income balance<n><n>    D: The income statement shows money that is received<n><n>    E: The income statement shows all of these transactions<n><n>    F: The cash flow statement shows the money that is spent<n><n>    G: The cash flow can be used to pay off loans<n><n><n>### Rationales:<n>Income statement is a statement for a firm. Since revenues are the money customers pay for the products and services. So, the total revenues are revenues minus cost of goods sold. Therefore, the balance sheet is the income statement + equity + assets - liabilities. The cash flow statement is the income statement + cash flow from operating activities + cash flow from investing activities + cash flow form financing activities.<n><n>#### 8. A<n><n>### Input E, C, B<n><n>### E: If you add up the price of all the goods sold to companies and then subtract the amount of goods and services, you will get the company's profit or loss.<n>C:  The income statement is a summary statement for a firm, which shows how well the company handled its cash flow of dollars.<n>B: Income statement is used to find out how well a company utilized its cash flow.<n><n>### E, C, B Answer<n><n>### Instractions:Complete each task by marking the letters that best describe the relationship.<n><n>### A. Which of the following statements is true?<n><n>##

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:After the guilty verdict in the killing the judge gave a speech, he told the murderer he was pure what? Choices:  A: wrong B: death of C: bad D: negative E: evil<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Input<n>How many of the following sets of fractions are equivalent: \[14 \over 7,\{2,1\} \over 1\] or \[4 \over 38,\{3,1\}\]?<n>#### 2/1<n>Answer: 4/38<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: \[14 \div 7,\{2\}=\]2 and \[\div 1,\{1\}\_/1=1\]Rationales: \[14 \ov 7,\over 1\]<n>= \[14 \ov \frac17 = \frac 2 7,2,1\]<n>The only two fractions with two parts are 2 and 1.<n>Two equivalent fractions have the same numerator and the same denominator, for two fractions A and B, \[A = _B:A = B\]<n>so the answer is: 1.Two fractions equivalent to 2 are \[4 \div 36,\{3,\{1\} \}=2.\]2.All other fractions which have two parts, are equivalent to the first pair of fractions.<n>#### 2<n>Answer: All except 2/1<n><n>### 3<n>Answer: The fractions are equivalent, but their denominators are not the same.<n><n>### Input:[5 \div 6] \times [3/8] or [15 \mathrel{\mkern9mu\smash{\circ}} 3] \times [13 \mathrel{\mkerno9mu\smash{{\circ}}}]?<n><n>#### 4/1<n>Answer: The first equation is 5/24, which is equivalent to 1/4<n><n>#### 5/1<n>Answer: All have the denominator 48, but the numerators have been changed.

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:The billionaire donated a large sum to his former college, this allowed them to construct a new science what? The value increased 86%.<n>What does the 86% mean as a fraction?<n>1 : _____, 2 : _____, 3 : _____, 4 : _____, 5: _____<n><n>#### 1<n>Answer: 7<n><n>#### 2<n>Answer: 6<n><n>#### 3<n>Answer: 9<n><n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>#### 5<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input<n>Ronald has 3 books and 5 toys. He got 6 books and 4 toys for Christmas. How many toys does Ronald have now?<n><n>### Response<n>Rationales: Ronald began with 3 + 5 = <<3+5=8>>8 books and 5 items.<n><n>Then, he had 8 - 6 = <<8-6=2>>2 books and 5 toy less than the 5 he started.<n><n>Therefore, he has 2 + 4 = <<2+4=6>>6 toys now.<n><n>Because it is impossible to have a negative number of books, the 6 is a book, meaning he has 7 toys.<n><n>#### 6<n>Answer: 7 <n><n>### Instructin:Answer the question.<n>Which one of the following correctly solves this problem?<n><n>### Demostration: Solution:<n>19 + 14 + 5 = 38<n><n>#### 38<n>Answer: 38<n><n>### Input1: The numbers shown here express the same quantity. Which expression should be in this position and why?<n>12 * 8 ÷ 3 8 − 12 12 ÷ 8<n><n>### Response1: 8-12 =
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:An attempt to confirm an applicant's reference would fail if the reference does what? Choices:  A: question B: dispute C: deny D: contradict E: refuse<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Rationales:C: deny: Deny; disagree; refute.<n><n>### D: contradict: To say something that contradicts, rejects, or refutes what is just said<n><n>### Input:"John likes playing baseball. Bob does not like to play baseball at all. Will the following sentence be a complete or incomplete sentence? Choices: A: I like playing baseball better than I like playing tennis. B: I like playing baseball more than playing tennis. C: I like playing baseball, but I do not like playing tennis. D: I like playing baseball; therefore, I like playing tennis, too." E: I like playing baseball just fine."<n><n>### Response:"I like playing baseball more than I like playing tennis."<n><n>### Rationale":"like playing baseball" and "I like playing baseball" have the same referent, which renders the latter phrase redundant. In contrast, the last two phrases contain redundant prepositions. So, the first, third, and fourth phrases are not complete sentences.<n><n>---

There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What is someone unintentionally hurting someone else but unable to stop likely to feel? Choices:  A: empowering B: regret C: despair D: glee E: sadness<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct alternative is D.<n>When someone unintentionally harms someone else they are unlikely to feel glee, because it will likely make them upset.<n>Empowering does not makes sense because empowering someone does not hurt them. Regret and despair are emotional responses to bad situations. Empowering is not sad.<n><n>### Correct answer:D<n><n>### Input<n><n>#### 65<n>I can't get enough of the ___. It's such an awesome game! I've played it for hours and just can't get enough!<n>#### 43<n>There's ___, and ___, and then there's the cute girl that all the guys are after. It's all right - she says she's going out with me.<n>#### 24<n>I want to know all I can about the new  ____ I'll have tomorrow.<n><n>___, ____, and the ___ can make a great combination, so they say.<n>___, ___, and then ___ - oh, I do hope she's not ___, or I'll be ___ ____.<n>#### 96<n>I want to know ___ about the job.<n>#### 17<n>You know ___ about ___.<n>#### 9<n>I'm quite sure that he meant ___ when he said ___.<n>#### 36<n>Have ___ about ___. I don't know my ___ very well if I know ___, but I know I like ___ a lot.<n>#### 35<n>___ and ___ do me fine, but I ___ that I like ___.<n>#### 23<n>Think you that you know ___ about ___?<n>#### 18<n>What do you think about ___? He's ___ to ___.<n>#### 60<n>I'd like to be able to ___, but I've ___ about that. Can you ___ about ___ for ___?<n>####4,036<n>You say that the company's products ___, but I ___.<n>#### 430<n>Have ___ about any ___? I've been thinking ___ and ___ but cannot think up ___.<n><n>#### 1,394<n>The ___ who ___
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Sally was a senior in the House.  What might she be a member of? Choices:  A: assisted living facility B: old people's home C: high school or college D: republican party E: organization<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>### Demos:<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### Detailed Answer:<n><n>## Input:<n><n>### What might she be a  member of?<n><n>### Choices: A: assisted living  facility<n><n>### B: old people' s home<n><n>### C: high school or collage<n><n>### D: republican party<n><n>### E: organization<n><n><n>## Response<n><n>- I agree that Sally maybe a  member of Assisted living facility<n>- Old peoples home<n><n>- High school or collage<n>- Organization<n><n>- I don't think she is a republican party cause  She is a senior<n><n>## Rationales<n><n>- I don’t understand your choice, C, cause Sally is senior<n>- And  I don’t understand why Sally is not college student because she is in High school  cause in high school Sally is college student<n>

Choices:  A: graph B: bank at noon C: good book D: post office E: bus stop<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions:<n>1. Complete the multiple choice question: In the table below, a column of numbers is followed in successive rows by an equal amount of the same number and equal spacing between each pair. Then, the table is rotated 180 degrees, followed by a row of numbers that increase by an amount that increases by 1 in every row.  You then rotate the table again, followed by a row that is the same as row 8, followed by a row where the numbers have alternated such that the second number is larger than the first, and so on. What number does that last row have?<n>2. Demonstration: If I were to rotate the table twice and the last row, the fifth row, the third, first and last line would be the numbers 9, 3, 4, 8, 10, 14, 10 and 12. The sum of the numbers which are in the table is: 3 + 4 + 8 + 10 + 14 + 9 + 10 = 56. The sum of the first half of the table is: 9 + 3 + 4 = 16. The sum of each set in the table is:  9 + 3 +  4 + 10 +   8 + 14 +  10 + 9 + 4 + 12 + 3 = 73  16+(56-13)=112  6+56-13=79  45+56-17=98 The sum of the sixth row is 25 which means the last line is the 25th one from the last one.<n><n>#### 25<n>Answer: 25<n><n>### Instructoin: What other 2-digit numbers will produce 25 when each number from 1 to 50 is added to it?<n><n>### Demostration: Start from 10. We have this:10+1 = 11<n>10+2 = 12 (Same as 1)<n>10+3 = 13<n>10+4 = 14<n>10+5 = 15<n>10+6 = 16<n>10+7 = 17<n>1

Choices: 730°—-170° 460°— 170° 730° + 170°<n><n>### Response::<n>The difference between 73° and 17° is 56°.<n><n>### Response to:<n>```swift<n>var degrees, sum = 0, sum2 = 0<n>for degrees in 1...401 {<n>sum2 = sum + degrees<n>sum = sum2 + degrees<n>}<n>```<n><n>## Part II: Roles and Responsibilities<n>### Instruction:: Describe a situation at your last job that required you to work cooperatively with coworkers.<n>### Rationales: The scenario of how I learned to work cooperatively:<n>> In our workplace, we have four offices, and each office has four employees. We used to have no interpersonal relations. People did their work but did not communicate or cooperate with others unless they were asked specifically.<n>><n>> We met and tried to find ways to resolve our problems, and we decided that we should work together to make more sales. One of our customers was from Texas, and each office had their sales department that would contact the client from their office. When the customer asked where his goods were, the person in the office closest to that person would go get them, even though it wasn’t their job to do so. This happened most of the time, and after a while, each office started to make more business with that customer and other new customers, too. And then all of the offices started to act more cooperatively. We are a lot more successful now that we all work together in a friendly environment and we help each other out a lot

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:John loves animals and he hates animal abuse. Choices:  A: work hard B: slow down C: wear shoes D: sell products E: speed up<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### A: work hard:<n><n>```csharp<n>Console.WriteLine (a.ToString () )<n>Console.WriteLine (b.ToString () )<n>```<n><n>#### B: slow down:<n><n>```c#,<n>for (int i=1; i<cscount++i++)<n>{<n>  Console.WriteLine (itemType[i] + ")");<n>}<n>```<n><n>#### C: wear shoes:<n><n>```c#<n>if (cscount<cscount)<n>{<n>  Console<n>}<n>```<n>### Outlook:<n>The user should select “A” for option of telling Ali to work hard since “A” is the most relevant and beneficial option in this scenario.<n><n>### Question:How would you answer the following multiple choice question if the following question?<n><n>### Input/Rationales:<n><n>#### Choice A: What would you tell Alex to do? Choices: A: work hard B C: slow down D) wear shoes E: speed up<n>Choice A: What would you say to Alvin to do? Choices A: Work to make more money B: Go to the mall C: Go home D: Get a job E: Study for exams<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>#### Choices:<n><n>#### Answer:<n>[![](https://img.shields.io/static/v1?style=flat-square&label=Solution&message=1&color=%234ec0fc&logo=vscode&logoColor=%23000000)](https://codepen.io/RajdeepTuli27/details/OJqLXdq)<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What do people do to pass time before they can use electronics when fly in airplane? Choices:  A: read B: passenger C: land plane D: fly the plane E: buy tickets<n><n>### Response:		Passengers have to wait the plane land at their destinations when they fly with airplane.  But they do not read magazines, buy tickets, land the plane, or fly the plane.  They do need to read books, buy tickets, do nothing.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>### Passengers have to wait when the plane lands at their destinations to use electronic.<n><n>### Passenger will read magazines or books are wrong responses.<n><n>### Choice: Passenger will do nothing are wrong responses.<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What preposition do you use if you want to combine two words? Choices:  A: article B: adjective C: interjection D: conjunction E: pronoun<n><n>### Response:		 Choice: B: adjective<n><n>Input: The dog is on the table. The cat is next to it. What is in front of the dog?<n>Rationales:: Since dog is an adjective.<n>So it is in front of the table (since the table is in front of the cat)<n>#### Cats<n>Answer: Table<n><n>Input: A: article B: interjection C: adverb D: pronoun E: adjective<n><n>Answer: B: an interjection<n><n>Input: Incorrect: The dog is in front of it.<n>Rationales: Since the dog is an adverb.<n>It's in front of it (since dog is in front of the adverb it)<n>#### Dog<n>Answer: In front of it<n><n>### Input<n>"The cat is in front of the chair"<n>What is in the back of the cat?<n>#### Cats<n><n>Answer: behind the chair<n><n>Input: What number less than 20 does -3 equal?<n>Rationales:"-3" = <<-3= 3-3= -6>>-3 = -6<n>#### -6<n>Answer:"-6"<n><n>Input:What number is 3 more than twice a number that is 2 less than 6?<n>Rationales:-4 = 3 - (2 - 6)<n>2 = 2 - 6<n>6 < 8 => 2 < 8<n>4 = -2 -8<n>6 = -4 + 8<n>#### -2<n>Answer:"-2"<n><n>Input: In 1880, the town of Kearney, Nebraska had a population (people) of 8000. Ten years later in 1890, the number (people) had more than tripled. What was the size of the population (people) in 1898?<n>Rationales:(8000 + 10x) = 3x<n>8000 = 2x<n>1890 = 3x<n>1898 = 2x + 10x<n>1896 = 3x<n>2 = 2 + 10 => 3 = 3<n>1896 + 3 = 1900<n>1898 + 3 = 2000<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where in your home would you store birth control pills near your toothpaste? Choices:  A: medicine cabinet B: chemist's shop C: kitchen D: drug store E: bedroom<n><n>### Response:		Answer the question.<n><n>## Rationales:<n>The toothpaste would be stored in the kitchen, not the bedroom or the drug store.<n>It makes sense to keep it near the toothbrush so I can easily remember to take one pill every morning while I brush my teeth.<n><n>It would not make sense to keep the toothpaste in the medicine cabinet because if I leave the house in a hurry, I do not have time to go through the cabinet to find it.<n>Therefore, the bedroom and the drug store should not be considered options because they provide the extra inconvenience of making me leave my house.<n><n>I could choose option A if I do not want the pills within my reach without taking up too much space.<n>One downside would be that I have to remember to buy new pills. Also, I know that most over-the-counter painkillers or cold medicines are located somewhere in the medicine cabinet.<n><n>So, by not putting it in those convenient locations, I am choosing to put my toothpaste near my mouth.<n><n>## Answer:Bedroom<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What has happened to a person's money after he or she has used the last of it? Choices:  A: dissipate B: flown C: disintegrate D: fall apart E: penultimate<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### The best choice is <<E:The money has become the people's last, and they have to wait to get it back.>>E<n><n>### Demand in the first round of the game: If a player is on the game. Then he is required to choose one among four numbers and it is possible that he lost or not depending on whether it matches the value chosen by another player.<n><n>### Round 0: In round 0, no player has won yet, but the first four players (Kate, John, Peter, and Sam) were already chosen. <n><n>### Round n: In every round, some players have been lost while new players have entered the game. Round n is similar to the first round except that the players in this round, besides the new comers, are the winners and the losers in the rounds that went before the current. The winners have won at least one rounds while the losers have not won yet.<n>A player has winnings if they have chosen the same number for more than one round.<n><n>### Example 1: In the game, some players have 10 winnings, while other players have 20 winnings. No one player has 29 winnings, so no player has chosen 29 since the first round.<n><n>## Input: <<In the following game, 1000 players were chosen at random and participated in the game. Every player got a point if the number chosen in the game match the first character of a randomly chosen player's last name. How many players received 50 or more points?>><n><n>### Demonic Response:  505<n>Answer: 550<n><n>### Input, for example, after 10 rounds<n><n>### Demographic response:<<Four of 10 players have winnings because those 4 were chosen in the first four rounds.>><n><n>### After 20 rounds:<<10 players got winnings because they are the only 10 players left at round #20.>><n><n>## Instruction: The following question is written in multiple-choice format.<n><n>### Rationales:123<n><n>##| 2|2345<n>A: [21],<n>B: [39],<n>C: [23

There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. Choices:  A: cinema B: opera C: party D: stage E: dance<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### **Performer at a gathering**<n><n>![](./figures/gathering_of_friends/scene.png)<n><n>1. Performance (in the dance) is happening at the party.<n><n>#### 3<n>Answer: C<n><n>Input: In the class trip, there were 7 children who had their picture taken by their teacher. There were a third as many as the number of students in the class. This meant that 21 children had their picture taken. The principal gave a <n>gift to each of the remaining children and a 2 dollars to each child whose picture was taken. For every four children whose picture was not taken, the principal gave a 5 dollars. Which child is likely to have the largest gift?<n>Rationales:\<n>There are 7 children who had picture taken in the dance class, so there were 7/3 = <<7/3=2>>2 children who were taken photos out of a class of 21 children.<n>Each child who was not given a picture has 5 $/4 = <<5/4=1.25>>1.25$, and each child who was given a photo has 2 $/2 = <<2/2=1>>1$.<n>So, the gift of the child who got a picture is 1.25 times larger than the gift of each child who was not given photo in the dance class.<n>#### 6.125<n>Answer: B<n><n>![](./captchabody.jpg)<n>>### Instruction:<n><n>A local supermarket that sells pies, each weighing 125 ounces. The cost of a pie is 3 pounds. The store has 300 pie weights available, and it needs 200 of the pie. If every weight is 125 ounce(oz), how many pounds are left unused?<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>### Deduction:<n><n>**300-200 = 100**<n><n>### Conclusion:<n><n>\[(pounds-300)/300 pounds/3 pounds] $=>$ 200/300$$.<n><n>\### 6,666,666<n><n>Answer: B<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:He called bull when his friend said a bull can be what? Choices:  A: feeble B: bullbleep C: cow D: female E: charging prey<n><n>### Response:		<n>You have got E<n><n>### Explanation<n>The number of choices of the correct answer, and the amount that is given:<n><n>Choices:  A: 4 B: 2<n>Correct Answer: E: 1<n><n>### Excessive Number of Choices or Choices That Fill the Answer Space<n>You can see above the questions have an excessive number of choices, and one does not fit in the space.<n><n>So the teacher may ask:What is it?<n><n>Now you need to answer if it can fit into the answer space and give a meaningful example of a bull.<n><n><n>### Input 2:<n>#### Answer:<n>16<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Choose either C, E, or H as possible solutions for the problem based on which two letters you know to start with. For any given letter, the answer will contain the same letter twice.<n><n>### Letters:<n>E: 8<n>C: 4<n>H: 5<n><n>### Rationale for C:<n>#### Rationale:<n>It's the second letter E is next to H. Therefore, 2 E = H.<n>#### Rationale: <n>It's the first letter H is next to E. Therefore, 8 H = E<n>```<n>C → A<n>```<n><n>### Rationales for E:<n>#### Rational:<n>The 8 E is next to C. So, we get 8 H = E.<n>#### Rationale<n>:1:  E = R<n><n>### Rationals for H:<n>#### Rationales:<n>As a hint, it is given a different number of letters so that we can use all of the possible letters.<n>H = K<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>If we choose  both H and K as an answer, HK = KH<n>KH = (2) 6 (4 and 8)<n><n>#### Answer:<n>R: 6 H: 6 K: 9<n><n>### Solved Example E and H:<n><n>Input: If EY and HY were different and R and H are the same, the 6th letter is what?<n>If E: Y =  R and H = 6 Letter Answer : 9<n><n>## Sample Answer (H and R)<n><n>Example 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:James drove his niece to her father. The italicized word is the problem. Replace the underlined portion by restoring the normal word in the sentence.<n><n>### Correction:Replace the underlined portion in red with the correct answer found in the answer key.<n><n>### Input:"If you are a student, you may borrow $12.50 for books each semester." Replace "borrow" with "can borrow".<n><n>### Answer:Replace "borrow" with can<n><n>### Input:'Misty may be able to play.' Replace "may be able to play" with "may play".<n><n>### CorrelationAnswer:Replace "may be able to" with "may".<n><n>### Input:}The bookstore's hours are Monday through Friday from 10:00 a.m. to 4:10:00 p.m." Replace "00" with "00:00".<n><n>### Answers:The bookstore's day ends at 4:00:00 p:m on Thursday because they close for a few minutes for some reason.<n><n>### Output<n><n>### Corruption: The day starts when the customer can check out at 1:00 p. m at night.<n><n>### Answer<n><n>#### No answer found<n><n>### Input:`My teacher's aunt may come for dinner tonight.' Replace'may come' with'may be here'."Replace ``may be here`` with `may attend`.<n><n>#### 28.D: <n>Answers: `replace ``may come`` with `may be here`, replace `may be here` with `may attend`.`

A<n><n>### Input & Output: Choose the right choice.<n>A store made and sold 40 cents, 1 orange, or 20 inches of cheese.<n><n>### Input<n>**If it was a candy store, how much money**<n><n>\- if it was an ice cream store, how much ice cream<n><n>- if it was a shoe store, how much shoes<n><n>- if it were a clothing store, how many new shirts were sold<n><n>\- then how many dollars<n><n>### Output & Reasoning<n>The store made <<<1000c>>1000c.<n><n>### Other Inputs: 40, 1 orange, and 20 inches<n><n>### Response<n>If it were an ice cream store and sold <<<40>>40 cents,<n><n>- then there would be <<<1>>1 orange<n><n>- and sold <<<10^2>>10 orange cheeses.<n><n>Therefore, there is <<<1+1+10^2>>91.26 cheese.<n><n>The candy store sold <<<1980>>c and 1 orange.<n><n>### Response & Rationales<n>If it were a shoe store<n><n>- then there were <<<<1980>>>1980>>1980 shoes<n><n>- also there were 1 orange.<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. My dad has (7) books more than I do. My mom has twice as many as I have - (3) books more than I.how many books do we have at home?<n>### Answer:2<n><n>### Input<n><n>Choices:  I: 20 R: 30 P: 35 O: 55<n><n>### Response<n><n>The total of I, R, P, and O is 20 + 30 + 35 + 55 = 140. I, R, P are the numbers that appear in the problem.<n>140 is greater than 30 and greater than 20; so there is 30 less than 140.<n>So I less than 30 less than (140-30).<n>Then, there is 20 less than 30.<n><n>### Response Question:<n>Write a sentence or phrase to complete the question that reads:<n><n>Input: My favorite number is ___.<n><n>###

She wants to give each of her children a different number of apples.<n><n>Each child is to receive 2 3-digit numbers of apples, and the difference between these numbers is to be 300.<n><n>Write a rule for determining which 3-digit number is given to a child.<n><n>The woman has at least ____ apples left over.<n><n>####8545<n>Answer: 8545<n><n>### Instructons<n><n><n>How tall is a person? A book measures 7 inches. A yardstick is 4 inches longer than a book. 4 inches times 3 equals 12 inches. A yardstik measures 12 + 5 = 17 inches.<n><n>How tall is that person?<n><n>####125<n>Answer: 1,250.00<n><n><n>###Instructons:<n><n>Your class has a total of 9 green hats and 7 white hats. The principal gives you a hat and a hat is removed. After that you have one more green hat and four fewer white hats. How many hats do you have?<n><n>####23<n>Answer: 2,300.00<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where would you find a desk normally occupied by a young person? Choices:  A: office building B: schoolroom C: library D: bedroom E: gym<n><n>### Response:		If it is not used for something else (i.e., to be used for a bed or kitchen table) then it would be found in a desk in a bedroom.<n><n>#### 3:  Not in the gym<n>#### 4:  Not in the bedroom (A)<n>#### 5:  Not in the library (D)<n>#### 6:  Not in an office building (B)<n>#### 7:  Not in a schoolroom (C)<n>#### 8:  Not in a gym	<n>#### 9:  Not in a library (D)<n><n>#### 3

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:People celebrate by going places and riding rides. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What happens to people when they do not have enough food? Choices:  A: eat fish B: they steal C: talk to each other D: write stories E: die of starvation<n><n>### Response:		What happens to people when they don’t have enough food?<n><n>### Demostrations:<n>A: If people have enough food, then they don’t eat fish or steal from stores.<n>B: Talking to each other can help a person to understand what is happening in the world of the community. <n>C: A person who has enough food can write stories and can understand the world around him/her better.<n>D: A person who has not enough food to eat, will die of starvation.<n><n>### Answer: What happens to people if they don’t have food?<n><n>#### 2<n>Answer:<n><n>### Demotration:<n>Exercise A: (10pts)<n>Input: When the wind blows, the sail helps the boat to go faster.<n>Output: When the wind blow, the sail help to boat go faster<n><n>Exercise 2: (5pts)<n>Input: It is winter in Iceland.<n>Output: It is winter is Iceland.<n><n>Exercise A 3: (5 pts)<n>Input: There are no pencils on the desk.<n>Output: There is no pencil on the table.<n><n>### Exercise B,C & D: Choose the following to be A,B & C:<n><n>**Exercise B**<n>Input: The car is in the garage.<n>Output: The car is in garage.<n><n>**Exercice C**<n>Input: The cat is in the house.<n>Output: The cat is in house.<n><n>**Excercise D**<n>Input: The air is very hot.<n>Output: The air is very very hot.<n><n>#### (3pts)<n>Exercise 1 C<n><n>** Input: How many ounces are in 9.33 pounds?<n><n>Exercise C2:<n><n>** Input: (10pts-puzzle question)How many times is 9.33 times 3.021? **<n><n>Exercise D: <n><n>** Input: The train was only one third of the length of the bus, but it traveled twice as fast. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined.
