Therefore,  B  is  the  correct choice. <n><n>#### B<n><n>###  Input:Ask the Question:What is it? The first one is the longest-lasting type of candy. Which confection is that? I'm going to answer that question.  Which one is an unpleasant noise that  a person makes when  he or she is unhappy, frightened or angry or in pain?<n><n>### Response 1:<n><n>A<n><n>## Input:<n><n>* I'm going to  answer that question.<n>* Which one is an un - pleasant sound  that a person  makes  when  he  or she is unw e ll - pleased, frightened or angry  or in pain.<n><n>### Response<n><n>A<n><n>* Rationale <n><n>* I' m going to answer that question is not the correct answer since the answer is not stated  in that statement.<n><n>* The next statement:<n><n>> which  one is an - unpleasant  sound  that a person makes when he or she is  well-pleased, frightened or an - gr y or in pain?<n>* Rationale 19's statement suggests that the question to be answered is:<n><n>> What  is an unpleasant sound that a person makes when  well-pleased frightened angry or  in pain?<n><n>* The above question can be simplified as follows:<n><n>* "What is an unpleasant - sound that a  person makes  well pleased,  frightened  or angry, or in pain?"<n>* Rationale 2<n><n>* There - are three types of sounds:<n><n>- sounds in words;<n>- sounds in letters;<n>- phoneme.<n><n>* When people speak, there are sounds in words.  These sounds are silent
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:He was selling all his collector items even the rare plate, he had bought a lot at the what for the weekend? Choices:  A: supermarket B: kitchen cupboard C: table D: flea market E: dishwasher<n><n>### Response:		The answer is letter D.<n><n>For more instructions: [Review 5.2](https://github.com/Nikhil-Hariharan/HolidayFare/blob/master/Review%205.2/review_5.2.md).

Choices:  A: large city B: seattle C: curry D: clothing E: reservation<n><n>### Response:		<n>### What:<n>### You can see that the answer depends on the questioner and your answer. If you ask someone "What do you want for dinner?", it can mean a variety of things. Are you looking for a meal suggestion, food preference, or a choice between multiple meals? The answer depends on what the person wants you to get from asking the question.<n><n>## Output:<n>### When a questioner asks what it is that you want or need, that person may need more information. If you are buying dinner for four people, the questioner will probably want to know what each individual wants to eat. If you are at a friend's house and you're about to go into the kitchen, your friend may be asking what you want to help with.<n><n>### You'll notice in these examples below that the questioner doesn't ask a lot of follow-up questions. They assume that the answer from their listener will be something specific.<n><n>### John might ask "What might john order at the indian resturant over the space needle?"<n><n>### "A: large city B: Seattle C: curry D- Clothing"<n><n>### "Curry"<n><n>### Curry is a dish of many cultures and uses many ingredients.<n><n>### But for John it would be an Indian resturant up on the space needle on his first trip to Seattle from Texas which is why I went with C.<n><n>### The clothing option was never going to be chosen because as a first time visitor I wasn't going to get a chance to pick it out.<n><n>### This is a real example, this was a test taken in college.<n><n>### Curious that the curry thing was missed.<n><n>### A follow up question might be "Did you like yours? You should check out an actual place instead of eating there."<n><n>### The person might then say "I like it but I also like the clothing and curry is my favorite food."<n><n>### Whenever someone says "I like" or "I don't like" to me, I can't help asking why.<n><n>### People will say that they don't like broccoli. I'll say "Why don't you like broccoli?" They say "I don'

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where can you buy a hairbrush along with bandages? Choices:  A: drugstore B: hospital C: bedroom D: car E: house<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### If A, the hairbrush and bandages can be purchased in a drugstore. The patient would need to get the items from somewhere else.<n>### If B, the hairbrush, and bandages can be found in a household. The patient would only need to get it from somewhere else if it is lost.<n>### If C, the hospital store is the only place. The hairbrush and bandage would be located where they treat the patients.<n>### If D, the car is the only place. If the patient broke a mirror while driving, they would purchase it from there.<n><n>### D<n><n>### Rationale:<n>If a patient cut himself with the hairbrush, the hairbrush would likely reside in a bedroom. Then, if a patient cut herself with the bandage, that would likely be located in the first aid kit in the car.<n><n>### Output: The patient will need to go to drugstore.<n><n>### If E, the patient would purchase them from a drugstore. First, they would obtain the hairbrush and buy the bandages. Then, if they needed anything else, they would get those items.<n><n>### E<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The hairbrush and band-aid belong in the same category, so they would be found in one place.<n>The patient would need something else to bandage the wound. This would be found in somewhere else.<n><n>### Response if A or B:<n>### The hospital or the drugstore would need to provide those items.<n>### The patient will need to get the necessary items from the hospital or the drugstore.<n><n><n>### If C:<n>### The hairbrush and the first aid kit would be in different places, so it would have to be purchased at two different times.<n>### The hair brush will need the band-aid while it is located at the hospital.<n><n>### Answer C:<n><n>### The first aid kit will be located at a different place. The hair brush and the band-aid are the only things that have the same location.<n><n>### The bedroom would be the place the patient is able to find the hair brush.<n><n>### There are places where the first aid kit can be located. However, if the patient does
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where would a restaurant put a candle? Choices:  A: dimly lit room B: kitchen C: wall D: table E: birthday cake<n><n>### Response:		C  <n><n>### Explanation:There should be a birthday cake, candles, etc. somewhere near the table for children.<n>

(40-23=17) Joe has 3 green sticks, 6 green sticks and 12 yellow sticks for a total of green sticks and 36 sticks. (36-32=4) Joe has 8 pink sticks and 2 yellow sticks totaling 10 sticks. (10-8=2) Joe has 4+9+10+10+2= 49 sticks<n><n>### ------------------------------------------------------------<n><n>### Write a response that appropriatley completes the blank.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:A person with children might have a lot of plastic things in what place? Choices:  A: cupboard B: cabinet C: own home D: everything E: garbage dump<n><n>### Response:		The object of this exercise is to demonstrate the ability to select the correct option.<n><n>#### A<n>Rationales:<n>Based on the context, a person with children will probably have (or may have) a lot of plastic stuff.<n>A person with children may refer to the parents of children. <n>Therefore, the correct choice is A, which states, "owner home." <n>### A: cupboard<n><n>```<n>Answer: A<n>```<n><n>### Response 1<n>Rationales: <n>When the instructions stated, "A person with children might," there is a possibility that the individual in reference might be the person with children, but could also be someone with children. This choice could refer to the child. Since this option is referring to what one could refer to another person, it is most correct for the answer to be C.<n>For example,<n>A man who owns a cupboard may choose the answer and say "This means me." or he may choose the meaning of the cupboard. This answer doesn't make sense since he is not the owner of the child. The answer is C, which is the best answer for this question.<n>### D<n>Rationales: This choice does not seem to answer the question directly. <n>It does not seem to fit in with how the question is being approached. <n>It does seem to be a plausible answer, but we are searching for a better response.<n>### E<n>Rationales: It does not seem that the word "garbage" is connected well with the other words. <n>It is not an acceptable answer because it does not seem to fit the rest of the questions. <n>The question is being worded around the word, "plastic," and the word "garbage," does not seem to fit that term.<n>### Reference:<n>https://www.academia.edu/19658237/Practice_of_Learning_to_Critique_Multiple_Choice_Questions<n><n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:A bride and groom are taking care of proposals, what is the likely ceremony? Choices:  A: efficiency B: getting work done C: marriage D: finishing up E: results<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### A efficiency<n>#### B getting work done<n>#### C marriage<n>#### D finishing up<n>#### E results<n><n>#### A efficiency<n><n>### Instructions:<n>#### Answer a short essay type question related to the following topic.<n><n>### Topic:<n><n>### Demand a response that reflects your understanding and application of the concepts covered in the topic and their connections to any other topics.<n><n>###<n><n>### What is the most appropriate title for the video?<n><n>### Demos:<n>#### A: A bride and groom take care of wedding proposals at an office<n>#### 9%<n>Answer: A: A bride<n>#### and groom take care<n>#### 23%<n>Answer: B: taking care<n>#### of wedding proposals<n>#### 7%<n>Answer: C: office<n>#### at an<n>#### 2%<n>Answer: E: a video<n><n>#### What is the most appropriate topic for the video?<n>#### Demonstrations:<n>#### A: Money<n>#### 66%<n>Answer: B family<n>#### C: Happiness<n>#### 33%<n>Answer: C family<n>#### D: Ecology<n>#### 0%<n>Answer: C Family<n>#### E: Food<n>#### 0% Answer: C Family<n><n>### Describe the main purpose of the video in one phrase or a sentence.<n>#### Demonstration: A: 2%<n>#### B: 33%<n>#### C: 11%<n>#### D: 34%<n>#### 0% A: Influence<n>#### C:<n>#### 0% E: Sell stuff<n><n>#### <n><n>### Demonic:<n>A: 11% Influence<n>#### B: 17% to sell stuff<n>#### C: 63% to influence<n><n>A: 17% To sell stuff<n><n>### What type of video is this? How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where would someone be likely to store a double edge razor? Choices:  A: pocket B: shower C: chemist D: drug store E: shaving kit<n><n>### Response:		Answer: A: Pocket<n><n>### Rationale: Most likely in your jeans or work shirt pocket.<n><n>A double edge razor is not much bigger than other small items that go in a pocket.<n><n>### Input where:<n>What is 84 x 19 + 648 - 3?<n>In your own words, express the task as a mathematical calculation.<n><n>### Question:<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input:<n><n>1. 84 x 2 + 648<n><n>2. -3<n><n>Rationales: 6 x 4 = <<6x4>>24<n>19 is double 9<n>0 + 0 + 0 +... = 0<n>9 - 1 = 8<n>The answer is 24 + 8 = <<24+8>>32<n><n>#### 32<n>Answer: 32<n><n>### Input How do you calculate the largest three digit integer that has an exponent of 0.5?<n><n>### Demos:<n>Input: Calculate the largest three-digit integer that has an exponent with the value of 0.5.<n><n>Rationales:"Integer " has 2 letters between the 2nd O and 4th letter (e) and is between the letters (e) and (3) = 5<n>120 has 4 letters between the 2 and (3) and is between (3) and (4) = 0<n><n><n>### Input Output:What is 5.463 * round to one?<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demostration:Input:<n><n>### Input<n>What is 4.423 rounded to the nearest 10th?<n><n>### Response<n>204.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The answer: 202.3 rounded to 4 is 204.<n>### Rounds the number 200 to the nearest 1.<n><n>### Round to the nearest 1: 200.25 200.333333 200.4757576 200.5<n><n>### The value that is nearest is 2
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Eating breakfast with a large family leads to a pile of what in the sink? Choices:  A: fullness B: underwear C: bad breath D: better day E: dirty dishes<n><n>### Response:		The correct choice is underwear.<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Output

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where you have finished a conversation with a person what do you say? Choices:  A: open letter B: thank god C: say goodbye D: bless you E: listen to radio<n><n>### Response:		The only correct answer is option D: "Bless you". (Since the person is out of the earshot he can't get the message)<n>#### Blur the out of our mind when the conversation is uncomfortable or you can't understand what the person is saying.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where would you put a computer other than a desk? The remaining students are in elementary school. If 320% of the Middle schoolers buy food to support the school, how much food will be needed?<n>Rationales<n>(A) 320/100 = <320/110 = 3">3/4 of 320 = <32/40 = 21/20>21/20 students.<n>Elementary students = 40 ÷ (720 * 100%) = <40/72000*100%">3200/72 students.<n>Multiply 21/21 by number of elementary students = 40.<n>The food needed is 3200/40 ≈<3200 / 40*10000= 75000>>75000<n>#### 7500<n>Answer: 7500

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Society cannot exist without numbers.   They only rise up in what sort of spaces? Choices:  A: population B: populated area C: create government D: group of people E: make person sick<n><n>### Response:		<n>[Response](Society%20cannot%20exist%20without%20numbers.htm)<n><n>### Input and Response:<n>Society cannot exist unless they are in what sort of places, and where does the word numbers are not the word used in what is population? Choices: A: population B: population of government C: population group D: population of population E: population of government of population<n><n>[Society cannot exist within numbers](Society cannot exist with in numbers.htm)<n>Answer: Society cannot exist within numbers.<n><n>### Input<n>How many pounds in a bushel? Choices A: 4 B: 5 C: 6 D: 9 E: 8<n><n>[Input](How much weight in a bushel.htm)<n>Answer = 5 <n><n>### Input <n>How many quarts in a gallon? Choices A: Quarts B: Half gallons C: 3 quarters D: Pints E: Pounds<n><n>[Input](Quart in a gallon.htm)<n>Answer=8<n><n>### Input  <n>How many pints in a quart? Choices A: Pounds B: Pounds C: Pounds D: Quarts E: Galls<n><n>[Input](Pint in a quart.htm)<n><n>Answer=4<n><n>### Task:<n>Input <n>Choices A: More than fifty percent B: More than eight percent C: More than 30 percent D: More than 40 percent E: Less than 10 percent<n><n>[Task](More than fifty percent.htm)<n><n><n>Answer=A <n><n>### Task<n>Input <n>Chooses A: Less than 13 percent B: Less than 18 percent C: Less than 22 percent D: Less than 28 percent E: Less than ten percent<n><n>[Task input](Less than ten percent.htm)<n>Answer B <n><n>### <n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Bill bought an upright piano but didn't have anywhere to put it because he lived where? Choices:  A: band B: music room C: college D: university E: house<n><n>### Response:		<n>    Band<n><n>### Reasons:<n>When looking on the piano, it appears to be a band.

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What could you find at a bus station that can help you? Choices:  A: city centre B: lottery ticket C: maps D: street E: busy city<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer for this question is C: maps. This is because at a bus station, there are maps which can help the passenger find places in the city.<n><n>***<n>***<n>***<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Demand:<n><n>### Rules:<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Input #4<n>Given a series of letters and an operation, write a response that computes the sum of the series (excluding the letter that is chosen).<n><n>### Demopnation:<n>Example: Given the series, 'abc'. Add the first and last letter of the series. (First letter added is 'a', last letter is 'c'.) Then the answer will be 'ac'.<n><n>### Answer<n>Input: "abc" is the series. Add the first and last letters of the series. (first letter added is A. Last letter is C.) The answer is "AC".<n><n>Input: "aad"; Add the first and last series letters "a" to "a". The answer is "aaaaaad".<n><n>### Answer #2<n>The first and the last digits are "x" and "5", respectively. The answer is "xxx".<n><n>### Demography<n>The question asks to add the first and last letters in a given series. Example: "abc" has three letters: a, b, and c. So, the answer is "ac".<n><n>### Rationale<n>When solving this problem, notice that all letters are added before the one that is in between and after it. <n><n>First, add the first and last digits. Then add the second and last digit. And then finally, add the middle and last digit. <n><n>For the answer, "A + C = AC".<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What would you use if you wanted to make some columns of numbers? How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. Choices:  A: drawer B: back to its owner C: police station D: crime scene E: holster<n><n>### Response:		I believe you meant to say the following,<n>The investigator examined the gun evidence.<n>#### <n>Answer: C<n><n>### InputThe number of pencils in the box is 2/3 as what as much as the number of pens<n>Rationales: 2/3 of 7 equals 4/3 of 7.<n>The answer is the number of pencils = 7<n>#### <n>Answer D<n><n>### The difference betwen x and -7 is -9. What is the value of x?<n><n>### Rationales:<n>x +(-7 )-(-9) = x - (-7 + -9)<n>Therefore the value of x is 2<n>#### <n>Answer B<n><n>### Instructions:<n>A man's age is one tenth of his brother's age. Fouryears after his birthday, the difference between his age and that of his brother is not equal to eight. Write a two step inequality that can be used to find how long time the man and his brother take turns in birthday.<n><n>###Rationales 2x +2y -8 =2x -2y -8 <n><n>###The man is twice his brother's age, after how many years should they take turns in birthday<n>##### <n>Answer D<n>The man and his brother are at the ages x and y.<n>After 4 years, this means that the man gets x+4, and the brother gets y+4<n>The difference between the two will thus be (x + 4 - (y +4) = -(y-x) <n>The difference between the ages would thus be 2y - x.<n>So their ages are 1/2 apart. 2y-x >8 would then mean that y-x > 8<n>###Rationalization:<n>4 years after their birthday the man gets x+ 4 but the brother has to get the age that is two times the age he gets 9 years after <n>and that is y=2x<n><n>###I need to find y<n>#####<n>Answer D<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What do all rooms facing outside have? Choices:  A: square shape B: different sizes C: flowers D: doors and windows E: high walls<n><n>### Response:		What do all rooms in a house have? Choices A and B: doors and windows B, C and D: different rooms E: high walls Choices A, C and D: windows Choices A, D and E: flower Choice D: different sides<n><n>### Demostration:<n>#### 252<n>Input: Which of the following are used to count money? Choices: A: coins and bills B: pennies and dimes C: dimes and quarters D: money and credit cards E: coins and credit cards F: banks and bank accounts<n><n>#### 453<n> Input: Which of the following people has two sisters? Choices: A. Adam B. Chris C. Emma D. Sam E: Mike<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Explain why it is incorrect to answer the question with answer (110/2) = <<110/-2=55>> 55. <n><n>### Demos:<n>#### 545<n><n>### Demstration:<n>**How many blocks did Pete walk in all?**<n>Rationales: For the second time, Pete walked 5/5 blocks. In total, he walked 5 + 5 = <<5/5+5=10>>10 blocks.<n>#### 458<n><n>### Answer:<n>P.S.<n>If you need help on anything else, you may get in touch.<n><n>---<n><n><p><img src="https://res.cloudinary.com/davidmichaelg/image/upload/v1535717570/Cover_1.png" /><n><div style="text-align: center" align="center"><a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/kyle-michael-rutherford-b1b97512/"><img src="https://media.giphy.com/media/xTQ756DYX57l6/giphy.gif" width="75px" /></a><a href="https://github.com/KyleMicheal01583">Github</a></div><div style="text-decoration:underline;text-align:center" align="center"><p><
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What usually happens to people who are models? Choices:  A: very ugly B: appear beautiful C: free slaves D: pay bills E: suffering pain<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Answer: Model A: appear beautiful<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: A father drove his car the same amount of time as his daughter drove her truck. He drove twice as many days as his daughter drove her car. How many days did he and his daughter drive combined?<n>Rationales: They drove each cars for a total of 2d days.<n>The father drove his car 2d/3 times.<n>The daughter drove her car 2d/d times.<n>So, The father and the daughter drove their cars and the truck for a total of 3d + 1d = 5d days.<n>#### 5 * 3  = 15<n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Instractions:<n>#### Answer a question.<n>Input: A person travels 4 miles in an hour. How many hours does it take to travel 15 miles?<n>Rationales::If it takes x hours to travel y miles, the formula x = y/x.<n>So, the hours needed to travel 15 is 15/x = x.<n>Therefore, x = 15/x ≈ ∞<n><n>#### ∞ = ∞<n>Answer: ∞<n><n>### Input<n>#### Answer a question:<n>> A person drives from Atlanta, Georgia to Los Angeles, California. Along her trip, she covers 100 miles and stops for the night. The next day she covers another 80 miles and again stops for the night.<n> > _________________________________________________________________________<n> > ________________________________________<n>> > _____________________________________<n> Input: A person drives from Atlanta... ______________________________________<n> Rationales: The driver started from Atlanta. She drove 100 miles. So,<n> she's at the destination.<n> The driver drove 100 + (80 × 2) = 250 miles when she arrived in Los Angeles.<n> There aren't enough hours in the day to<n> drive 250 miles.<n>#### 250 < 24<n>Answer: 250 <24<n><n>### Input - The sum of a number and 8 is 11. What number? ***********<n>Rationales: _________________

There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Why would someone be wet after being full of fear? Choices:  A: run B: swimming C: calculate things quickly D: fight enemy E: urinate<n><n>### Response:		 Choice: E: Urinate Answer: E<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the following instructions.<n><n>### Input :I bought a 12 pack of water. I drank one and threw the rest away. Write a sentence to replace the question mark. If I throw away 6 cans, how many did I drink?<n><n>### Rationales : I drank one 6 cans of water and threw the rest away<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Inputs:A dog will sleep 16 hours a day. Write a sentence to complete each question.<n><n>## Instructions:Choose one: A: It sleeps 16 hours and 48 minutes<n>	   or	  B: It sleeps 48 minutes and 16 hours<n>	   or 	 C: 48:16 (hours) equals 16<n><n>### Rationale:A and C are the answers to the questions and therefore should be choices among the answers.<n>	   or  Answer:C (48:16(hr))<n>#### 48/16<n>Answer: 48/18<n><n>### Input:(1) How many cokes were sold yesterday?<n>(   		(0/48)  = number of cokes sold<n><n>(2)  8 more cokes were sold than yesterday.<n>(   		 (48/48)  - 8 = number of cokes were sold<n><n>Answer: 40/48<n><n>### Rate:If you are 16 years old, how long will it take u to turn 32?<n>	   or Choices:(A) 9 years (as u turn 21 and then 32 for 9 years)<n>	   or (B)  9:1 = 32:21 as u turn into 21 then 32<n><n>### Ration:B is the answer since u turn 21 for 9 years and then 32.<n>#### 9:1<n>Answer: 9<n><n>### Input:"Which part of the sentence should be in italics?"<n>This sentence says: I _____ on my bike. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Dan outfitted his house to run on the oldest heat source on Earth. What is the oldest heat source on Earth? Choices:  A: fire B: solar energy C: sun D: house E: coal or wood<n><n>### Response:		The correct response is: solar energy.<n><n>### Rationale: the energy source on earth where it comes from the sun which uses sunlight as the first energy source.<n><n>### Input:(4x + 1)/(x + 3): What is the value of the quotient? Choices: A a) 3 B b) 1 C c) -4 d) 7 e) 3<n><n>### Response:(4x + 0)/(x + 0): The quotient is 4x/x=<<4/x>>3x. Since the dividend is 0, the quotient is 0.<n><n>### Response2<n>We can divide both sides and get 4x/4=<<4/4>>1.<n>Therefore, the quotient is equal to 1.<n>#### 1<n>Answer: 1<n><n>### Input (3x + 6)/(2x - 5): What is the value expressed as a quotient of the dividend and the divisor? Choices: A. 2:1 B. 3:1 C. 2:2 D. 1:1 E. 2:1<n><n>### Response<n>(3x + 0)/(-5): The quotient is -3x/5  =<<-3/-5>>-15/5.The dividend, 3x is negative so the answer is negative.<n><n>#### -15/5<n>Answer: -15/5

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:James was delayed for a couple of hours because he had a connection. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What is the opposite of foolhardy? Choices:  A: thoughtful B: discreet C: calculated D: cautious E: careful<n><n>### Response:		<n>There are three ways to know the correct answer from choices. The word that describes the meaning of 'foolhardy' is the opposite.<n>The opposite of foolhardy is careful, and cautious. The correct answer is therefore 'E'.<n><n>### Input A and B:<n>A: What is the opposite of foolish? B: discreet<n><n>### Response A and B:<n>The word that describes the meaning is the opposite. The opposite of foolish is discreet. The correct answer is "B".<n><n>### Input C and D.<n>C: Which of these is an example of a word with a root word and a suffix? D: B: the root word ‘wild’ and the suffix ‘er’.<n><n>### Response C and D:<n>The correct answers are 'C' and 'B'.<n><n>### Instructions:What is the sum of 8 + 9 + 18?<n><n>### Demostrations:8 + 9 + <<18="18">>18 = 25<n><n>### Answer:<n>The sum is a total value of 8 + 18 = <<8+18=26>>26.<n>The sum is 26 + 9 = <<26+9=35>>35.<n>The sum is therefore 25.<n><n>### Input E:<n>Mike is traveling from Austin to Houston on a bus. The bus leaves Austin going 70 mph. The bus leaves Houston for Austin going 55 mph. When the bus leaves Austin, it is traveling for 1 hour and 45 minutes. When the bus leaves Houston, it is traveling 85 minutes. What is the total trip time?<n><n>### Reponse E:<n>The total trip time is the elapsed time of travel from Austin to Houston. (Time left in Houston). The total time of travel is (2 hrs x 85 mph) + (90 mins x 70 mph) = 170 mph + 630 mph = <<170*100+630*100>>630<n>Therefore, the answer is <<630*1.6 = 1004>>334 and 3 hours;

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where would you see some people standing on a line near a road? Choices:  A: water fountain B: military base C: apartment D: fire house E: bus stop<n><n>### Response:		<n>If you are standing near a road you are on a bus stop.<n><n>#### 55<n>Answer:<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Demosturation:<n><n>Input: If you multiply 6 by 4, what is the problem? Choices: A: you multiply by 3 B: you get 12 C: you add 3 D: you divide by 3 E: You should use the x mark<n><n>### Rationale:<n>If you multiply by 4, you get 6x4 = <<6*4=24>>24.<n>#### 24<n>Answer:<n><n>> ## References<n>><n>> <https://www.so-l.ru/content/l28n/l31n/010409/0.shtml> |<n>><n>> <http://www.math-salamanders.com/pythagoras_theorem.html><n><n>### Exemplar:<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input: What does 10,000 times 350 equal to? Choices: A:: you have 350 thousand B. You have 35 million C. You have $350,000. D. You have $3.5 million E. You have $3,500.<n><n>### Response<n><n>10,00 = <<10,00=10,00>>10<n>350 x 10 = <<350*10=3,500>>3500<n>3500 x 100 = <<35,00*100=350,000>>35,000.<n>#### 35,00,000<n>Answer:<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:If a student was about to graduate, they would no longer be attending what? Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Where may I view sharks in a clear tunnel? Choices:  A: south pacific B: sea world C: pacific ocean D: indian ocean E: gulf of mexico<n><n>### Response:		<n>C: pacific ocean (Correct)<n><n>Input: A man purchased 50 pounds of tomatoes. He had the tomatoes weighed and 15 pounds were overweight. He returned 8 pounds. How much tomatoes does he have left over all?<n>Rationaless: Because he returned 8 pounds, his new weight is 50 - 15 - 8 = <<50-15-8=40>>43 pounds.<n>(Overweight is the same as extra tomatoes; the extra tomatoes represent the overweight.)<n>Therefore, the extra weight is 40.<n>#### 43<n>Answer: 43<n><n>Input: In school, there are 15 new hats available in 8 different colors. There are 16 students who want hats. Choose 2 hats from each color to give each student a hat. How many different hats can there be?<n><n>Rationale: There is a total of 8 colors. The students can each get 2 hats from 8 colors = 16; each student can get 2 hats. The only exception is if a student gets 1 hat of his color and 1 hat of another color, we subtract 1 and re-choose. If there are 12 hats, we have (15 * 2) - (12 * 2) -1 = (30 - 24) -1 = 6 hats.<n><n>#### 8 * 16<n>Answer: 128<n><n><details><n>  <summary>In class, Maddie received 4 green marbles, 3 blue marbles, and 2 white marbles. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:If clothes have developed a smell and can't be washed what should you do with them? Choices:  A: hang in closet B: sniff C: get dirty D: become soiled E: air out<n><n>### Response:		<n>In the context of this task, the students are supposed to recognize that the correct option is E.<n>In the sentence “… if clothes have developed a sm…,” the students should guess which word should be replaced by an appropriate alternative, based on the context. In order to do so, they must remember that they should add contextual information to a word in order to understand it.<n>To “hang in closet” means to put a person, animal, place, or object in a position where the person, animal, or place remains standing. So this option is not the best one since clothes are not objects like people.<n>To “sniff” means to smell intensely. So, this option is not the correct one since smelling clothes is not common since they do not have a nose like a person.<n>To “get dirty” means to become unclean. So, this option also is not appropriate since dirty clothes are clothes that lose their original clean color and become unclean. The correct option is E meaning “to air out.” In this case, the students should understand that to air out clothes means to let them stay in the air, usually outside, on a windy day.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>1. Clothes are not objects like people but are clothes.<n>- Therefore, the correct option is E (air out).<n><n>2. To smell strongly with one’s nose is possible only for living objects that have noses like humans.<n>- So, the option A (get dirty) is not appropriate because humans cannot smell clothes.<n><n>3. The color of clothes is not alive like the noses of humans.<n>- So option B (sniff) is not appropriate.<n><n>4. Clothes cannot stay out in the wind (unless they are tied) like people and animals.<n>- Therefore, option C (hang in closet) is not appropriate. <n><n>5. Clothes have no body where wind blows on them and they cannot become unclean like humans and animals. Instead, they lose their original clean color.<n>- So, option D (made soiled) is not appropriate. They must be replaced.  <n><n>### Input  : What is the first step to take to make cheesecake?<n><n>### Response  :<n>The first step to making cheesecake is to make a batter. Here are the steps to making a batter.

Choices:  A: intelligence B: education C: effectiveness D: distress E: a stupid<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### D: distress<n>Input: What might the inability to read cause? Choices: A: vision problems B: distress C: confusion D: an inability to teach E: a stupid choice<n><n>Rationales: An inability to read means an inability to teach because knowledge is power. To teach someone you need to read what you are going to teach to that person. If you don't read then you are not going to be able to teach. Therefore, distress would not be an appropriate choice.<n><n>#### E: a stupid choice A: the ability to read C: confusion B: vision problems D: an inability <n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>### Solution:<n>#### Solution 1:<n><n>```python<n>print("The correct answer is "D")<n>```<n>```python<n>def solve_exercises():<n>    return print("The correct answer is D")<n>```<n><n>#### Solution 2:<n><n>```python <n>def solve_exercise(string,index):<n>    if (index <= 0):<n>        return<n>      <n>    else:<n>        print("The correct answer " + string[(index-1)-1]+"")<n>```<n>```<n>def problem_2():<n>    for string in input_questions():<n>        # print(input_question[0])<n>        print(input_question[(0)-1])<n>```<n>```python <n>problem_2()<n>```<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:People were talking on the corner, who were they talking with? Choices:  A: god B: mix C: with people D: have friends E: see people<n><n>### Response:		Choices: a b c d e<n><n>### Note:This is a multiple response problem.<n><n>### Answer Choices: A: E B: A C: B D: A E: D<n><n>### Answer Summary:<n>

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:Danny hated helping people.  It always brought what? Choices:  A: satisfaction B: good feelings C: complications D: feel good about yourself E: stress<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Dem:<n>Danny hated helping other people because he often had to deal with complications that arose after aiding someone.<n><n>### Dumb question, I know, but here it is anyway:
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:What is something you do  in a bank? Choices:  A: make noise B: have tea C: make time D: make payments E: take time<n><n>### Response:		<n>Your answer is A. A customer comes to a bank and gets their account from the teller. Often, the teller is noisy. <n><n>### Input<n>```<n>Which of the following statements is true? Choices:  C: None  B: Both  A: The first  D: The second<n>```<n><n>### Response<n>Your answer is C. Both statements are true.<n><n>### Input <n>Input: The first man to have gone on the Moon was an American. Therefore, Neil Armstrong was probably an American. The last man to climb Mount Everest died while attempting the climb. Therefore, a person who dies while attempting to climb Mount Everst is not the last person to climb Mount Everet.<n>(Note: Neil Armstrong did NOT die attempting to climb Mount EVERest)<n><n>### Response <n>Your answer is the third one.

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>### Input:If a human wants to enjoy another human's company, where might they go? Choices:  A: place of work B: office C: friend's house D: workplace E: deep thought<n><n>### Response:		Choice: B<n><n>### Rationales: A:Place of work: The place where a human works is their job.<n>B:Office: This is another word that means place of work.<n>C:Friend's house: A human's friend is another human.<n>D:Workplace: A human's workplace is also known as their job.<n>E:Deep thought: This is referring to thinking.<n>
